When I tried to get reimbursed for the damages, I was denied by Nest. They stated a faulty Transformer on my A/C unit was the cause. THAT was NOT the case according the my A/C guy.
title: Garbage! Do NOT buy.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Gagan
content: its 6 months out. The networking has stopped working. Troubleshooted as directed. Even a professional came and checked it. It is simply now a regular thermostat. I had 2 of them now both with same issues. Its a scam. Please avoid.
title: Do not install it if you don't have 5 wired system. Networking failed in 2 out of 2 nests in 6 months.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Matt
content: I thought the Nest thermostat was going to be amazing. It's expensive, high tech, and top of the line. But it has been a disappointment. There's no hold feature. Probably so you don't forget and waste energy. But it will turn off all the time for no reason. Or the other way around. It will turn on even after you have adjusted the temperature to avoid it. I have turned off all the "smart" features and it still seems to do. The only way to stop it is to turkey turn it off. Another problem is the software. I've had multiple times where it has randomly stopped charging. When this happens the wifi will cut out. After research it has been shown to a software issue that hasn't been fixed yet. I have also purchased the remote sensor and have had connection problems with it when using it just feet away. On a positive side. The screen is a nice feature. I like how it displays the weather when walking by. Choosing which site to use would be nice. Something I'm sure nest would have to set up contracts with. The WiFi is obviously the main feature in a thermostat like this. And scheduling is a breeze using the app vs traditional thermostats. A fun, high tech gadget that needs to get the bugs worked out.
title: Really wanted to love it

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Amazon Customer
content: This thermostat worked great Jan-Sept 2018. I had it integrated with Alexa and could voice control everything. I loved it. All of a sudden after 9 months of use with no issues, I come home to a very hot house and a red light blinking on my nest. Apparently Nest wasn’t able to stay charged with the amount of power it was receiving. I checked the voltage and got 27Vac... adequate power from my Rh wire. Called Nest tech support and they tell me I need to call an HVAC professional to install a common wire. I don’t understand how this device worked perfectly fine for 9 months heating and cooling perfectly and now they tell me it’s an issue with MY home’s wiring. I call BS on this. Sounds like a device issue with the battery to me!! Not impressed at all with tech support. So now I have my old low tech thermostat reinstalled working just fine and this Nest is now an expensive  paperweight :(
title: Do not buy!!! Battery issues!!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: StudioPeg
content: December 2019:  Installed flawlessly.  Integrated with Alexa flawlessly.  All just to insidiously enter my home to torment me! This thing has a mind of its own.  I've had it installed for one month, and twice I have come home to a 54 degree house (cat and dog doing forbidden things together to stay warm, icicles in the toilet bowl) and three times to an 80 degree house (palm trees sprouting, vacation webites advertising my house for a winter getaway). Many times the furnace just won't shut off despite exceeding the programmed temperature, and I have to go down in the basement and flip the switch manually as even turning the Nest all the way down did not shut it off.  But other times it will reach the programmed temperature and shut off properly.  "Ahh" I think, "it's working now."  I could hear its quiet evil laughter...  20 seconds later the furnace kicks back on for another cycle. So I turned off the learning feature and set my own schedule.  Didn't matter, none of the glitches changed.  My natural gas and electricity bills this month are going to be through the roof.  And this thermostat is supposed to save energy? Nah, at night it makes surreptitious visits with the gas and electricity companies promising them even more money! I gave in and called my HVAC guy who could not find anything wrong with the wiring.  The install was perfect.  He pulled out an unused common wire in the wall and added it and reconfigured the wiring to see if it would help.  Nope.  That cost me $141.50 - their minimum home visit charge. All so I could say "Alexa, set the heat to 72" from the comfort of my couch.  Gahhh!! Good thing I saved my old manually-programmable thermostat.  Back on it goes.
title: A mind of its own.....

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: arboritionist
content: The first one we got we had to return as it would not connect to wifi. The replacement worked well on our dual fuel system for about 2 years then began to fail sending signals for the gas furnace to turn on (yes, we already have a C wire). Then it started short cycling the heat pump. Nest support sent a replacement backplate instead of a Nest for some reason, probably cheaper for them. After it failed to help, they refused any more support and blamed the system. We called our HVAC guy who came out, checked our system, determined the Nest was bad and recommended we avoid Nest when we get a replacement thermostat as they had had so many issues with Nest.  We got a competing brand thermostat and now everything works again as it should.
title: Nice idea, poor build quality. Stay away!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: No Public name
content: Product probably works well, but I spent two hours prepping the dry wall, texture and paint and then wiring and testing so the thermostat could be mounted to the wall in an attractive manner.  Then went on line and signed onto Nest System, followed ALL instructions.  IT DID NOT WORK.  I called customer service and their rep, DwightS, carefully walked me through identifying any issues.  He is fantastic.  But alas, the Thermostat is incompatible with my Carrier AC system.  It would be a great improvement if there was an online Nest web page that asked a potential customer the ID information on the existing thermostat and whether it is compatible.
title: He is fantastic. But alas

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: norsebavarian
content: Do not buy, this thing is the worst!  The problem is you will think it’s great for about 6 months to a year, then your troubles begin.  What you can expect.  Constant disconnects from your WiFi “thermostat offline”. Internal battery goes bad after about a year.  The base plate will go bad. All of these wonderful issues will have you on the phone with nest for a minimum of 90 minutes each time trying to trouble shoot.  If you insist on buying a nest thermostat, do it at a big box store so when one of these issues occurs you can go buy another, swap your defective unit and return it to the store. I am on my 3rd thermostat in 1.5 years.
title: The worst thermostat ever

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: S. Krauss
content: I reserve the right to change this rating if this gets resolved, but right now I'm very annoyed with this product. For the most part I like it. It's a nice clean design, and I like the auto-away functionality. But after a week's use it is repeatedly dropping off wi-fi because the battery is not charging off the low-voltage wires like it is supposed to. Which ultimately means it's not that much better than the digital thermostat it replaced and which will go back up on the wall if I have to send this back. It's nice that it has a micro-USB port on the back to plug it into a wall to recharge, but that is not a viable solution in my book. I have an older house, and the only wires I have are Y1, W1, G, and Rc. I had it hooked up to Rh originally, but when I started researching this problem a post said to try Rc instead. It made no difference. The thermostat will eventually charge enough to get above the 3.7v it needs to connect to wi-fi, but then hours later it will drop off wi-fi again. Which means I cannot control the thermostat with my app at the minimum. What other functionality it loses when it has no wi-fi connection I don't really know. I sent an email to Nest customer support. We'll see what happens.
title: Constant Low Battery, Drops Off Wi-Fi

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: The Writer
content: Installation is not bad, setup involves a lot of steps, and it keeps wanting to dial back the temperature settings.  I find that I have to keep checking to make sure it hasn't decided to only cool to 77 instead of the 74 I told it to.  I suppose it will learn and adjust eventually, but it has been several weeks now and it keeps wanting to change settings while I'm asleep. It also only has one sensor (like most conventional units) so I have to guess what to set it to in order to make sure that my office (south facing, second floor) gets enough air conditioning.  If I had this to do again, I might have been better off with something that uses multiple sensors. The software interface on my phone is easy enough to use, but not great.
title: Looks nice, but does not work as well as claimed

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: ZoomDoc
content: So because I purchased Amazon in home installation for about 116 bucks this review can cover both. The product integrates with my nest app. Flawless operation at least for air conditioner. In winter I’ll do the heating. Versatile WiFi control with my phone, allows me to turn it on and off from virtually anywhere. Now where I have an issue is with the installer. Technically competent but poor in disguising some underlying intentions. First all of the stupid questions. What work do I do for a living ?Response a lie. Then where is my furnace ?My response a lie. He’s is walking in areas that have zero to do with installation of the device. I told him where the air conditioning condenser was but he wasn’t interested. Then the kicker. He literally runs up the stairs claiming he was looking for the furnace without my permission. I told him to come back which he did after looking around what I had upstairs. He then goes on to state there is poor cell service in my area and needs to connect to WiFi to notify Amazon he’s completed the job. I took his phone and put in the password and when he left changed the SSID and password. Then had the update all devices on my network.  A real pain in the ... So if these stranger come to your house be aware beforehand of exactly what they need access to. That said I know where to go if some untoward should happen in the near future. He thought he was slick but I read him right out the gate. Casing your home is a preview of what they might get if they break in. He was not aware of my wife and child or of my Rottweiler dog who’d be happy to chew him and his cohorts butts off. Beware of these idiots. Don’t even think to try it.
title: Product Good Installer Casing my home

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Michael M
content: I bought two of these and both are having issues in under one year. One of them came DOA so I had to get a replacement sent. They are frequently reporting they have lost connection, but as soon as I touch the panel it pops back up on my phone as connected (as well as the Nest site). The signal strength always looks good, ping levels are normal, it says it is communicating with the cloud services still, battery levels are good, etc. In the forums this seems like a more and more frequent problem. They both have line of sight to my business grade WiFi router and are no more than 30 feet away from it. I have wireless devices further away that have no problems or intermittent drops. The Nests will say they've lost connection and they will stay that way, but as soon as I touch the dial, they come right back up. It can be down for a few minutes and I touch it, or it can be two days. But as soon as I touch it, it's working again. Google announced they are dropping IFTTT support. So now I have two thermostats that can no longer respond to price spikes per kWh (I'm a wholesale energy user). EcoBee has support for IFTTT and many others. $450 or so spent on garbage thermostats by buying into the Nest propaganda. There really is nothing special about these.
title: Get an EcoBee instead

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: kim ross
content: I purchased this thermostat and installed it in the summer of 2018. Reason for the purchase was my mom, who was turning 88, and needed something easy to read and understand (she does not understand technology and had trouble seeing the old mercury thermostat we had since the 70s that worked perfectly all those decades). This thing was great!  She could turn it with the dial like she was used to. It was easy to read. It had color so she knew what system was on. And best of all,  she could tell Alexa to turn it up or down from her chair. Only thing I noticed was it kept kicking the AC unit on and off in shorter cycles,  which I didn't like. Then winter came. I live with her and work days. She would start noticing the thermostat would adjust itself to 60, without touching it,  at least twice a day. She would get cold and realize it's on 60 and turn it up. The other thing I noticed was it would adjust itself to 70 at around 4 AM when I didn't want that, wasting heat and money. I tried adjusting the schedule so it wouldn't do that and had the away feature off since she's home. That didn't work. Turned the schedule feature off and figured that was that. Seemed to work. Then we started getting the infamous "2+ hours" message people are reporting when you turn the heat up. Thermostat is still lit orange, which means boiler is still sending heat ... and registers are warm, but the temperature in the room wasn't going up. In fact sometimes it was falling. Thought maybe internal battery was getting low (I don't have a C wire,  but support says it's not necessary). Battery was reading about 3.8. Charging it via USB didn't make a difference. Adjusted display brightness and farsight to "on when pressed." Didn't help. It would take hours to go from 67 to 70. So by the time I get home,  my mom's finally comfortable in the room. Thankfully we have a big house,  so during the day she's in the back bedrooms, which is controlled by a regular manual thermostat,  to stay warmer. So in the last few days I've had to use a space heater in the room with the Nest to warm it up before I leave for work. It seemed to to maintain the warmer temp (70) for the first two days. Over the last two days, however,  after heating the room to 70 it gradually fell (usually not below 67, however this morning I woke up to 64 degrees in the room. I went into settings and updated software .. which said was up to date. I decided it worked better when auto schedule was on so I turned it back on,  and instead of saying "2+hours," (which is the thermostat saying to you it doesn't care if you turned it 70 it's refusing to heat the room to that temp for over 2 hours, even though I'm cold), it said "heating." I thought yessss, heat! That's what a thermostat should do, give you heat when you're cold. So since it's my day off, I have to get my car worked on and do shopping. Checked the thermostat before I left. And you guessed it .. it won't seemingly heat past 68 (giving me that 2+hours crap message again). Checked the app while I'm sitting at the car mechanic waiting ... sure enough it's reading 67 in the room, even though the color is orange and set to 70. So temp is falling again. So far I've used support online ... not chat yet ... and YouTube videos to try to solve this. My life is too busy at the moment to deal with nightmare stories I read online about being on hold over an hour and how bad Nest customer service is.  Guess I have 2 options at this point. Suck it up and waste probably hours with customer service when I get home. Or simply trash it and put back the old reliable thermostat my mom has trouble seeing. Soooooo, my conclusions.  I thought this thing was literally the greatest thing since cheesecake (much better than sliced bread). It worked great for one summer, fall, and much of one winter. I've had it installed for nine months to date (it's currently early March 2018). I live in NYS, so no major temp swings during the year. I'm technologically savvy with just about everything.  But have no idea what's going on with this thing. I'm a technology junkie of sorts. I wanted to love the Nest, but decided never to buy a Nest product again. I'm starting to hear a lot of bad things about them (my mechanic had trouble with one too he just told me). I can't afford it failing with my elderly mother at home and I can't even get the heat to go up. BTW the app worked perfectly for me ... really loved the easy interface and that I can control it remotely.  Installation and setup was super easy too. It's all such a shame. The design is beautiful.  They would have to lower the price and have maybe a 10th generation before I may consider one again. They have to fix a lot of issues. By then, however, there will be many smart thermostat options, so doubt I'll give Nest any more of my money. If it wasn't for my mom's vision problems I would probably still have that old reliable thermostat on the wall that worked perfectly.  It "listened" to me when I was cold. Turn it up and presto ... heat came up almost on cue. A thermostat is supposed to keep you comfortable and obey your wishes. I think this one actually wasted money by blasting heat early in the morning when I didn't need it. Although now it's not giving me enough heat. If customer service miraculously solves this I will update this review. I'm not holding my breath though. To safeguard my mother I'm going to put the old thermostat back. We still have cold days ahead. Guess I'll use my $200 Nest as a hockey puck for the kids.
title: Don't know what's going on with this thing ..

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: JoyceM
content: Our Nest learned every time we turned the heat up or down.  The following weekend, it went up & down like the previous weekend.  I had to go to the schedule and remove most of the settings.  Sometimes. we're in all day, sometimes not.  The Nest couldn't handle that. The bigger problem was, every time we walked by it, it would display the temperature (nice and big, which was nice) but it also turned on the air handler!  I don't think we had it connected a month before we woke up to a very cold house - no heat!  It burned out our air handler motor. We had to have a heating & cooling repair man come and replace the motor.  We put our old Honeywell thermostat back on and we have heat. I do miss the display and the ability to turn the heat up or down by phone.  It was handy if you forgot to turn the heat down before you left the house and you could turn it back up on your way home so the house would be nice & warm. I was really excited about trying it!  It was an expensive experiment.
title: You have to be a really good 'teacher'.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Shane Higginbotham
content: Have a Nest for the first floor, and decided to get one for the second floor. This is only half the story though. The rest is to be told in the future. Trying to get a smart vent solution to pair with the Nest, but the company I had in mind is sold out. Will update in future. Till now, it is doing an okay job by itself. EDIT: Well, lots of disappointment now. Our new Nest began to stop working every night. Restarting the furnace would get it to kick on a for a little, but then it would stop. Our temps would fall down to below 60 degrees F. Then the Nest began to get... weirder... Instead of the correct temperature, it decided to gain 10 to 20 degrees. It's59 degrees inside? Well, Nest now think's it is 78 degrees. Restarting or resetting the Nest had no effect. In the end, we had to put our old thermostat back on, and everything went back to normal, if not a little toasty. The question is if I should give the Nest another chance, or to just go for an Ecobee.
title: So far so good - Edit: Or not...

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Ralph Sherrin
content: Continued issues when weather got cold.  Now power problem.  Research online all the issues when cold weather before buying this product.  The thermostat says says no power to red wire when checking the red wire with the yellow and white wire the voltage is 26v more than the required 24V (range should be 24 to 30V).  Nest tells me it is a faulty base to the thermostat.  The $60 dollar trane thermostat is actually cooling the house while waiting for a replacement.  I almost bought an ecobee after reading reviews but bought the nest because of Google.  Wish I hadn't bought the nest with all the troubles and days without a functioning system.
title: Continued issues when weather got cold. Now power problem ...

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Mr. Deal
content: I was excited to get a Nest, but that excitement was short lived. Sure, it looks cool! But... does it function as well as my previous thermostat? No, unfortunately, it does not. In fact, it's has cost me a lot more to operate the Nest, because it does not understand Dual Fuel systems properly! You can not choose which fuel source to use, you can only either have them both on, or both off. In the winter it's a lot more affordable around here to use natural gas, however, it's impossible without rewriting every time you want to change the fuel source to turn off the Hot Air Pump. So, my heating bill has been $200-300 per month during the Winter months. On top of all that, there's more! First off, the original device sent my way was defective. I paid 2-pros to take a look, the first one charged me $200 and we got no where. The second one was a Nest certified pro, unfortunately, Nest does not actual train their "Pro's"... From the Pro's mouth, they give you them a multiple choice test, and a video interview (in which my Nest pro just looked up the answers on the web... thanks for the honesty! I don't blame the person, he was a nice guy, but Nest should know better!). So, I paid $120 for a "Nest Pro" to come out, we ended up having to send for a replacement for the Nest... And the saga continues! The replacement was the wrong color... at this point, I'm probably giving up... I have spent hours with customer service, running in circles. Honestly, out of the 10's of thousands of dollars of equipment I've bought on Amazon in the past couple years, Nest has been the most difficult to deal with. Wish this would of worked out! At this point, I've lost hundreds of dollars using the Nest, and everyday it continues to run during the Winter, I lose more money.  Perhaps this is a great product for a Single Fuel home, I'll never know!
title: Have a dual fuel system? Look elsewhere.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: rgprints
content: From my experience with the product, I can see why some might rate it 5 star, but my experience was not good and cost me a lot of time and frustration after purchasing and subsequently returning (one after another) three Nest Thermostats. It's a long story... My heating-A/C system is three zone with a Honeywell HZ311 controller and an Amana ASXC16 air conditioner. The saga begins in early January when I purchased and installed the first Nest Learning Thermostat after checking for compatibility online. Installation was a bit of a hassle because Nest thermostats won't work with the Honeywell controller unless there is a common wire. I had to overcome two problems - (1) the Honeywell thermostat that I was replacing had been incorrectly wired with respect to the common wire and Nest's instructions are based on existing wiring, and (2) the Nest tech support person that was helping me did not understand the common wire requirements as related to my controller. It took me a day or two of further detective work, greatly aided by inspecting the wiring on a second thermostat, to figure out how to properly wire the Nest. After several weeks of using the Nest with my heating system we ran into significant conflicts with the so-called "learning" aspects of the thermostat. I would set a schedule only to notice a few days later that my heating schedule had been inexplicably altered in ways that I could not understand. (A personal note. I have decades of experience in AI, starting in the early '70s as a graduate student, so I was also very interested in seeing how the learning function would work.) Well, the learning function of the Nest, IMHO, is beyond comprehension as it seems to completely ignore any explicit instructions it receives from the human operator, so I think Nest techies have a lot of work to do there. As a practical matter, we could not live with the thermostat as a learner. In a conversation (or chat) with tech support, the Nest representative suggested we replace the Learning model with the "E" model, which I then did. Now we were very happy with the Nest (the "E" model) for several months. We really liked the scheduling functions and the Eco "away" functionality, and what was particularly useful was the ability to remotely set the temperature prior to our return after a week-long absence. However, that happiness evaporated when we had a heat wave in early April with temperatures hitting 80 degrees and we found that the "E" was causing our air conditioner to rapidly cycle on and off with a significant loss in efficiency. What I had failed to notice and what the Nest rep had failed to point out is that the "E" and the "Learning" thermostats have differences wrto A/C compatibility. In particular, whereas the "Learning" works with two-stage air conditioners, the "E" does not. Our Amana is two-stage. All of this involved another long session with a Nest tech rep, and after going through our whole saga, the rep suggested we go back to the "Learning" model and also that it was easy then to turn off the learning feature which we strongly disliked. (I wish that the earlier rep had made that recommendation rather than the suggestion to replace with an "E"!) So the "E" was returned and another "Learning" model obtained and installed. A few weeks went by and with the learning mode disabled we were now pleased with the the "Learning" model, until the weather got warm again. Then we saw that the "Learning" model induced exactly the same rapid cycling in the A/C as had been the problem with the "E". Again a conversation with tech support and this time the rep told me that my specific model of Amana was not compatible with any Nest thermostat. So now our third Nest has been returned, and we are getting a "smart" Honeywell thermostat instead. After all this I began to wonder if I had not been diligent enough in my initial compatibility checking, so I did a Google query combining "nest" with my Amana A/C model number, but got no hits. From that I conclude that the fact that my Amana is not compatible with Nest is knowledge available to Nest reps, but not the public. Some final comments on Nest tech support. If you've read this far, you are aware of several problems arising from tech support. Overall, support personnel were easy to work with and seemed very knowledgeable, even though in some cases it turns out that they should have been more knowledgeable. The biggest problem is that waits are extremely long, both for chat and for telephone support. On top of that, their chat and telephone technology is not reliable. I had at least two chat sessions that terminated unexpectedly, and one extremely frustrating phone call where I was finally connected to a tech after a 40 minute wait, only to immediately get disconnected. The phone wait is also extremely frustrating in that a voice occasionally comes on to inform you that wait times are extremely long and to suggest that it might be better to try at a different time, without suggesting a time range that might have shorter waits.
title: Compatibility issues are paramount. Tech support has some problems. Be aware before you buy!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Live to Ride
content: Initially loved this thing until, well, it didn't work as we wanted.  Wanted to run thermostat off our phones (new iphone and samsung s9.)  Easy setup in app, but very unreliable (leave and it would sometimes recognize that you left, same when returning - if didn't check app, AC would run most the day.)  We both spent 2 hours on Nest support with senior tech rep (painful to get to that level) and seemed to be working.  Over the next couple of days it was unreliable as before.  Would not work with one phone or two.  Another 1.5 hrs on the phone with tech support.  Rep went over all settings (same as before, no change), but then told us to add actual street address instead of just the flag on the map.  Tried that over next couple of days, no help.  Tried calling support again, but got stuck on hold for almost 40 minutes so decided to punt.  Unit worked with schedule only, but why pay $250 for a programmable thermostat I can get for $29?  T Stat will be going back. Hopefully, they will fix issues one day.
title: 15+ hours of my life I won't get back......

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Donald W.
content: I have lived with the Nest thermostat for three years now. It has done nothing much to improve the heating/cooling experience in my home (as compared to a regular mechanical thermostat). As others have commented, they market this product as a "learning" device that will save you money in the longterm by automatically setting optimal temperatures. It absolutely fails in this regard. You might as well stick with your old thermostat if that is what you are looking for. In fact, my Nest actually wound up costing me extra money on heating/cooling during the first year because I naively believed the hype and didn't do a good job of checking on it. When I did start checking, I found it pretty much was just keeping the temperature at constant settings with no good adjustments for time-of-day or outside temperature BUT, you can easily program a schedule of temps and times. That's not "automatic" and other cheaper thermostats can do that, too. It does look modern and cool but if your thermostat is down an out-of-sight hallway like mine, who cares? The best thing about the Nest thermostat is you can adjust your settings in your house from anywhere in the world using the app on your phone or computer. That's great if you do a lot of traveling. But, if you're mostly always at home and only take a few days away here and there, it's not that big of deal.
title: Overhyped gadget

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: David J West
content: With our below zero temperatures outside, my newly installed Nest just quit working this morning.  As the house temp was down in the 50's, I was on hold for Nest support for 2 hours and 15 minutes (Happy New Year).  This a big issue and we are starting to see the reviews stating the serious problem.  If you do not have a functioning control wire (usually the blue wire) and the temps get below zero outside, some HVAC systems quit powering the Nest thermostat and it just turns off because the battery drains out.  The temp solution is to disconnect the yellow wire which controls the air conditioning.  That will get the furnace working again.  It also means you need to remember in the spring to hook up the yellow wire again or you will have no AC.  The long term solution is to get an HVAC repairman to hook up a common wire to the Control port of the Nest so the battery will always receive power.  The only redeeming part of this review was the Nest support person I dealt with (Alexis) was very helpful and spent the time to answer all of my questions and wait patiently for about an hour as we fixed the problem.  That good support person got it up to a 2 star review.
title: Furnace quits running in frigid temps due to Nest battery draining

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: S. Heath
content: Just installed yesterday, but so far, I love it.  Very stylish.  Ease of install could not have been better.  They even provide an optional mounting plate and screwdriver for the install.  Turn off breaker, record which wire went where on the old thermostat, then reconnect to the same terminals on the Nest.  Breaker back on and it boots up in a few seconds.  Connect to Wifi, then it walks you through the rest of the install asking a few questions, then even lets you run through test cycles to make sure it is working well.  You have to download the app, then input a code the unit displays to activate fully.  Then, in my case, I linked my Nest account to my Alexa account (in the Alexa app) and I have voice control.  Worked like a charm, both in setup and voice control, so far. My son had a Gen1 Nest and he complained all the time that it would not 'see' them in the house (since they were on the other side of the house) and assume they were away.  Not a concern any more.  Now you get Geofencing as an option.  You can tell it to use the GPS in your phone or tablet to 'know' when you are home and when you leave and adjust accordingly (per your guidelines).  It even will let you share the app features with others in the house, so it knows if one phone left, but the other is here, to assume you are home (unless one of you forgot your phone, of course). Make sure to go back to the settings menu and scroll through each.  You can set up the display to show the current temp, current setting (including high/low range if set for auto-changeover from heat to cool), or even the current outdoor temp and expected temps for the next 4/8/12 hours (which it gets from the Weather channel, when you set it up and tell it your zip code). I'll update again if I end up with any negatives, but have to give it time to learn our habits to see if it will save us anything in the long run.  If not, still happy just getting the automation with app and voice control.
title: So far so good - I think I'm going to love it.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Marilyn s.
content: Don’t buy; if you encounter a power surge you just toss your money way. I bought one two months ago and there is no way too reset back to factory mode no matter how many suggestions you get for techs. Still not wanting to throw my money away I call two of my friends that I knew had purchased them and ask for help just to find out that they also encounter the same problem and decided to replace with an other brand. Ouch I just lost $300.00 of my hard earned money.😔
title: Nest thermostat

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Chris
content: I've been slowly upgrading my home to a "smart home" since the end of 2016. This white Nest learning thermostat is the 1st of 3 thermostats I'm upgrading and I'm very happy with it so far, but there are specifics that need to be mentioned. The 1st Nest thermostat I received from Amazon was defective. During installation and near the end of setup the thermostat detected a wire connected to the Y2 terminal (which there was not one). After looking high and low on the internet for any similar issues and finding non at all (I can only assume this means it's a rare issue), I called Nest tech support. They concluded the device was defective and gave me the option of using up the warranty or returning it for a replacement through Amazon. Obviously it was best (and faster) to replace through Amazon. One thing that really bothered me---since the device thought there was a wiring issue, I could not finish setup. But, you must finish setup to remove your personal information that was entered at the beginning of the setup process (wi-fi password and SSID for example) and reset the device. There is absolutely no way to remove your info in the event of a setup error such as mine. The replacement device works great and I really like the white version. I've heard the stainless steel version gets finger prints and smudges very easily. The white matches all of the trim in my home and it looks fantastic. I did use the wall plate to cover a hole that was previously hidden by my old thermostat. The wall plate looks great though and with the inclusion of a built in level, a metal back plate (if needed), wire labels, and magnetic screwdriver, it shows all the thought Nest has put into making installation easy for anyone. It works seemlessly with Alexa and the devices display is customizable and gorgeous.
title: An excellent smart home addition!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Neil Jansen
content: Today, Google (Nest's parent company) decided to deprecate their 'Works with Nest' API.  It will be completely phased out in 116 days (16 weeks from now).  They've rolled out an intrusive replacement that requires a Google account. This will be my last Nest product that I buy.  To be clear: I love Nest, I love their products.  I hate their parent company and their knee-jerk management style.
title: Was great until they dumped their 'Works with Nest' API.  It longer works with my smarthome hub.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Andrew L
content: I have had 2 Nest Thermostat replacements at this point and contacting them is never a pleasant experience. Since my first replacement they have outsourced their customer service offshore and the agents are very difficult to work with. I'm on the phone with customer service now again. Here was the worst experience I had with them: My Nest Learning Thermostat failed inexplicably today 11/16/2018, with family en route for the holidays, and a 5 day old in my home. We are expecting 20 degree lows overnight and up to 1" of snow here in Iowa. I performed a lite reset and factory reset the thermostat to see if that would resolve the issue. It looked like it was functioning but the furnace wasn't responding so I initially ruled that out. I mean, the thermostat was only about a month old! I paid an HVAC professional $125 for an emergency service to diagnose the problem, suspecting it was something wrong with the furnace. He diagnosed the thermostat as the culprit and even plugged in a new Nest unit to verify a new unit would work. Before things went downhill from there I must say, I have been extremely pleased with Nest products up until this point. I have them throughout my home and they have been a major convenience and peace of mind. I am furious however that your customer service is so limited in authority and arduous to navigate. I spent 3 hours on the phone with your support team, at least 1 hour on hold. My call dropped and I lost my place in queue. I was referred to the chat support for senior level support. Chat access was quite a bit faster actually, so that was good, but my optimism was quickly stymied by support agents that were stuck in old modalities of thinking. Instead of "the customer is always right", I got, "here are the options, they both suck and require our customers to be punished and suffer." My solution was, I went to Walmart, got a new unit and sought approval to refund my original purchase upon receipt of the defective item (the lesser of what I paid for the two Nest thermostats I have bought now). I had the new thermostat at the ready for the approval from Nest support. They could solve my problem in just minutes if they only agreed to the resolution I had at the ready, but they wanted to make it harder than that. They want me to wait 1-2 days for a replacement to arrive from the factory. This inconvenience with everything else I have on my plate at this time. I don't have time to write this comment, let alone spend the 12 hours I did today dealing with this in-toto. After all I had been through today, I was not wiling to accept their solution when mine was clearly better for them, and better for me. I'm not trying to screw anybody here, I just want to get back to my newborn and preparing for the holiday! I drove a hard bargain and still customer support did not arrive at the solution I had at the ready. The correct solution. How infuriating! I'll be selling the replacement unit on Craigslist, buying a competitors product, and advising to everyone I know never to buy Nest products again because of this experience. Mega-huge companies like Walmart, Amazon and Nest have to be built to eat some expenses when their products fail. Even if only within a certain statute of limitations. It provides an incentive for the development and perfection of your technology that your already making money hand-over-fist upon. The expense you would have incurred making me happy if peanuts compared to the money it WILL cost your company in the long term. Tech fans like me practically sell your products for you and instead you cause insult to injury. Angry in Iowa
title: Garbage product, awful customer support, censor bad reviews, fails when you need it most

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Steve
content: I bought the Nest thermostat with high hopes about a year ago.  It has, so far, not been quite the life-changing element that the sales material suggests, but I have been completely happy with it (who needs their lives changed by a thermostat anyway?). I think my favorite functions of the Nest are these: 1) Really easy installation.  Nest has been really good at providing instructions that think of everything (they included the screwdriver to install the unit).  I came away impressed because many companies provide instructions that leave a lot to interpretation. 2) The Eco function.  The Eco function allows you to set minimum and maximum temperatures (I set my minimum to 60 degrees F and my maximum to 80 degrees F) that dictate whether or not to run the appropriate unit (heating or cooling).  While we're away, I know that I'm not running my AC or heater unnecessarily, but I also know that I won't come back to a 90 degree home.  I live in a relatively temperate climate (Colorado) and so I use this setting most of the time. 3) The Airflow function for AC.  I just learned about this - but the Nest is smart enough to turn off the AC condenser a little bit early and still run the fan over the chilled coils in order to extract the last bit of cold air in order to get your temperature down to the desired level.  They correctly know that running the condenser is the big energy draw, so by limiting that, you get more bang for your energy dollar. 4) The integration with Amazon Echo has been seamless, and while I don't use the voice function a lot, I have integrated the lighting through the Nest occupancy sensor (it knows when you move past it) to automatically turn on my lights as I come home after sunset - which is a cool integration, I think. I will say that I haven't really noticed a lot from the learning function.  It has done a pretty good job of noticing when I routinely will change the temp (we'll turn down the heat when we go to bed, for instance) and it will automatically do that - but for the most part I still find myself fine tuning the temperature more than I thought I would.  That said, the dial is really tactile and intuitive and easy to use. I've liked the Nest and would recommend it.  It is pricey, and I'm sure other thermostats would work just fine for the way I use it, but I'm happy I bought this.
title: Good Thermostat with lots of neat features

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: cian c debaldo
content: We had two different AC Technicians come out to our house to inspect why our ac unit kept tripping.  Both told me it was the Nest system causing this.  It makes sense because we did not have the problem before we installed it.  Now that we switched out for another system, we are having no problems.  Amazon is not making it easy for me to return this product.  I am having issues dealing with Nest as well.  I feel since it was purchased through amazon, they should allow me to return it at least for credit!
title: TOO SMART FOR MY AC UNIT

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Daniel
content: After 15 months I got the low battery warning. After 30 minutes of net research this is my conclusion. The nest requires a C (common) wire to PROPERLY recharge the internal battery. However, in an effort to broaden compatibility to (older) HVAC’s without a C wire, they essentially hacked or hot wired the thermostat to recharge the battery while the HVAC is running. This will get you by until the rechargeable battery degrades enough to not hold a charge (in my case, 15 months.) It seems Nest has deemed this not covered under warranty and basically tell you, “yeah, you gotta install that C wire.” That being said, these are your options. Install the C wire. $200 for the HVAC guy to run one skinny wire 30+ feet. Keep buying a new Nest thermostat until the battery degrades. The battery appears to be replaceable. Available for $10 but you have to open the thermostat and fiddle with the delicate internals. Take the unit off the wall and manually charge via USB port on the thermostat, daily. Run the HVAC (no matter what the weather is like) to keep the thermostat charged, daily. Scrap Nest and put up a classic thermostat that costs $20+ and will last for 40 years. It’s these kind of corner cutting scam job companies that make me lose faith in anything modern. Fix it anyway you want, but it makes you think, what other nightmares are in store for me down the road with products from this company?
title: DO. NOT. BUY. Factory implemented hack job.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Jason
content: I have had 2 fail. Thank god my pipes didn't freeze. They should have a recall on every one of these. The wifi chip fails, then the battery dies from the nest constantly trying to connect to wifi. When the nest is off the heat does not come on. I am very disapointed and now constantly worried about these failing. The two that broke were sent back under warranty. Nest sent me a replacement that failed within a week. The same issue where the wifi chip fails and then the device stops working.  This was not caused by lack of power. They stay charged just fine. There is no quality control. Stay away from these. These are very dangerous to rely on from my experience.  It may be safer to just keep your old mechanical thermostat. If you live where it gets freezing cold like new england try something else. When i called the nest support they told me that they received many calls that day with the same issue, the wifi chip failed. Nest knows about it and they sent me another one with the same issue. They told me they run a 100 point inspection on it before they send it back out. That inspection failed to detect the issue on the replacement they sent me.
title: Wifi chip and nest failed in freezing cold weather twice so far!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Starman
content: I believe Nest is not honest in their products. This product is being sold without further testing and troubleshooting. It foes not work correctly. Very buggy. And alot of research I did in this product after install. Discover that alot, if not most consumers who purchased it have problems and issues and it does not save energy. Why they continue to say this is b.s.  The main issue is the built in temp sensors. Very buggy , and are suspect to get wrong readings, thus causing the "smart" thermostat to not operate correctly. It is always reads wrong actual temperature in room. And it constantly running, because the sensor is faulty. I'm use for cooling only,and it will not work correctly. This after several phone chats with Nest "experts", by way,are not ,they just read from a book. This is the biggest rip off going on now in "smart " thermostat world. Do not buy. I'm sending back,and going back to reg thermostat.
title: Faulty product, not enough testing done,don't buy

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Ziv Family
content: I'm an electrical engineer and a very big fan of smart home gadgets and early adopter of Amazon echo, smart lights, doors, blinds and unfortunately the Nest... This product is faulty by design and surprisingly their service is useless if you realize their product is faulty after 30 days... When we first installed it I thought it was just trying to be smart and learning the environment but it seemed to have a mind of its own not always heating when we wanted to.  The Nest never provided any error messages, or warning of any kind. It took us quite a bit of time to realize there was something wrong. But recently we kept losing heat, the furnace would shut down during very cold days and it was clear something was wrong. We thought the problem was with the furnace. We call a heating technician who didn't find a problem with the furnace and left. But the furnace continued to shut down randomly. We had to call the technician back and in total he spent over 4 hours costing us over $600 to finally realize that the Nest was faulty or not compatible with our heating system.  The technician replaced the Nest with a simple thermostat and solved the problem and our heat is back!!! I then called Nest and spoke to 2 different agents including an executive called Alex. There answer really surprised me "they do not accept returns after 30 days", even if the product is faulty. Very disappointing. I will never buy another Nest product again - and if you value your heat and want to avoid over $800 in expenses especially in the middle of winter, I suggest you look for something different or stay with what you have. DZ
title: Shut down our heat for several days in the middle of winter!!!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Robert R. Depew
content: Setting up the nest was quick and easy. The instructions were simple, clear and easy to follow. Nest's goal is for customers to have the thing up and running in less than 30 minutes. I ran into two tiny problems, neither of which should discourage you from buying and installing one. 1. I had some trouble mounting the Nest to the backing plate the first time. To control the nest, you turn the metal ring on the outside and then push the Nest to click it, like a mouse. If it's not mounted correctly, the click-like-a-mouse doesn't work. It took me a few tries. Maybe I'm just clumsy. Once the locking tabs were engaged, it worked fine. 2. Don't expect it to light up right away once it's installed. The display remains dark for a couple of minutes while it wakes up, brushes its teeth, checks its circuits and so on. Be patient. Installing the smartphone app, and controlling the Nest from the app or the webpage, is painless. I object to the huge stack of permissions the app requires (why does it need access to my Contacts?) but that doesn't really apply here. I'll take that up on the Google App Store. ONE FINAL NOTE: We've only had the Nest for two days. Always be wary of reviews posted within a day or two of receipt of something. Check back in a few months to see if this review has changed.
title: Quick and easy to set up.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Jer
content: Everything I needed was included in the box.  I have a 14 year old heat pump system that had a programmable thermostat already so I knew it would work, I just didn't know how easy it would be to install and cover up the area where the larger thermostat had been.  The included trim plate was the perfect size and looks great.  I did not have to drill any holes as the included wall screws were perfect for the drywall and specially made to hold it securely.  I would definitely recommend using a HAND SCREWDRIVER to install them as an impact or electric screwdriver or drill would almost certainly turn them too tightly and strip out the drywall. I had a slight hiccup on the install.  I put all the wires in according to how they were supposed to be placed, but when I tested the system, the heat pump would heat when it was supposed to cool, and cool when it was supposed to heat.  I used the built-in troubleshooter app on the thermostat itself and discovered that the O/B wire (which tells the heat pump which direction to run) was set as an "O" wire which is normal, but was actually supposed to be a "B" wire setting.  I simply selected "B" wire on the screen and the thermostat automatically reversed it and now everything runs perfectly.  I also set it up to work with my SimpliSafe security system and now it automatically changes to the Eco setting (my Eco setting is 86 degrees) when my alarm is set to "away" (as it knows no one is home), and changes back to normal operation when the alarm is off or in "home" mode.  I can also set it to start cooling at a designated time before I get home. Another cool thing is that if I set the temperature lower (or higher if heating) it actually tells me how long it will take to get to the desired temperature.  A function that I'm sure it calculates after it has been in operation for a day or two and senses how long it takes to cool the house.  A very innovative and smart upgrade to my home.  I also like that it senses when someone is approaching and displays the current temperature (or outside air temp, or current set temp, whichever you choose to display), then when I get closer it changes to the temperature setting.  Pretty smart device.
title: Smart and Innovative upgrade to my home

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: William
content: I got this Nest thermostat because they offered a NestPro installer to install it for me and get it working for $99 plus tax and I think in total it was just a little more than that. It was supposed to include a year of support and service with the Nest Pro installation. The installer had some difficulty and said that our wires to our AC were not right so some adjustments had to be made but it appeared to work for almost 2 months. Then it suddenly began turning on the heat at random times. We live in Florida so if the heater kicks on in the middle of August you feel it immediately. You can even smell the difference between the AC and the heater so it was obvious when the heater was switched on. Going to the thermostat and manually turning the temp way down seemed to correct the problem but I have a small dog that is not suited to high temperatures and I don't want her dying because the temperature in the house got too hot while I am away from the house so this is not acceptable. I had to call for support. Instead of sending another professional to diagnose the problem they tried to walk me through troubleshooting on the phone. They had me remove a wire and check the voltages and said that seemed to fix it but two hours later the heater just kicked in on it's own again. This was after some automatic firmware update that went in at midnight. So in the morning I switched the wires back to the way they were initially since it did not solve the problem. I then went into the settings and turned off all the eco settings for power saving. I basically asked the brains of the "smart" thermostat to stop thinking and just cool my house on a schedule. This seemed to solve the problem for about 2-3 weeks. Now it is back to randomly just turning the heater on again. It does this while it says that it should be cooling the house. I am done trying to make this work. I paid WAY more for a "smart" thermostat to monitor my house temperature very closely and hopefully be more efficient but this thermostat can't be trusted. I am removing this piece of crap and putting the old "dumb" honeywell that works back where it belongs. I will just buy a smart thermometer to keep me apprised of the temperature and warn me if things go wrong. That was a $350+ lesson. If you pay for a "Pro installer" don't expect to get a "Pro troubleshooter" when it's not working.
title: Can't be trusted to cool your home

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: John S
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. Have had 6 of these nest thermometers starting about 3.5 years ago.  Unfortunately, they are not built to last.  They look great, and work great too...  Until they do not.  Check out the video.  At about 3 years of age they start to fail.  Others have mentioned similar experiences here. Here is my thought.  A simple sensor failed on this thermostat.  Probably a 25 cent part.  Why not offer parts kits on a $250 computer that acts as a thermostat.  If it was a $50 thermostat, I get the "throw away" and consumable mentality.  But once you go over 200 bucks for something that used to cost $10 and last for 50 years (mercury switch thermostat), it is a durable good. I am not a lawyer, but I do sense a class action on this one.  Nest should be forced to sell, or allow others to sell, aftermarket parts kits. Is there a wonder that their warranty is only 2 years.  I am really torn if I tear down my nest of Nests, or risk throwing good money after bad. I do have to say that Nest support was  "so generous" with at 20% off coupon from the Nest store (list price).  Amazon sells the thermostat at about a 20% discount.  Nest should know that we can do math.  That is not a savings to keep customers happy. I am really torn.  I like the thermostats, but there is no way that each of them save $200 in their lifetime.  No way. The video below shows the failed nest (outer ring sensor failed).  And worse than that, it randomly started setting the heat very high and the AC very low.  Good thing we took it out of service while we were home.  If we were away, we would have come home to crazy utility bills!!! I do not know what I will do going forward.  But I can say I wish I never started with the first Nest. OLD REVIEW BELOW - I already had two Nest 2 thermostats, and to continue down our path to the internet of everything, we replaced our master bedroom heat with this thermostat.  We had previously run into the issue in the family room (with the nest 2 - but believe this is similar) where our setup (heat and cool) needed a common C wire for 24V power.  Nest went above and beyond for that and paid for an HVAC tech to come out and complete the wiring for us to the AC unit. We had already replaced another one of our heat zones (Red and White wires only) to a forced hot water oil furnace, with a nest 2 that was working perfectly.  So when we installed this one with identical wiring, we expected identical results. The form and function are nearly identical to the Nest 2.  I dont think it is worth the extra money if you can get a nest 2 now for 100 dollars less at times, but we got a cyber monday deal... What did surprise us is an very audible buzz when the screen comes on and when the heat is on.  You can google it - others hear the same thing.  But it appears to be a function of the power stealing technique when not using a C wire. We had the extra wire, and it was not hard to hook up to the 24V transformer in our case, I just had to do a bunch of research to make sure I was doing it right.  I didnt want to fry my whole system going into winter. With the C wire hooked up, the audible buzz no longer happened, and it is on par with the Nest 2.  (Added the C wire to that as well.) C wires aside, I do like the wifi app and the ability to have as many schedules as you want on a 7 day cycle.  It seems that you have to get into this price range for that functionality.  We have a Sensi as well, and for 100 bucks you get the wifi, but are stuck with those four schedules.  A real legacy hassle if you ask me.
title: Started out as a 4-5 start product.  But they started failing after 3 years.  What a colossal mistake this has been!!!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: JKT
content: Had the nest for 3 months now.  Not much savings to speak of in our power bills.  Maybe a few bucks.  This is due to having it set to go down to 68 at night and warm back up in the day to 71 (but my spouse will often turn it up a few degrees over that if he's home)  I'd love to have it set lower but my family would revolt.  So if you are prepared to suffer with much less heat then this might give you more noticeable savings. The Good: Installation was not easy, but when we accidentally broke the nest they sent us a replacement no questions asked.  You can opt to hire some one to install this for you.  Our problem is our wiring didn't match exactly what any of the examples showed.  Maybe yours will be more straight forward. Cool looking interface You can control this when you are away with your cell phone, or even in the house with your cell phone or connect with your Echo and voice control it. The display remains off unless you walk by, and then it lights up to show you what temp it is set for. The Bad: Not a lot of cost savings unless you are willing to really cut your power use. I don't like that it won't automatically show you the current temp when the house is warming up after being away.  You have to manually set it to that.  Sometimes the controls/app is not that user friendly.. or it could be better anyway. Seems a bit big brother-ish. So, I advise if you don't have a lot of extra money for home improvements, this is one to skip.  If you have plenty of disposable income then what the heck, drop the 250 and get it because it's cool.  But if you are not willing to change the heat and cool levels in your home, this won't save you all that much money. UPDATE 2/7/17 - Our nest stopped heating and we were on tech support for an hour and they were helpful and we got it working again and they wanted to follow up with us too.  Although I'm a little concerned that we would have issues after installation, customer service was supurb.
title: The good and bad.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: sushicatlover
content: In the past, all electric homes with heat pumps were persnickedly about thermostats.  But our electric company had an unbelievable deal at 60% off.  It was a challenging install but nest tech people were there with chat and phone call.  We installed it after a return from vacation when the weather went from 85 to 32 and the heat was turned off because it wouldn't get "that cold".  It did, house was 52.  Once installed it was an easy set up in the app and Alexa.  We liked it so much that we bought one for our vacation home where we often based our plans on whether we could warm up this house.  I love being able to control it away from house.  And thermostat will work without internet, you just can't control it.  I searched for best price but was leery about buying outside of the Amazon umbrella or a traditional store.  So I paid $10 more, still getting 20% off from one of the Amazon sellers covered by the Amazon guarantee.  I am pleased.
title: I thought it wouldn't work

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Aerosparx
content: This is a NEST thermostat purchased for a second location based on the ease of use of the first thermostat. What I really like is the NEST app that allows remote control from anywhere for yourself and anyone you may choose to add to the app as a user. I have to edit the previous post since installing the thermostat it has been "offline" more than online.  The main reason for the purchase was the fact that I could monitor and control the heating remotely since this is a cottage in the middle of the woods and the power in the area tends to go out frequently.  Since installing the thermostat the power has gone off several times now and the NEST thermostat has not come back online in 2 out of 3 power loss/power restored occurrences. Thankfully, the NEST thermostat continues to function as a thermostat . . . it just can't be monitored or controlled remotely when it is offline.  I have no idea if it is in ECO mode or in regular schedule mode and heating the cottage while no one is there. As a result of the above issues I need to downgrade the NEST 3rd generation Thermostat to a 2.
title: Simple Install . . . easy to use . . . not so great when power goes out

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Eric B.
content: I purchased the 3rd Gen. Nest thermostat only to return it after learning Nest has recently been repurchased by Google’s parent company Alphabet. Google is an information and marketing company that gets it’s information by offering services, ie GoogleMaps, Gmail, Chrome and selling the user information for marketing purposes. Although I was interested in the features offered by a wifi thermostat, it is not worth the price of my personal information on an ongoing basis.
title: Warning! Nest is now owned by Alphabet and is being incorporated into Google’s Smart Home system.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Rsdeak
content: This is one of the few smart thermostats that does not require a “C” wire. It has an internal battery. If the power goes out for several hours though, the battery discharges and it takes several hours to recharge. During that time the unit shuts down its WiFi function and the screen stays dark. When it finally recharges you must reset the time. If you have a C wire, which I don’t, I believe the unit comes back on immediately when power is restored. I found the learning function and auto home/away function to simply be a nuisance since my schedule varies and it takes too long to recover the temp when I come home. I set a schedule manually. You can’t beat the convenience of being able to monitor and control your a/c from your phone though. The on-line support is excellent as is the ability to connect with a tech 24/7.
title: A godsend for your part time home.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: MimiKing
content: Wish I had known before we purchased, but the Nest thermostat is not exactly compatible unless you have a C-wire. True, it will technically work, but the Nest requires a power source to charge the battery, and our furnace was short cycle starting throughout the day to get that charge to the Nest. The Nest essentially pulses the furnace to charge itself and it was loud and annoying (woke us up at night) and we were worried it might damage our furnace to run constantly like that. Called Nest and spent hours on the phone with their help desk, who eventually told us that, yes, we needed a c-wire, which was going to cost over $200 to install. So the Nest is going back. Now that we understand more about how wi-fi thermostats work, we're very disappointed in Nest, because other companies are frank about the necessity of a c-wire upfront, while Nest customer service told me before we purchased that we most-likely wouldn't need to worry about it.
title: Not *exactly* compatible without C-wire

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: me
content: Last weekend, my Nest went offline. Turns out, the internal battery isn’t holding a charge. 8/29: chat with support since they don’t have a phone support. Everything seemed fine. They were going to send me a new for exchange before this weekend’s scorching heat.  Plus they send me a label to return the broke one. Everything seems fine. 9/2:  no email or tracking number. I chat again and they said I should receive it by Friday and tracking number should be sent shortly. 9/3: no email and I chat again. Assured I would be receiving it Friday. 9/4:  115 degrees and no ac. I began a chat a again and ended up with a supervisor.  She ends up calling me explain hi won’t have my replacement because they changed warehouse and how they do replacement support. She puts me on hold and talks to someone for replacement. Here’s the new procedure for replacement. They will send me a link via the google store to order a new one and place a hold on my credit card. Once they receive the replacement, they will release the hold. The email should be coming shortly. It’s 9/6 and I still haven’t received any support. The email she sent came from Support@nest.com with her name at the bottom. I can reply to this and I will be able to have direct contact with her. I emailed her twice and no response. When asked what the other chat reps were doing, she said they had the wrong information. Get you act together google! I do not recommend the Nest. They don’t stand behind their product and I don’t have 2 hours to spend on chat/phone for broken promises.
title: INTERNAL BATTERY DOES NOT LAST 2 YEAR AND TECH SUPPORT IS HORRIBLE! MUST READ

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: runnerjud
content: The installation instructions looked a bit complicated, so I had an electrician install it, but the tech support was great in helping me to figure out whether the Nest was compatible with my furnace - something everyone should do BEFORE they buy a Nest (which I did not do).  Fortunately it was compatible. I got a $100 rebate from my utility company.  The Nest can be monitored with my cell when I am away from home and temps changed.  It reminds me to change my filter and gives me information about how long the AC or furnace was on and at what temperature.  It undoubtedly saves money - it is a learning thermostat so it learns what temperatures you like and will automatically do it for you.  It has an eco moe to save money.  I recommend the Nest. It is a bit expensive, especially if an electrician installs it, but that is a one time expense and probably in the long run that expense is more than offset.  You do NOT need to buy a plate to cover up the hole where your old thermostat was - it comes with one.  I did not know that and bought one separately.  Even though I am Amazon Prime, I had to pay $5.95 to return the plate which I was not happy about.
title: I had an electrician install it

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Ben
content: I bought this for my vacation home.  I have one in my regular home and had no issues but had nothing but problems with this unit which really surprised me! The unit lost wifi constantly, had low battery power and since it’s my vacation home it was driving me nuts that I could not control my climate remotely! After doing some research, it turns out not having a common wire was my problem.  Since I rarely have the AC/heat on, the Nest wasn’t able to charge its battery and it draws power by having the heat pump or air conditioner running - so for me that was rare since I only go to the home on weekends. I got lucky in that I had a 5 wire setup with the blue wire being a spare.  When connected to Common, quickly found out from the nest that it was not connected so I had to climb in the attic and attach that wire to the C common terminal.  It wasn’t hard. Problem solved!  Lots of YouTube videos out there on how to do this.  Other options include using the fan wire if you only have 4 wires or adding a device which will give you a common wire
title: Vacation homes require a common wire!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: BERK
content: Product didn't last 6 months, tried to send in for a replacement and they said I need to hook it back up and troubleshoot it. It's the dead of summer and the the hvac guy already hooked up the original thermostat. Nest wanted me to unhook that one and hook the Nest back up. $235 down the drain. The hvac guy said these things are junk.
title: Poor customer experience, Nest is junk

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Emery G.
content: I love my Nest, I would recommend it to everyone that comes into my house. So great that you can control your temp from anywhere in the world. Also the home/away assist and other energy saving techniques really do save you money. Installing is also easy as long as you don't rush. I am moving in a few months and will be buying a new Nest for my next home.
title: I am going to buy again

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: JILO
content: Lesson 1 - DO NOT WAIT TO HOOK UP. Amazon has only a 30-day return policy for this unit. Lesson 2 - DO NOT TRUST IN WINTER - be careful of freezing pipes if you loose power. Lesson 3 - Three days after installation realized screen always black because battery is low. Tried calling Nest twice - Second time took over an hour for them to pick up.  Need to remove the Nest face to charge with our own charging wire daily. Keep in mind without the face attached the thermostat does not work (not good in winter). Found the issue is not only a needed common wire to be ran from handler to thermostat but all wires from handler to Nest thermostat need to have at least 24 volts when prior Honeywell thermostat was low voltage. Without the 24 volts (which can fluctuate as ours did - one moment showed 24 volts and next showed 14 volts).  For something so popular, I am really disappointed in customer service availability and quality of the product after only a few days after installation. Update: After working on the phone with the technician for two hours, they approved a $150 diagnosis fee and sent an approved Nest Technician to our house for diagnosis only.  The bill came to $185 with tax after learning the Nest is not compatible with our HVAC voltage.  Note if the common wire was needed it would have been another $200 plus tax.  The additional $200 (plus tax) for the common wire would need Nest approval and the technician said they many times are on hold a very long time also for that approval.  The approved Nest technician will only run the common wire if it is uncomplicated. Otherwise, they tell you to hire another electrician. Over Five hours down the drain and Hoping for the reimbursement for the technician who told us our system is not compatible and hoping Nest will provide a refund. Amazon customer service was called and they too are having difficulty contacting Nest about a refund for the Nest unit. Hoping to hear from Nest soon about the reimbursement and refund since we have invested approximately $400 into the Nest thermostat that does not work with our HVAC system.
title: Common wire issue - Voltage issue

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: GK
content: These are so easy to install and get setup, even for someone with very little tech skills. If you are able to pull off the old thermostat and take a picture of the wiring configuration there, turn a screwdriver to install the new base, and match those wires from the picture right back into their proper label - then installing this should be a breeze! Every little bit you can save on heating these days really helps and Nest does a great job keeping the house comfortable while being smart about energy usage. 3 stars because the Nest support line is HORRIBLE! Pray to anyone or anything you have that you NEVER have to deal with them. Their solution when you can't add a family member to the account - don't add them. Their solution when their website is broken and can't send a confirmation email - keep using different emails until one works, because we all just have 50 Gmail accounts waiting to be used for one single login.
title: Love the product, hate the support.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: ChocolateMaven
content: The battery is not charging so I'm on the chat line with nest support for an HOUR. I charge it via USB for 10 minutes, re-mount it as instructed, bla blah, it's still not working so I'm told to upload a photo. Twice. Doesn't work so I'm told that I'll be getting an email that I should respond to with the photo. I get the email from a NO-REPLY ADDRESS. So I'm back on chat and get another email, this time giving an email address of support@nest.com So I send the photo, and get yet another email from a no-reply address asking "we would like to know exactly what happened to your thermostat?" REALLY??? You guys have the full transcript of the hour-long chat and now I',m to respond to yet another no-reply email address? Return these pieces of garbage, people!
title: One of three failed after 5 days

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Amazonian
content: Google Nest really is the future when it comes to automatically controlling the temperature of your home. You can easily control the temperature on the Nest unit itself, via smartphone (anywhere in the world) or with Google voice commands with our multiple Google Home Mini speakers throughout the house. Plus, you can set up all sorts of schedules as well. It's really convenient. Even though the install guide told me I would need professional assistance installing my Nest, I installed and configured my unit all by myself just fine.
