I did have to look up online and downloaded a larger Nest pdf manual that shows all possible variations and combinations of wires, for numerous heating / cooling units with heat pumps and emergency heating, which is what I have. It really was no big deal. After that quick study, the installation was easy and although some of the wiring colors in my HVAC unit were different from the Nest install diagrams, it all made sense in the end, and the system confirmed the wires accordingly. Once all the hardware and wires were connected, everything worked and tested properly. All in all it took me about 30 minutes from beginning to end of install. The only extra tool I used, other than the included screwdriver set was a thin head pliers that I used to push the wires into each socket all the way in. After that I just placed the Nest on the base plate and finished the testing and setup walk-through. The app is very complete and easy to set up and understand. It really gives you all the tools that will certainly help you decrease your overall utility bill costs. I am really looking forward to my future utility bills with better savings next month! So far, with 2 days of usage the system has automatically switched between heat pump and auxiliar heat on its own. Before, we had to do that manually directly on the old-school thermostat depending on the temperature outside and how comfortable we felt inside our home. Now, Google Nest does it all on its own. It's amazing. See the screenshots. Plus, Nest detects when we're physically present and controls the temperature accordingly. This will really reduce our electricity costs very quickly. It's been about a week since I installed Google Nest and I can definitely see huge savings by reducing the temperature in my home by a half a degree has already resulted in a lot less time running the heat pump and auxiliary heat in our home. Eco mode kicks in when there's no one home. Just look at the screenshots on both Android and iOS. My only gripe, completely unrelated to the product itself is that my electricity provider is cheap because they don't provide customers with any rebates when installing a Nest. Oh well... At 140 bucks I couldn't really ask for a better price on the 3rd gen Next. I'm really loving our Google Nest. This product certainly deserves a five star review. Must buy for sure. Highly recommended!
title: Incredible product! Must buy for your smart home!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: MT
content: I had an old 1997 thermostat and wanted to upgrade it. After looking at the top smart thermostats on the market,  I decided to go with the nest. I then proceeded to watch several different YouTube videos on how to install the thermostat. Some common themes emerge after watching the installation videos: 1. You need to use the google nest site to make sure your thermostat is compatible with the nest before you buy it. 2. The Common blue wire is an important wire for the thermostat to work properly in many situations 3. If you have a dual fuel system it is highly recommend you have a HVAC professional install this thermostat. I have a single fuel system and some knowledge of HVAC and electrical so I gave it a shot. It took me 90 minutes to install the thermostat as I ran into mounting the thermostat onto the drywall with the screws provided. I advise having anchors and screws with flush ends ready to go for this project. Otherwise, it was easy to install if you follow the wiring guide And online instruction videos. Setup was seamless through the app. My thermostat now keeps a consistent temperature in the house thanks to the nest.
title: Thermostat of the future!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Christopher Gardner
content: This thermostat was incredibly easy to set up! The whole process began with removing the old thermostat and wiring the Nest and installing it. Total time was about 25 minutes. Once I powered it up and logged it into my home network, it downloaded all of the necessary updates it needed. I was pleased to know that it will display time in the 24-hour format! I live and breathe by this format and when I walk past it, it flashes the time and the date to me. The display is easy to read and navigate. I waited too long to put this thermostat in my house! If your HVAC system is compatible with this thermostat, I would highly recommend it to anyone! Just a side note: After several months, I noticed that the battery wasn't keeping charged and I was losing my internet connection. After consulting with a neighbor that is an HVAC technician, he said I needed to have the common wire hooked up (blue). My system only had four wires, and nothing going to the common terminal. I bought some 18 gauge 5 wire thermostat wire (that's the way it comes packaged) at Lowe's and rewired my system. My furnace had the terminals labled for the color coded wire, and everything matched with the Nest unit. The whole process took me less than an hour, and the system runs better than ever. The battery is being charged better than it was before. Make sure you use the five wire setup for best results! Check YouTube for more installation ideas.
title: This thermostat was incredibly easy to set up

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Dutton and Beth Armstrong, Editors
content: We bought two of these and our experience is VERY mixed so far.  I installed both but we had HVAC installers on hand putting in a new system so they supervised my install. Installation is pretty easy BUT the wires do not LOCK in place so if you bump the Nest or if any of a dozen things happen, one or more wires can slip out of the slots rendering the Nest a brick.  While it is easy to insert the wires, getting them to STAY in place has been very difficult with one of them.  The professional took over and also had issues getting the wires to stay in place on one of the units. Usage is also pretty easy.  You can set the Nest locally or on the app.  However, one of the two we bought does not handle touch very well.  You press in (and should get a click) to select.  On one of our thermostats it worked beautifully.  On the other it was very intermittent.  Sometimes you would get the selection you desired.  Other times it would read a "press" as a rotation (changing selection).  The professional also had this experience. Both of the issues we experienced in installation and setup lead me to believe that QC on these units is very hit and miss.  They might be expensive, but they simply are not built well and they apparently are NOT tested until installed by the end user. In usage, things went as expected for several days. Then..... I came home to the front zone (oddly, the unit which had not issues during install and setup) being VERY cold.  It is normally set to 78 degrees with the eco set to "on".  Despite my not having changed any settings, the Nest was suddenly set for 68 degrees and the air was running like crazy.  It was 72 degrees already so the system had changed itself and been running for quite some time. I thought that this was a one-off situation.  It wasn't. I arrived home after running errands for a couple of house and the same Nest had again changed temperature settings on its on.  This time to 75 degrees.  Once again the A/C was running like crazy. I have re-set the temperature again and verified that it is properly set to 78 degrees with the eco setting active. One more crazy change on its own and both are coming out and will be replaced with Ecobees which is what my HVAC company recommended.  They have found the Nest to be expensive and problematic.  I already wished I had listened to them. Beware of these units.  Something is not right in their build process.  Additionally, it looks like some have terrible flaws causing the settings to change spontaneously. I have several other Nest devices with NO issues.
title: Disappointing Beginning

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: USMarine
content: PLEASE READ THIS BEFORE YOU PURCHASE If you want a thermostat that keeps your home a 1° degree +/- of a designated temperature then look elsewhere. This product is nothing more than a manual remote for your thermostat. The auto programming or manual programming on this device is junk. If you’re comfortable with living in a 3° variation in your home then this product might work for you. Keep in mind that you will not be saving money on your heating and air-conditioning utility bills, because this device causes your unit to run longer than you wanted to run by not sending the signal to turn it off prior to the temperature arriving 1° to 1 ½°  +/-  of your designated temperature. You will find yourself pulling your device out a dozen or more times a day to turn your thermostat up or down (+/-) in order to get it to kick on and then have to turn it back to the setting you want it to turn off at. Even then, the thermostat will go 1° to 1 ½°  degree +/-  a designated temperature. Again, this is nothing more than a remote for your thermostat it is not going to convenience your life. It will not save you money because it runs longer than it needs to be before shutting off. I am what is a Black Hawk pilot for the United States Marine Corps and Overqualified and capable of programming this device properly. It will annoy you if you want your home to stay a ½° to 1° degree +/-  of a designated temperature. EXTREMELY IMPORTANT • This thermos has a internal battery that seldom self-charges consistently and/or properly. Making the thermostat inoperable for several hours at a time.
title: This thermostat that keeps your home a 1°degree +/- of a designated temperature then look elsewhere.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Jkronetwlv
content: Make sure you have a blue, common wire on your current system/thermostat or this $200 device will cost you about double that for an HVAC technician to come out and run the wires to the indoor and outdoor units. Learn from my mistake. It’s an easy install, but it requires a blue, common wire. Update 9/28/20 If you have a carrier infinity system, don’t buy this unit. It worked great until it burned out the control board in 2 months and then you needed the original thermostat as it’s a “communicated system” and the Nest cannot work after a part went bad. You have to have the original Bryant thermostat to program the new board which we no longer had. It cost $750 for their thermostat. We have had nothing but problems with this thermostat since we bought it. All the HVAC people I talk to say that Nest is the worst thing to buy and to steer clear of them. I wish I would have asked prior to purchasing this thermostat as it’s an overwhelming amount of professionals saying how bad these things are. We are now over $1,000 into repairs and service calls for a $250 thermostat that we can’t even use anymore in just 3 months.
title: Buyer beware

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Steven C
content: All in all, I'm very impressed with the Nest and I love the minimalist design.  It's a well-made device that feels sturdy when pushing and rotating it.  I think it could win design awards! I replaced a 15 year old Robert Shaw programmable thermostat with the Nest 3rd Generation.  What turned me on to the Nest was the ability to program via your smart phone, some of the modern features, and the ability to add remote sensors.  Installation was straightforward, however, you have to be somewhat handy and you need the right tools, such as a wire stripper (you have to have enough exposed wire to be able to seat the wires in the connector ports, thus you need a wire stripper to remove the wire outer sheath).  Nest has very informative guides on installation, and they include a small screw driver in the box along with a plastic decorative plate with two screws and an internal metal plate designed to attach to a junction box in your wall. I've read some of the reviews about problems when the battery life runs low and it stops working.  I can't attest to these issues since I've only had the Nest for a few weeks.  I believe it uses a CR123 battery that is recharged thru the wire connections and lasts for years.  At some point, the battery will need to be replaced but this is the same for any battery powered thermostat.  Apparently, the unit warns you when the battery is running low. So far, I'm quite impressed with the Nest's intuitiveness, sleekness, and build quality. It does about 90% of what I want and expect.  I did turn off the auto-movement sensing, a feature which turns on the display when the Nest senses movement, such as when you walk by.  The problem was that it was turning on in the middle of the night when I went to the bathroom and lighting up the bedroom.  You can turn off auto-movement and instead activate it by a momentary push, but in the push mode, it doesn't appear that you can customize what is displayed, such as the current temp, the programmed temp, or a short weather analysis.  UPDATE: I discovered that you can change the brightness, with three level options.  The lowest level works best at night for me with the auto-movement sensing. I added a Nest remote sensor (a small disk with a thermostat and wireless capability) which automatically paired with the Nest 3.  The remote sensor can be placed on a table top or mounted to a wall with an included screw.  I programmed the Nest to use the remote sensor in my son's room in the morning when his room heats up due to its south-eastern exposure.  Now his room is comfortable in the morning.  It's not the perfect way to control temperature throughout my house, since the master bedroom where the Nest is located will be over-cooled, but it's only a few degrees difference.
title: Great design and intuitive user interface.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: TA
content: I purchased a Nest a few years ago and it has worked perfectly on my first floor.  My wife purchased a Nest for me for upstairs and I'll just give the facts of what happened over the last few days.  I checked the compatibility test and it passed and I began installation on Day 1.  After about an hour, I had the old Honeywell thermostat off and installed the Nest.  The fan came on but no heat came on in the heat setting.  On the auxiliary heat, nothing came on.  I couldn't test the AC because it was too cold outside and Nest doesn't allow that.  I called Nest and they couldn't figure out the issue and after an hour, they suggested I contact a Nest Pro.  I  contacted a Nest Pro that was suggested by Nest.  On Day 2, he came and spent two hours working on it and about an hour with a Nest customer service rep.  It did not work.  The Nest Pro came back today (Day 3) and spent from 9 a.m. until 12 p.m. with Nest customer service and tried to install my Nest.  At noon, he gave up and had to go to another job.  He had the Nest customer service rep call me directly.  I spent an hour and 45 minutes with Nest on the phone testing all sorts of wiring and different configurations.  It still did not work.  Nest will send me a new Nest for upstairs.  When I went to put back my Honeywell thermostat upstairs, it stopped working.  No idea what happened.  Now, I have no heat upstairs.  Also, I'm out $600 to a Nest Pro.  And, the upstairs Nest does not work.  Later on tonight, my downstairs Nest started going haywire.  Our forced air would turn on and off.  It would do that repeatedly.  I spent the next two hours with Nest trying to fix the downstairs Nest that had been working perfectly for the last two years.  I have no idea what the Nest Pro did or what Nest customer service did to trigger this issue.  After two hours, the Nest customer service could not resolve the issues and is sending me a new base for my downstairs Nest.  In other words, I have two Nest products that do not function and now, I do not have any heat in January.  Those are the facts.  My opinion is that Nest products are difficult to install and Nest customer service is hopelessly incompetent.  The Nest Pros are untrained handymen and women, who are clueless about the product.  I'm really hoping these products can be fixed within the next few days.  I will certainly never be buying any more Nest products.  I'm worse off today for having Nest products rather than my manual Honeywell thermostat.
title: Compatibility is Huge Issue

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: terpfan1980
content: Honestly the installation of this thermostat is pretty darned simple, or so it seems.  Take a picture of your existing wiring, look through the app and if necessary send a copy of the picture of your wiring into Nest support and you should wind up getting a clear set of instructions on which wires need to connect to which terminals that this thermostat will be using.  In most cases it is simple.  Until it isn't quite so so simple.  Which was the case for me recently. I actually called in the services of a family friend that I paid a few $$ to do the install of this thermostat (along with putting in an older thermostat back in my old home as the new owners didn't want to have the Nest thermostat and instead wanted a "dumb" thermostat to use there).  He got it installed pretty quickly and the initial tests seemed to show it was working as it should. We could feel cool air blowing through the vents when we should and seemed to be getting warm air when we should.  Seemed to be though, and not actually getting forced air like we should have.  I didn't catch the issue until the next day and at that point it was a bit cooler outside and I was looking for more forced air to push the warm air around.  I was very disappointed in not having the fan motor running as it should be, and worse without the fan working the heat was working too hard, heating up and not having the air blown through so it was turning itself off after just a few minutes before it cooled down enough to try to repeat the cycle. This issue lead me to make use of Tech support to try to confirm the wiring was correct and had me uploading the picture of the old wiring along with a picture of the new wiring.  They confirmed that things *should* have been correct.  OK.  That lead to more trouble shooting and a determination by the tech that the Thermostat that I had just purchased must have had a bad terminal internally.  No problem, I was offered a replacement unit and would be shipping the "bad" unit back upon receipt and install of the replacement. Replacement unit was received and other than having to take down the old thermostat (that I had to go back to using during the intervening period, at least temporarily) and wire in the new one, the replacement went quickly and easily.  Except the same problem still existed.  Which ruled out bad hardware and left me wondering and troubleshooting again as to what wires were used on which terminals.  More troubleshooting lead to proving that the fan motor worked, that the heat worked depending on how the device was wired, or that the air conditioning worked depending on how it was wired.  Getting the proper combo of all of those was continuing to elude me. Back and forth between where the thermostat was and where they HVAC and heating system are installed was exhausting me a bit, but I went and confirmed the manufacturer of the hardware and relayed that information to the technician that was providing technical support.  In doing this I started researching a bit myself to see if that combo of hardware and Nest was a problem or had known issues and that eventually lead me to solving my own problem when I saw mention of the wiring for the Oil heat making use of the RH terminal.  Hmmm, the recommended wiring for me was using the other R terminal, and not that terminal. The tech support person kept going with me and I noted that I was going to and did test using the RH terminal.  MAGIC happened!!  It worked.  Again, not what the tech support people were telling me to use for my own wiring, but was exactly what was needed. I give credit to the tech support people for being pretty patient with me.  I give credit to them for working to ship me a replacement item when they thought that the one that I had was malfunctioning.  I give credit for the additional support and trouble shooting time that was taken when I was trying to get the replacement working. I take away some of the rating for not realizing early on that they should have suggested trying the RH terminal earlier. Functionally, this is a pretty nice smart (learning) Thermostat.  I like it, otherwise I wouldn't have bought a second one for use in my new home.  (One upstairs, one downstairs actually) I have a complaint that has been common with these in the past in that I really, really, really wish that you could set a "hold" temperature and get this thermostat to stay at that manually set temperature until the hold is released.  If I know I'm going on vacation, I should be able to quickly and easily use that sort of function.  This has been asked about multiple times by multiple users or potential users and I honestly believe this is a failing that the company just doesn't want to address.  It shouldn't be that tough to add as a new feature. I can't give this 5 stars at this point (reasons listed above), but I do really like it.  It is mostly a really nice Smart Thermostat and the Alexa integration makes it a really nifty item to use in my home.  Alexa set {Thermostat name} to {Temperature} is really powerful for someone wants to make things easier on themselves. 4 stars from this reviewer.
title: Second time around with one of these, not quite so simple on this latest install

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Robert J. Kierski
content: I could have swore I already posted a review... but when I came to update it, I wasn't able to find it.  So here goes: I was very surprised at how easy it was to install and configure.  I had a Honeywell programmable thermostat, with an hemostat to control my April Air humidifier.  I'm not an HVAC professional, and I don't pretend to be one.  So I was expecting the uninstall and re-install to take hours, and potentially leave my house un-heated on day that was expected to be -10F. I watched the install and configure video.  The video was very complete and easy to understand.  I was able to watch it several times just to be sure I understood every step, and that I hadn't missed anything. If you exclude the time I spent watching the install video, and the time it took me to figure out how to remove my old thermostat from the wall, it took me at most 10 minutes to replace my thermostat.  And that's when the joy started. Setting up a schedule was pretty freaken easy.  The first week, the Nest "Learned" how long it takes my furnace to warm the house.  So on the second morning, it started the furnace at 4:15-ish so the house would be warm when my alarm goes off at 5:00am.  Similarly... it started the furnace at 3:30 because I told it I'd be home at 4:00.  That it was actually able to figure that out is pretty impressive. The April Air humidifier didn't have a smart hemostat.  You guess what it should be set to, and try to remember to update it if the weather changes.  The Nest if fairly similar, except that I can monitor the humidity in the house from my phone and adjust the settings... from my phone.  It would be nice, if Nest was able to automatically adjust the humidity based on the outside temperature.  Maybe it already does, but I can't tell what it's doing. The user interface, both on thermostat and on the phone app is easy to understand. I'm a little disappointed with the Alexa integration.  I can set and ask about the temperature with voice commands via Alexa.  But I can't control the humidifier, or ask about the humidity via Alexa.  I can't ask about the temperature of my remote sensors via Alexa, or switch to using the remote sensor.  I can't "Hold" a temperature via Alexa.
title: This is how you do it!!!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: KennyC
content: After using this product for almost a year I have found it to be a complete waste of money. It worked ok last winter on heat but when I changed over to AC this summer it has required constant attention and numerous resets and clearing memory. The worst thing is that it can be over set temp by as much as 5 degrees before it comes on. WiFi control and Alexa control work fine. The smart learning feature is just so-so. I still have a warranty on it but I won't bother trying to see if Nest support can do anything as I am not happy with it at all. Nov, 2018 - This is an update to my last review, Nest replaced my last bad one (third Nest since 2016) but it totally failed, which included locking my heating system on all day and allowing a dangerously high temperature to occur. I had to pull the unit from the wall mount to stop the heat. Sorry Nest but this product is not safe...
title: Failed Completely and heated my house to 103 while I was gone.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Aaron Rehm
content: I bought the nest in November of 2018. Had absolutely no issues all winter and loved it. Being able to monitor and change things from the app on your phone was great too. However, this spring the nest blew the control board on my furnace twice in two weeks. Initially it seemed like it could have just been a faulty control board and it was covered under warranty so no big deal...paid for a couple hours of HVAC labor and that was that. Two weeks later it blew the board again, which led to a much more in depth check of the HVAC system which showed everything was perfectly fine and the only possible cause was the nest. It was professionally installed and compatibility was checked before installation. Again, worked fine all winter and ended up costing quite a bit this spring/summer. Not worth the risk of it blowing your system at all.
title: Spend almost $200 to spend almost $1000

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: D. Hagel
content: First, I’ve moved a few times and installed a few different smart thermostats in different homes. The Nest is by far the easiest install. If you are shying away from a smart thermostat because you fear the install...this is for you. All of my houses previously had builder grade basic thermostat.  Typically I upgrade to a more basic smart thermostat. Basically a adding WiFi/app control and a schedule to the otherwise basic thermostat.  I originally tried that here too, but either mine was not compatible with my heat pump unit, or it was defective.  Frustrated, I broke down and paid 2-3 time the cost of a Honeywell for a nest...and I hate it.  But more on that later. As I said, install was stupid simple. Install the app on my phone. Answer a few questions and follow the on-screen instructions and it just works. When you buy a nest, your buying the sort of hands off Smart technology that keeps your home at a comfortable temp When You are home and saves energy when you are away.  So when I first installed it, I let it do it’s thing. The house was frequently too hot when I was home (I’m in Florida)  and took too long to recover from the eco mode once I got home.  So I ditched all the fancy AI for the good ol’ scheduled settings.  I thought this would be the answer to problems and it was...sorta. I set up a schedule to keep the house on track, but I noticed that it wasn’t following the schedule, and still used all the smart tech to adjust the temp for me, despite the schedule I set. I had to turn all the smart tech off to get it to just follow the schedule I set. That took some trial and error to figure out, and that is why I hate the Nest. The problem is that my thermostat is in a hallway that doesn’t see a lot of traffic, so I may pass it in the morning to go into my home office, but then I won’t pass it again until I stop working for the day...-and of course the Nest assumes I’m not home and would raise the temp to save me money. Maybe that would work better if my thermostat was in the living room or another high traffic space, but no home I’ve ever owned has had the thermostat in a high traffic area. No one wants to display their favorite art next to the ugly thermostat. So that’s pretty bad, but the thing that makes me hate this more than anything else is the display.  On a $10 builder grade thermostat, you walk up to the stat and read the temp...but NOT with the nest. The nest shuts off the display and wakes it up when you walk by which is a great feature...and even though I have the app setting to show me the temp, it actually displays the set point if the AC is running...not the actual temp of the house.  So if you are hot or cold and want to know what the temp actually is, it will likely take some fiddling to find it.  This is a real shame because the screen has the ability to do some cool things, but in practice it’s not as cool as it should be. Another big short coming I just found...no ability to just set a temp and leave it there...at least not if you use a schedule. On a $20 basic stat you set a schedule, but when you go on vacation, or for some other reason, you can manually set a temp and press the hold button.  Then it will disregard the schedule and just hold the temp at that setting.  Not with the Nest. Apparently adding a software switch is way to advanced for this massively overpriced thermostat.  Support was nice enough to tell that it can sort of be done if I use the away feature, but then we get back to the motion sensing features changing the temp of the house while I’m working.  Oh but if I just let google track my phone’s whereabouts 24/7, it will do a better job.  No thank you.  How about you just add a hold button in the app. How hard could that be? So there you are.  I would never recommend the nest because I really hate it.  It’s over-priced and the smart features seem to be half baked to me.  If you just want a thermostat to save on your heating and cooling, I would suggest contacting your utility provider and signing up for their energy saving program that gives them the ability to control the temps in your house...because that’s what you are doing here.  You just turned over the temp of your home to google, who owns nest....and if you don’t have privacy concerns with google, you might want to do some research.
title: Easy install, but hate the automation

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: tech phreak
content: Terrible product with terrible support. Ours developed problems after less than 6 months and was constantly turning the compressor on and off - I’m told some sort of circuit board issue.  I was literally out on the side of the house in my boxers with a flashlight trying to disconnect the power to keep this buggy unit from destroying my ac. Since it’s already 97 deg here, we had to call a service to come and repair-they installed a new honeywell that works fine. I do understand that with any piece of technology there is a chance that you can have a defect. However, the design of this thermostat does not allow you to turn your AC units on or off there’s any sort of problem. Also, any time the internet goes out it seems to become useless. Called Nest who would not give a refund, claims that we had to use one of their “approved” service technicians?! So to sum up: buggy product, bad/constrictive service policy and poor design. They are sending a new one which I have no intention of using. If this is the future of the “internet of things” you can count me out. Do yourself  favor and stick with a simple, programmable thermostat.
title: Does not live up to expectations

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Jeff
content: I bought this for our home to monitor my house temperature remotely. We have a heat pump at our house and after reading all of the installation details figured it would work. Installation was not actually that hard, but before completing set up this unit runs a test. During the test it runs the heat pump, but the energy draw to turn on the heat pump was enough to trip the unit and cause it to fail. I called nest and ended up having an installation Pro come out to my house. He confirmed it was all installed correctly, but told me this is a known issue where the Nest sensors are so sensitive that any extra power can cause them to fail. Might not be the best choice for older homes. I ended up removing this unit and keeping an old “dumb” thermostat for now.
title: Very sensitive, did not work due to “power surge”

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Crabhappy
content: I already had this Nest Thermostat working on my IPhone. It installed immediately. I read all the reviews on this and was puzzled why they are so down on the Google Nest. When I downloaded the Nest App on my computer, It worked, flawlessly. Here is the problem with the app you need for interfacing that I came across and what is probably got these negative reviewers so upset. I read the Nest inductions and got to the Migrate the Alexia with Google. I think it is all in the wording. At Google says to migrate to the your Google account. At first I thought they were going to change my email that is Alexia's and change it to the Google account. Their wording of Migrate, stopped me in my tracks. I looked at the reviews, negative and positive. The positives were hopeful. The negatives were confusing. Here is where I figured that Google needs to change the wording Migrate to Pair. Because, that pairing is really what you are doing.  It is a word that people know. Migrate? That is understandably confusing and the wording of Migrate is deceptive. So my fellow Nest users, go for it. Oh, one more thing, when you get past Migrating be sure to go to get your's computer app at https://alexa.amazon.com/spa/index.html#appliances and "discover" the thermostat (or what ever else in the Google services you have. So it is a 3 step process that is really quick and easy.  1 On your PC, download the Nest App  2 .Migrate (which really is a pairing) the Google account with Alexia, 3 go to  the Alexia page and discover the device. All works out super. Enjoy your thermostat.
title: Neat Thermostat and Alexia.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Tori
content: Purchased based on good reviews. Well, it quit working after four months.  Then, had several HVAC reps tell me that the NEST is junk and to buy a Honeywell. Now I can’t get my money back on the Nest.
title: Buy a Honeywell.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Amanda Uhrig
content: Installed this product at the end of February 2019. Beginning of October, it stopped charging on the wall out of nowhere, which means no heat. After multiple calls to tech support, who were rude and condescending, I was able to get them to send a new base. I asked them to overnight it since I live in NJ and it’s getting cold. The guy refused and a week later, the new base came. Product still didn’t work. Three more hours on the phone with customer support and a call to an electrician And plumber to prove that It’s not my boiler and they sent a new thermostat and had me go to Home Depot for a cheap Honeywell, which they said they’d reimburse but still haven’t. New Nest came, and it worked for five days before dying. Paid a Nest Pro $110 to come out and he thought he fixed the issue, but I guess Nest doesn’t actually train Nest Pros because I woke up to a freezing house and dead thermostat AGAIN. Nest support is now telling me it’s that I need a common wire. This is a $250 piece of garbage and I’ve paid over $400 in service fees and over 8 hours of my life - to still freeze.
title: Stopped working after 7 months, customer support no help

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: KillerRabbit
content: Update Nest customer support was excellent although their follow up calling got slightly annoying. My old thermostat was a Honeywell RTH9580WF. I hated it. Needless to say, it was refreshing to take a well made thermostat out of the box (not cheap plastic), have everything you need to install it (including a screwdriver and labels) and have it install easily. No issues except had to troubleshoot an issue with the C wire. At first it was blowing hot air. I had to go into setup in thermostat and switch settings for the wire. I mention this in case yours does the same. So far I have had ZERO problems. Nest server has yet to disrupt the thermostat. Honeywell was down all the time with no warning. The Nest is much quicker to respond, the app is better maintained and has a slick UI and it runs like a dream. Also turning the dial is very satisfying. Would recommend. Old Review: My first Nest product and it was dead out of the box. Display never turned on no matter how much I charged it. I called Nest customer support and they were not surprised. Gentleman immediately put in a request for a replacement (brand new so I was still under warranty). That's great, but now I have to resort to using my busted thermostat until the replacement arrives. I will update review when I install replacement. So far though, not impressed.
title: Dead out of box; updated

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: David Bixler
content: There are a few setup / calibration procedures, and some notes you might want to take an interest in BEFORE you buy. First off, this thing requires the C wire to provide power to the unit. Keep that in mind. Luckily I'm "downgrading" from a Crestron-based "smarthome" system, which luckily supplied a lot of redundant network and power options, so I have the 24v(C) wire [YAY!]. You can get someone to install them, for around $150 based on other reviews and personal experience at a previous residence. The next thing you need to know is, it's going to be bugged until you reboot it (based on numerous complaints/reviews/support requests). Mine was... and the simplest solution was to reboot it (in the settings on the device), then run it through its paces with the heat/cold/fan test, and then to let it run for a while. Removing it from the wall and replacing it didn't seem to do anything. There are also some firmware updates which might help. The next thing you need to be aware of is the placement of your sensor/thermostat wire. We determined ours was in our master bathroom. My house has 3 independent HVAC systems, powering 3 zones. Zone 1 is the Master Bath/Master Bedroom/ Study which is where our NEST Thermostat is located. If someone is in the shower, and the door is closed, the shower will remain warm from the hot water, while our bedroom will cool very quickly due to the number of windows and the deck-facing door... The thermostat said 73/74 whilst the bedroom was around 67 at one point. Once the bathroom was cooled off, the doors were opened, the temperature stabilized to an accurate reading and began heating/cooling appropriately. If you're not sure if your system is compatible, you can contact a NEST rep on their website for free, and they will help you examine your wiring for your current system(s) and see if your system is compatible, and will even prepare a wiring diagram to speed up the process. Additionally: there are extra screws and far more wire connection options than you will need. You will only need 5 wires to operate the system effectively for heating and cooling. 4 if you're only doing one or the other. Very simple instructions, don't overthink it. 1. Remove old thermostat / cover 2. Use included wire labels on wires (BEFORE DISCONNECTING THEM FROM OLD PANEL) 3. Remove wires from old panel. 4. Remove old patch panel. 5. Install metal adapter panel (I used the 2 screws from the old thermostat back panel/patch panel. 6. Install Shroud (you will only have 2 screw holes, so you will only need 2 of the 4 included mounting screws) 7. Pull wires through, before placing NEST patch panel on the shroud, and attach all of the wires with corresponding labels. (refer to the diagram your NEST tech provided you from their website... free) 8. Once you've inserted and locked all of the wires, you are ready to install the patch plate/backplate. Remove the two screws (top and bottom) holding up the shroud and install the patchplate over the backplate, without fully tightening the screws. 9. Use the integrated level to align your backplate/thermostat, then tighten the top and bottom screws. 10. Finally, install the thermostat, configure your settings, set up WiFi connection, and then run updates. It may take some time for it to accurately read room temperature, based on thermostat location, airflow to the thermostat, and a restart of the thermostat may be required. The restart option is in the settings menu. The app works extremely well for me, but also remember you can integrate NEST devices with IFTTT to further automate and enhance your experience. You can even use IFTTT with NEST thermostats to get alerts when they detect motion, so it doubles as a security device for my home. MERRY CHRISTMAS! EDIT: 12/26/2018 I purchased 2 more of these from Home Depot (don't be mad Amazon) because, well, I wanted it done NOW. Mostly so I could properly utilize the eco/away mode. With only 1 zone in a 3 HVAC zone house on eco mode, the other 2 zones would have the burdon of normalizing the temps in the home. Instead I went all in, got 2 more thermostats for the other zones, which came with 4 temperature sensors, which paired easily and work very well it seems. As with the thermostats, it takes a little while (20-45 minutes give or take) to start reading the right temps. The temp sensors are a great way to manage a thermostat which is in a dead air zone. If you feel too cold for the reading on the thermostat, put the temperature sensor in an area that feels cooler than the rest of the room, then tell the thermostat via the app or the wall device to use that sensor instead of its own temp reading... and badda bing badda boom you've got a wonderfully balanced and convenient, and elegantly climate controlled home. It only took about 5-10 minutes for each thermostat to remove/replace the old units and install the NEST Thermostats. It's too freaking easy. Update Feb 5, 2019 Installed Nest thermostats throughout the house. Dropped energy usage from 2148 kWh for Aug - September 2018 to 1834 kWh in December. All the while using the 3 HVAC systems to heat the home. After ending up with a second Crestron thermostat dying, I had already sank over 200 bucks in replacement thermostats. So, I decided to upgrade to a smart "learning" thermostat. There is a marked difference in how well (and evenly) the house is heated/cooled now. The HVAC systems are not active, nearly as often. Before, the thermostats (placed literally a few feet away from the HVAC intakes) would be cooled or heated by passing air, being pulled into the intakes. (Talk to the Contractor about that one) NEST allows you to use remote wireless sensors. So I placed one in the kitchen, one in the office, and one in the tiny "study" between the master bathroom and bedroom. Since then the thermostats have done a far better job at maintaining temps, using less gas, less electricity, making less noise, and doing a better job at maintaining comfortable temps. Not to mention being able to use eco mode when I'm not home, saving more energy. Not to mention being able to set the temperature while I'm outside, or in bed, from my phone/tablet/Alexa etc. It's a straightforward install too. Nest support provided a wiring diagram for free. Used the screws from the old thermostat. There are no buttons on the units. The unit IS a button. The unit is literally a dial you turn to change options and you press it to select. Program a schedule, or just change it. When NEST detects a pattern it "learns" and will start adjusting the thermostat before you can make it there. Oh and you can automate with If This Then That (IFTTT.com). For instance If ( Motion Detected) Then (Turn On Lights) Yeah NEST thermostats have motion detection so the screen stays off unless you're close to it. Kind-of handy actually. A neat night light when I'm fumbling my way to the bathroom. Occasionally the Living Room thermostat freaks out and goes to 55 degrees. Not sure why yet.... perhaps a firmware update is required. Not losing a star. The pros far outweight the cons here.
title: Beautiful / Simple / Easy to Use... But

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: J. Gibson
content: So I purchased a Nest because I wanted a smart thermostat.  I didn't think it was going to save a lot of money because we already have a programmed schedule which minimizes the AC/Heat usage.  I was very excited and while I waited for it to arrive I was looking at the forums for it.  There is one missing feature that Nest users have been requesting on their forums for 2 years with no action from Nest.  That feature is a hold feature.  The only way to have the thermostat hold a temperature for longer than the next scheduled change is to delete the entire schedule and turn off smart learning.  This was a dealbreaker for me, as occasionally I will set a hold temperature and don't want it to change until I manually change it, (IE sleeping in on the weekend).  Furthermore as my schedule isn't static, I doubted the utility of the smart learning feature to begin with.  After further research, I returned the Nest unopened and replaced it with the EcoBee3 Lite.  The EcoBee has all the features I wanted, with the minor hassle of having to program it (which is very easy with the app).  Additionally when I change the temperature on the EcoBee, it asks me how long to keep the altered setting (2 hours, 4 hours, until the next programmed change, or until I change it back).  I really wanted to keep the Nest, but the refusal of the company to provide this functionality drove me to EcoBee.  I will say that while the EcoBee looks ok, the Nest blows it away in the looks department, but at the end of the day, EcoBee has a better feature set.  YMMV.
title: Lacking One Requested Feature

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: jmoar
content: This is for my upstairs thermostat.  My main level I replaced with a Trane thermostat about 6 years ago.  "Before" all the tech updates to the world of thermostats!  I paid over $600 for it from an HVAC friend and it required a separate sending unit at the furnace.  It still works great, but the on line integration is not so great and periodically it just loses the network and can't be controlled.  This Nest unit has been working flawlessly for about 4 months now and is SUPER easy to modify as needed and program.  When one of my kids comes home to stay for a night or so, we can simply alter the program and boom its changed for that time.  VERY easy to operate and now I'm debating just replacing my Trane stat with the same one for super ease.  I would buy this a hundred times over.  I don't use it to figure out things and exact temps as I think that is all silly.  I want it what I want it as far as interior temps go.  But that said, this thing is great and recommended.
title: Works great and super easy to program

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Manuel Noriega
content: You can read all these other reviews here, and I can't add much. I'll just report my perspective: $200 for a thermostat is pretty hefty. After doing a lot of research into thermostats I decided to pull the trigger on purchasing TWO of these. We have 2 units in our house and had problems remembering to turn off the smaller one we use only at night. We tried for a year to remember to turn the dial on the old honeywell every morning but would still forget a couple times a month. That can be an expensive mistake both from a power standpoint and because the smaller unit was trying to cool the whole house. It can't be understated how easy it is to install. I've installed 3 thermostats now and the auto-detect wiring was really impressive. Due to the old wiring in our house, we had to jerry-rig our smaller unit to leave out the "blower" lead (we therefore can't run the fan without either the compressor or heater). The Nest picked it up perfectly and saw what we were up to. The automatic schedule is absolutely amazing as well. After just 1 week it was automatically setting temperatures just as we wanted. Very impressive. I logged into the nest website to set the schedule (you can use the app) and really didn't have to make any changes from what it had put together by itself. I have yet to use the geofencing feature but plan to in the future. I have 2 gripes: - Price: Granted, this is a very pretty LCD screen and a smart computer on your wall, but I still think $200 is steep given todays technology. Though for me this thing will probably pay for BOTH thermostats within a year here in AZ just with electricity alone. Also, some services run a monthly fee to give you the same features and support. Still though, $200 :( - YOU MUST HAVE WIFI TO GET IT WORKING OUT OF THE BOX. After the initial config, I'm sure it's optional (??), but I was incredibly freaked out that you can't at least get your HVAC running out of the box without having it talk to Nest's stalk-o-matic cloud computer in the sky (which I am fine with, if I have to, I guess). You could easily configure it and then change your wifi password, but still. I'm knocking off a star, because you should be able to at least get your house temperature under control without wifi. It's $200, create a "dumb" mode people. UPDATE:  June 2019: I bought this Nest with the intention of eventually linking it to a wider home-automation system, which I have since finally built. This was a feature Nest advertised, I bought it with the intention of doing so, and Google has since TERMINATED this feature. The integration with most platforms has been shut down for those who have not done so already, and even existing integrations will be shut down in August 2019. Currently I'm trying to get Home Assistant to link in and the API sign-up has been disabled. It's unclear if they will ever allow me to use the product I bought in the way they told me I could. Alexa integration has been affected as well if I understand correctly, though I don't own an Alexa so I don't know for sure. I am waiting for the class-action lawsuits to role in to see how Google will make me whole after paying $400 for a product they've since hamstrung. Even if they fix it, this is obviously not a trustworthy company. Also, there are many other options out there now (Ecobee I've read is good). PS: Nest has responded to my "does not work without wifi" comment stating that this device indeed does--maybe once you have it setup this is the case, but myself and my friend the professional HVAC repairman friend were unable to figure it out after reading the instructions that came with it and tinkering with it in the 90 degree heat for a half hour. I suspect that if it is actually possible that it was added to a later software revision which my Nest did not have out of the box (and without internet, could not get it). There were definitely some configuration questions we had the option to SKIP plainly seen on the screen, wifi setup was definitely not one of them. If you buy a Nest and plan to review it on Amazon, maybe you can try to set it up without wifi to start out with just to have a more complete review.
title: [UPDATE: Bait and switch, buyer beware!]

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: K.W.
content: I really don't like it. I bought it trusting that it's an established product but I think the premise of this as a learning thermostat should be the most important consideration for a buyer. I got it in summer and let it ran, didn't pay attention to what configurations I needed. Winter came and it went crazy. I couldn't override the temperature when it was freezing cold. I tried to turn off all smart settings but it won't respond - even though at times it says it will get to the temperature in 2 hours. Never happen. At a point I finally got the low battery signal people online complained about, then I realized how many hundred thousands of customers had issues and had to rely on the community help for whever c-wire workaround. My contractor and I tried this method, but now it became super hot all the time and won't cool down. There's 20 degrees difference between what it is and what I want. I live alone and now constantly worry that my cat either is freezing or will be baked. I hate you Nest. The Google help isn't helpful as the community on YouTube.
title: Only looks nice

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Malori
content: Warning to anyone with an older home, make sure your wiring can handle the device. We tried for two months to get ours to work, the fan for our A/C would constantly run and then it wouldnt work with our heat. Had an HVAC guy come out to assist and he said he sees this issue all the time with people who have purchased a Nest. Unfortunately this product has an incredibly short return policy, so I wasnt able to return for another thermostat.
title: Warning to anyone with an older home, make sure ...

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: William W DeToro
content: A mind of its own. I was 1300 miles away and had someone staying at the house and he was not able to adjust the temperature to a comfortable level as the Nest kept setting the temperature back up picking up that I was away. Obviously, this becomes a real pain in the butt if you ever want to allow others to be in your house when you are away. My guest tried to unlock the system but even with my password he was unable. He had to physically take off the Nest and reinstall my old manual thermostat to get the place comfortable again. As for contacting Nest service: forget it these people are not at all interested in making the after the sale problem solving easy. Anyway, when I returned to my SW FL home I reinstalled the Neat again. I thought I had figured out how to get the system to unlock. It looked like things were improving however after two weeks I have not been able to turn off the fan and I have not found any place in the system where it guides me to do so. I am going back to my manual thermostat as this Nest just is too difficult to get to do what you want it to.
title: Too much of a mind of its own

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: NewEnglander
content: bought the thermostat to have the wireless functionality to set and change the temperature remotely. unfortunately the thermostat is unable to get to the right temperature; when we want to start the heat from a 68 night setting to 73 morning temperature it is unable to do this on-time. the designated setting for 73 degrees is not reached until 2 hours later, consistently for the entire winter season so far. (The learning mode is enabled)  the previous $65.00 Honeywell was more capable and achieved this feat without difficulty year after year. 2019 January update. Have owned this thermostat since late 2017 and very disappointed with this product. It is unable to get to the right temperature on time from a 68 night setting to 75 at 6 am. The learning mode does nothing. We have now set the desired heat time to 5 am in the hope it can reach the temperature at 6 am. No change as it goes as far as 74 and stops. We have to set it to 76mto get the last 1 degree. We don’t need the in-out of home mode for the temperature control as we have elderly parents home all day. The thermostat also does not turn on until one feels the cold air. This is worse on cold days. One would think that the thermostat would eventually figure out this environment since it is also supposed to be “aware” of the outside temperature. We expected the thermostat to learn the heating/cooling rate in this home, but it does not. Too expensive for what it cannot do.
title: very disappointed given generally good reviews - no improvement over time...

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: L Williams
content: I've never had a smart thermostat before, so I have nothing to compare it to.  But this Nest device is amazing.  Even better, the installation instructions are CLEAR and EASY to understand!  There is an interactive picture and text based set of instructions online that take you through each step, and troubleshoot along the way. The thermostat works with my Google Mini and of course the Nest app.  You can program what times you want the house to be at which temp and it will either start heating/cooling at that time, or you can set it to start before then, so it's nice and comfy when you get home.  It has features for dealing with humidity and can even learn your temp preferences and adjust accordingly.
title: Best purchase ever!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Victoria G.
content: Ohmygosh, we LOVE our Nest thermostat!!! Yes, it is pricey, but it will save you money. We have a two-story home with a single thermostat upstairs. With the Nest along with three additional sensors, we can adjust our temperature setting based on whatever part of the house we're in. No more freezing downstairs while the upstairs is burning up. We love that we can adjust it from anywhere. Anywhere. The other day we left and wondered if we'd remembered to turn it down. (We haven't had it long enough yet for it to "learn" our preferences.) I simply adjusted it while we were out shopping. It is so convenient! We were also able to turn the heat back up while we were on our way home. I highly recommend the Nest thermostat when used along with additional sensors. As an added note: we also have Nest doorbell and cameras on the outside of our home. Everything is seen and adjusted from the same app. It is really convenient.
title: A MUST have!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: L.W.
content: Although Nest products are a bit “Pricey” they are a quality product that works as advertised,while offering “Idiot Proof” installation. As I’m not the most mechanically inclined individual.nest makes the installation of their devices simple,heck they even provide a “branded” screwdriver.Once installed, setup and connection to your WiFi is again simple and straightforward. After setup you can control your thermostat thru your phone app from anywhere that you may be. As a bonus it plays nice with Alexa,which allows you to check the temperature and adjust your thermostat just by issuing verbal commands. And lastly it just looks good, mine is copper colored with a round black wall plate that I purchased at extra cost thru Amazon.Or just use the white (square)plastic wall plate that comes with it. Whichever way you go you won’t be disappointed with the Nest Programable Thermostat.
title: Finally a Thermostat that offers Home Climate Control while looking good doing it.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: michal
content: I think the core product itself is fantastic.  It's literally like a volume knob for your home temperature.  I think the ability of it to toggle on and off as you go in and out of your home is a great money saving green feature.  I also think having the ability to set a zone of the temperature you would like is great and pre heating or pre cooling your home when leaving work is an added bonus.  I do find that using the full extent of the application however is not the most user friendly.  I am a techy so I figured it out but I had a hard time trying to set hours on the calendar. It is learnable but it will take a lot of getting used to for the less tech savvy.
title: Great but App is weird

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Shockster
content: Every time I have to deal with this thermostat I'm frustrated. This thing has so much potential yet fails so horribly. Pros: It's pretty. No wi-fi connection issues. It hasn't broken, technically. (Has it ever worked, though?) Cons: First and foremost, it doesn't hold a temperature, which I think is what a thermostat is supposed to do. I can't overstate how terribly uncomfortable this is. Temps swing 2 full degrees. I wake up at night sweating because it lets the temps rise so much before triggering the AC to come on. And then 30 mins later I'm freezing because it over cools. This, according to support, is to save my compressor from cycling too often. Okay, I get that, but this is all software, right? Give me the option to choose how much the temps swing. Why is this not user configurable? Secondly, so many of the features have no consideration from multi-stage systems. Instead, the settings want to swing temperatures wildly, which defeats the purpose of having a multi-stage system. Again, this is software--it COULD be smart enough to not trigger the second/third stage when it decides to swing, but of course it's not that smart. For example, the auto-away mode has a minimum setting of 76 degrees Fahrenheit. (I don't ever want my house 76 degrees in the summer, by the way--what's wrong with you, Nest?). If I leave, my house will go from 72 to 76. When I come back, it now wants to run the second stage AC to force the house down 4 degrees. Uhh... why isn't there some logic to say use first stage for an extended period instead? Again, this is software, right? Or how about you just let me have my away setting at 74, which is way more reasonable in the first place. If my thermostat were 76 degrees half the day it would be a sauna. It needs to cycle more than that just to control humidity where I live (KY). The heat used to have some stupid max setting of like 64 but they fixed that--it can now go up to 70. I'm not sure why they won't fix the AC. When I called support, the tech said he hears this complaint constantly. Next, the scheduling is awful. The auto-smart crap is like AI from 10 years ago. They must have gotten the code from RIM for the new BlackBerry. Manual scheduling is unbelievably time consuming. I'm forced to create a gazillion points to slowly bring the temp down because I don't want it to trigger the second stage AC. What I want, in the summer for example, is for my house to be 72 if I'm home during the day, 70 at night while I sleep, and 74 when I'm away (Boy, how I wish that auto-away feature wasn't so STUPID--it's the whole reason I bought this thing!) So this thing can control a humidifier--great! Good luck finding that setting. I had to watch a YouTube video to figure out how to find it. Controlling the fan schedule is equally confusing. The humidifier setting is slightly easier to find on the phone app, but my HVAC tech doesn't have his phone setup to control MY thermostat. The fan setting is dumb in every interface. This product is a piece of crap for no good reason. My intention was to buy ALL of the Nest products, but if they can't get their core offering right, I have to assume that the rest of the line can't be worth my time.
title: The interface sucks, there is nothing smart about it, it doesn't hold a temp. Nest could fix all these problems but they don't.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Steven
content: RETURNED IT! Worked great during the 1st winter months, then acted up after 2 Summer A/C months. The Nest started turning off the HVAC fan, but leaving the A/C running so the coil would freeze over to a solid block of ice! I gladly re-installed my old trusty & SIMPLE Honeywell thermostat and my HVAC works perfectly again. Granted, I miss setting and scheduling on the fly using my iPhone remotely, but I’d rather have the security of knowing what my thermostat is doing over the comfort yet unreliability of having remote control and slightly higher utility bills over having to worry, lose A/C and possibly having to replace my whole HVAC prematurely! Plus, did you know that ConEd can control your HVAC tapping into your Nest! Creepy or what?! Smart homes are looking stupid to me now! The more remote and complicated? The more chance of breaking down and possible invasion of privacy! BEWARE
title: Ultimate? Simpler is smarter. Always!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Clay Franklin
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. Always Too Hot or Too Cold - In my opinion the Nest thermostat is inaccurate and too slow. I find that all day long I am turning the next up and down since it does not do it on its own in a timely way causing the home to get too hot or during the summer too cold. Exactly what happens is demonstrated in the video.  The house got too hot so I turn down the nest then a minute or two later the thermostat changes the room temp registered.  It should shut off 1 degree cooler than it does since it thinks it is colder than it really is and it finds out too late after I had to manually turn it off. I called Nest support and did all the activities they suggested all to no avail because it did not fix the problem of not working right.  I think they either did not want to send me a working new one or they did not have one that didn’t have that problem. Also I have turned off auto adjust temp based on history because it was acting wonky and causing a lot of manual override and way too frustrating. 1. Video (sorry its so long, 1.7 minutes so ok to scroll to the end to see it jump from 71 to 72 after I manually turned it down. 2. Picture of thermostat with a high quality “air quality machine” I got here on Amazon. 3. Screen shot from the Dyson air quality machine iphone app showing a higher temp than on the thermostat.  It is always colder in the kitchen so not surprised it is 1 degree lower in there than the living room where the nest is and where I see 74 degrees on the Temtop unit, 72 on the nest and 73 on the Dyson. Overall super excited to get it very neat and nice to be able to turn on heat manually from remote location like when wake up but need a thermostat that is higher quality and works more accurately so it is managing the heat instead of me stopping what I’m doing to adjust the “nest”. ...looking for the ultimate iphone controllable thermostat.  If you know of one please reply with the recommendation.
title: Not Recommended - Always Too Hot or Too Cold - Seems the Nest thermostat is inaccurate and too slow

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Metz
content: My installation is a simple forced air heater. For years I have had a basic programmable thermostat. I found a like new discount NEST (the one with the fancy screen) and jumped at the chance to upgrade. The installation was easy enough (I did need to do a factory reset but that is to be expected given it was a used device). Once completing the reset it has functioned flawlessly. With the ability to manage the system from my smartphone and the devices ability to adjust to my schedule and temperature setting makes to really nice. After a few weeks it seems to automatically go on or off just like it was reading my mind.
title: A new level of comfort

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Patrick123r45
content: Definitely recommand this product. I have a separate heating and cooling system. Gas furnace heating hot water which is sent to a radiator in the attic. A single blower is used for heating and cooling. Pros: Conpatibility app is great, It gives anyone the knowledge they need to ensure compatibility and gives you the confidence you need to complete the install on your own. Very easy install with added instruction manual, included wire labels, and on line videos On phone tech support was excellent Iphone (and mac book pro) apps are the best, no more getting up in the middle of the night to lower or raise the thermostat Kids think it's the coolest Cons: Price, it's not cheap Chat support was not technical enough, in the end they gave me false information. Could have burned out my heating coil if I didn't call tech support Problem, out of the box the system does not turn on the fan when the heat comes on. Has to be modified by a tech. Luckily, phone support walked me through some advanced settings to turn on this feature. Very easy to do if you know where it is. Problem, When the heat goes off the blower goes off. Should have a setting that keeps it on for say 5 or 10 minutes. Inconvenience, after making the change above the fan icon is not displayed on the thermostat, iPhone, Mac apps. Worried about burning out my coil I keep checking just to make sure.
title: Very cool tech but use caution

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Anthony
content: MY nest worked perfectly for about 5 months, then all of a sudden, it will not stay charged. I have removed from base and charged with micro USB cord and still will not stay charged longer than 2 hours. Now my A/C will not turn on and stay on due to thermostat shutting down. Even with out the Common wire connected, my nest worked for over 5 months, it is supposed to charge while the A/C, Fan or Heater are running without the Common wire connected. It is not charging even while the A/C is running. It will not get above 2.6 volts even after spending all night on the wall charger. Biggest piece of junk I have ever bought.
title: MY nest worked perfectly for about 5 months, then ...

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Rick Seeler
content: I have had two nests for the past year, one in my primary residence and one in a vacation house in the mountains. Up until today, if you'd asked me what I thought of Nest I would have given in five stars. But, all of the convenience and money saving just went out the window. Up until recently, the Nest app on my iPhone worked well.  When I was going to my vacation house, I would set the Nest to Home (70 degrees), and when I left, I would set it to Away which should have set the temperature back to 40 degrees. But, someone at Nest thought it better to keep the temperature locked at 70 degrees day and night when it's set to Away. As you can imagine my utility bill was exceptionally high since I last left that house several weeks ago. Apparently Away no longer does what it used to. Being a developer of iOS apps myself, I'm well aware of how to use the software, but some moron at Nest had to screw around with the app and f' it up. That's the last Nest I'm ever going to buy.
title: IOS App Sucks, Beware!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: EastBayRae
content: The 'learning' part of this thermostat is that you learn that it will adjust the temperature anyway it pleases no matter what you do. Set it 19C, come back 20mins later and its set to 24C. Turn off Eco, 2hours later its back on. I left it installed for 3 weeks, got frustrated that it was like having my cat control it, and then de-installed it. It gets 1 star for appearance and packaging.
title: Is that you HAL 9000?

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: telmar
content: Is your idea of a "smart" thermostat one that shuts off after you leave the house on a freezing day for "energy savings", so when you walk back in after work it's 48 degrees inside?  Nicely starting the heating process *the moment you walk back in* so by the time you go to bed you're warm enough to take your parka off? Then buy a Nest! (Bonus: you get the opposite effect in the summer!) If you don't want to walk into a frigid house every day, you can simply: turn Nest's ability to recognize that you've left the house off! Or manually schedule the house to warm up every day whether you've left or not!  Either way, overriding all of the "smarts" of this thermostat and all of your energy savings! I've owned two Nest thermostats and three Nest Protects for two years.  I've had plenty of issues with them... I was more enthusiastic at first, but then I noticed that my energy bills were not meaningfully lower (don't presume you will pay much less!) and functionality that used to work no longer did. But this one is the kicker.  It's a problem that most people would run into - seasonal variation.  Nest support/engineering seem totally clueless and unresponsive about it, and I've noticed this is a widely shared/posted issue. Folks at Nest... A "smart" thermostat with the ability to sense when you're away and turn your thermostat off has to be smart enough to a) turn it back on *prior* to you arriving home, unless it figures you're going to be away for a while, and b) not let it get so cold or hot that you lose all energy savings benefit in the process.  Isn't this obvious???  Maybe this just isn't a big problem in the Bay Area.
title: Nest, did you test this in any area with hot summers and cold winters?

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Carl S.
content: This thermostat works great as a remote controllable thermostat. Home/Away is a great idea, but there is no way for it to be used if you want the house warmed up before you get home. Schedules are a way to get around that, but you have to disable home/away because if the nest is set to away, it ignores your schedule. Since I am not following a consistant schedule, I found I was constantly having to change the schedule every day anyway. Eventually I disable all the automation on the nest and outsourced it to IFTTT and apilio. Now my nest works great as a remote controllable thermostat. 2 things that could make this better is to let me change the home/away status remotely (IFTTT) and let me use the motion sensor in the nest for an IFTTT trigger. Then at least I could call it smart.
title: Great, just disable all the "smart" functions

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Sephethus
content: This needs serious work, even in its third generation. I don't quite understand the mindset of its developers but it seems that they intended this for use by extremely rich white house wives with a/c and heat control in every room of their mansion. Most normal people have just one thermostat in their house, even if it's got 3 bedrooms and 4 stories. I don't think I've ever been in a house with more than one thermostat. There's not even an option to choose "House" as the location of the thermostat. This makes no sense. On top of all this their Alexa app is probably one of the worst device control apps I've ever had the displeasure of using. It has almost zero instructions on what the commands are, you basically have to guess, and the commands are limited, make no sense, and once again, assume that you have a thermostat in every freaking room. Who are these people? "Alexa set the basement to 68" Yeah, setting "the basement" to 69 isn't possible because that would set the whole house to 69, I named it "The House" instead, since it didn't have that as option I had to do it custom. Not only that, if the heat is on and I want it to cool instead, I have to say "Alexa, set 'The House' to cool" THEN say "Alexa, set The House to 69".  Only then will she turn the A/C on and cool it down. Why can't I just say set the house to 69 and have it assume that if the heat is on, and it's 76, that she should turn the A/C on instead and cool it down to 69? WTF?
title: Who Are These People? I'd Really Like to Know

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: geoff arvesen
content: We have had our best thermostat for a little over a year now and I have to say we love it. I would give 10 stars if I could!!! The features are amazing. I like that You can adjust the temperature when you’re not home plus it syncs with the weather and knows when to adjust the temperature. Plus it knows when you’re home or away and learns your routine. We keep it set to a temperature range where in the winter it won’t go below a set temperature and in the summer it won’t go above a set temperature. No more switching back and forth between heat and ac in our crazy Texas weather Our electric bill is significantly lower. It takes a couple weeks for it to learn your routine. We don’t ever even have to touch the thermostat.
title: Would give it 10 stars

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: A
content: I was skeptical upon buying since most reviews were negative. 3 months into using and so far I am happy with our purchase! • Set-up: Phenomenal walK through — ANYONE can do it! I was so nervous to start it on my own, I actually procrastinated a few days. Advice: make sure your phone is fully charged and house cooled (and it’s not the hottest day) before starting installation, as your power will need to be turned off to install. •Sensors: If you are looking to purchase, I would HIGHLY recommend getting AT LEAST 3 sensors (depending on your sqft; ours is 2400) or the Nest will not be worth it. Make sure you place the sensors in your warmest rooms and one in the coolest. This will help with the Airwaves feature, which saves energy by using the fan to circulate the air and make the house a similar temperature. With sensors, you will also be able to see individual temps of each room (which sensor was placed) and will have the choice to set the room as primary. For example, at night I set my temp to 68 and make the bedroom primary; otherwise, if I leave the family room as primary my bedroom ends up 3 degrees cooler.
