All this to drive home the point that the additional sensors make a big difference. • Learning: This feature can be turned off. As far as the learning thermostats settings go, I’m happy with it. I find myself adjusting the temp less, though I nearly always want it set at a certain temp at a certain time so could easily get by with a schedule. I could see how this setting could become a nuisance if you are one to change the temp constantly at various times without some sort of pattern. For us, it took about 5-7 days before the temp was automatically changing. • Geo-cache: The geo-cache is a really cool feature — we love! It will prep the house for your desired temp when you are within a certain radius coming/going from your home. Downside, the constant ping of your cellphone location decreases your phones battery life. • Remote access: Controlling the device from our phones and Alexa may easily be one of the best features. The convenience is a game changer! • Reports: I was so excited to review the history reports and they did not disappoint! It tells you the run time, of an adjustment you made saved energy, if weather affected usage, and how many hours the ac ran for the day. I’m sure there are other features I haven’t touched-on, but these are my most used and -enjoyed. As far as energy save, it’s hard to say that the Nest has made a tremendous difference in our electric bill. We installed it in Spring, when the temps outside have started to rise. Our electric bill has remained about the same since installing — so it’s either saving money (because with outside temps rising there has only been a slight increase to our bill) or it’s making little to no difference. Though energy savings was my main motivation for purchasing the Nest, I am still happy with the purchase (even with our electric bill not reflecting much of a change).
title: Great buy — must purchase sensors!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Andy H
content: After 1 year I had to replace the unit because the battery stopped being able to charge to a level that would power wifi.  This would have been fine because Nest was quick to replace it and things worked.  Until just recently, I had my A/C die and I had noticed that heat was coming out when the A/C was supposed to be running.  I replaced the air handler and outside unit b/c a valve had blown on the heat pump - only to find that heating was still happening.  It turns out something in the Nest, either a bug, or a faulty mounting base is causing the AUX heater to run while my A/C was running.  I have no idea how long this was going on for but I'm sure it isn't good for my A/C unit.  I have not done complete analysis yet to see how much this was affecting my bill.  Note to figure this out I used a temperature gun and pointed it at vents with the aux wire plugged in vs unplugged - I saw about a 10 degree difference.  Update - I'm raising my rating on this because I like all of the features of the Nest Thermostat.  And I like that they stand behind their hardware and do care about their customers experience. I'm raising my rating to 2 stars because I like Nest's software and the concept behind it.  Also their support, when I have known there was an issue, has been helpful.  I replaced the base on my unit and it is no longer running the heater.  So it appears that all of this was due to a bad component - the battery issue may have been related to this as well.  It's a shame because it's the cheapest component and probably should have been replaced with the thermostat the first time to rule it out as an issue.
title: Faulty Hardware has shaken my confidence - Still they have good features and stand by their product.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: SteveH
content: Thermostats have been installed for some time now and they're nice but I'm not a fan of the "learning" feature (I only bought this version because I wanted the copper finish and it was on sale). Sure, if you fiddle with your thermostats all day, "learning" may eventually be welcomed. But most of us live by the clock so great (manual) scheduling functionality, without having to teach it is, IMHO, better. I eventually turned "Auto-Schedule" off because it competed with configured schedules. I live in northern New England and have a duel-fuel system (propane, heat pump) with 3 zones; I run 2 different schedules for winter (one when it's cold and one when it's REALLY cold), then 1 for summer and 1 for spring/fall (heat-cool). But, you cannot configure multiple heating schedules and switch between them so, even with Nest, I STILL have to edit schedules. :-( Nest scheduling is better than many but still not ideal. Pros: 1) It's looks very nice on the wall. 2) Installation was easy although I did have some trouble getting one connected to WiFi. Googled for answers- got nothing helpful. Then it just mysteriously connected and has been fine. I dunno. 3) The user interface on the device and the app is nice and I really like the detailed technical info. 4) Heat-Cool mode: awesome. 5) Fan schedule. Cons: 1) It is obsessed with displaying the setpoint(s); seeing the actual temperature isn't as obvious. I'd like to see inside and outside temp, setpoint, humidity and time - all, conspicuously - when Farsight activates. Maybe someday there will be more display options. 2) Can only create one schedule for each mode. 3) Can't make different fan schedules for weekdays/weekends. 4) It will mysteriously light up at night in the bedroom even with Farsight disabled. Overall: Very good. Minus 1 star for the listed cons.
title: Good thermostat; don't like the "learning" feature

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: jm
content: My home is old and does not have a "C wire."  The system consists of AC and Electric Heater, using a 4 wire controller (R=24 VAC, Y=Cool, W=Heat and G=Fan.) I had the first generation Nest installed and it worked for about 4 years without problems, until it failed, conecting both the AC and heater for a day and a half: I have been heating and cooling my home during day and a half!  I installed an ancient mechanical thermostat and things were normal again. I decided to order the third generation Nest. In my installation, the 24 VAC transformer delivers an open loop voltage of 28 VAC (R wire) with respect to Y (yellow) or W (white) when the thermostat is disconnected and there is no load.  When connecting the 3rd generation Nest base to the wires, the AC voltage between Y and R, used by the Nest electronics, drops to about 12 VAC, impling that the current consumption of the Nest base produces a significant drop of 28 -12 = 16 VAC in the coil of the relay used by the AC activation.  With that low voltage the thermostat shows an error message when the additional load of the display is connected.  Bottom line, I had to return the Nest 3rd generation. Some people (even Nest) suggests that the heater wire (W) could be connected to C (common) as a short term solution, during the summer time, or viceversa, connect the cool wire (Y) to C during the winter time, until you have the time to add a c wire.  Others suggest using the fan wire G connected to terminal C.  Any of these "solutions" imply not using all the features of the thermostat. My suggestion is to avoid the Nest 3rd generation or any other smart wifi thermostat if your home does not have a c wire installed.  Nest should make it clear that a c wire is a requirement.
title: C wire strongly recommended

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Nathan
content: First off, I have to say that I am not only impressed with the actual thermostat but also Nest as a company. This was quite an expensive purchase and took some time making sure I was making the right purchase. One of the things that solidified my decision to purchase this thermostat was Nest's compatibility checker on their website which made the process a lot easier to know it would be compatible with my existing system. It involved me taking off the cover on my existing thermostat, looking at the connected wires and their labels, and then putting that into a checker on their website. Nest told me which models would be compatible and then also how it would look once I received it. Others here say that the installation is simple and they are not lying. I'm somewhat handy, but I hate messing with electronics like this. This was a relatively easy job that took me about 30 minutes, if that. Nest also included most of the tools I'd need to do it, minus one screwdriver but that was to remove my existing unit. Now Nest doesn't leave you in the dark once they get their money like other companies do. While going through the setup in the app (which is extremely user friendly and helpful), I encountered a problem. I called Nest support as I was directed in the app. The wait was about 7 minutes and I was speaking to someone who spoke clear, understandable English and then transferred me to their thermostat division. The call was interrupted for some reason, maybe my end, I don't know, but they called me back and the woman was extremely helpful in explaining. She didn't baby talk me nor did she use jargon most people wouldn't understand. She explained, what turned out to be, a very stupid misunderstanding on my part. Had I read the directions a little more clearly, I would have seen it, I just got confused. Once we got all that cleared up, she sent me an e-mail and directed me to take a picture and send it back to her. The e-mail arrived to me faster than she could finish her sentence, and I'm not exaggerating on that. She received my e-mail as I was done sending it and she explained to me over the phone how my wiring would be done. She also offered to create a customized diagram for me to use which showed me exactly which wires would go where. The rep offered to stay on the phone with me while I finished or encouraged me to call back if I ran into any other issues or questions as they have a 24 hour customer service line just for questions like this. I have to say I was very impressed based on that call alone. Next part was that I had a working thermostat in 5-10 minutes after ending the call with her. It really works! Setting up Alexa was no problem as well which Alexa does on her own for the most part in the app. We needed a thermostat like this for my dad who has been having vision issues. Thanks to this thermostat, he is able to control the temperature in the house much better than before, making him feel more independent and better even though he's in this nasty situation. From myself and my family, we thank you Nest for allowing this for us. The only complaints I have is in regards to the voice control, which I suppose could be changed if we really wanted to. For instance, there's no documentation I could find that tells you exactly what you need to say. But after a Google search, I found a forum on this where someone had the same issue and I found the solution. To control the thermostat using voice, you say "Alexa turn up the heat" or "Alexa turn on the cooling" depending on whether you want air conditioning or heating. I was hoping more for "Alexa turn up the heat to 80" but this is fine. We all now understand what to say and there's no real issue. The thermostat is smart and seems to be learning our habits and how we like the house and the Eco feature is supposed to save us some money on our bill, so we're looking forward to that. I can't comment on either of those features at this time since we've only had the unit for around a month now. As of now, we're extremely satisfied with this. It truly feels like we're living in the 21st century when you can turn up and down the temperature using your voice. And that thermostat is absolutely beautiful to pass by. It has a lot of useful information on the display and also lights up when you pass by. It's really awesome and I'm really excited about it.
title: 5 Star Item

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: FM22
content: Bought 3 nest thermostats for my house. I put a lock on the range using the Nest app. I tried to change the settings from Heat to Cool from the app, it did not work. I tried to unlock the devices from the app it did not work. I forgot the lock password. I am now stuck with the thermostats in the "heat" mode. I called customer support, I am on call for 2 hours waiting for the senior support folks as the first level cannot solve the problem.  I can clearly see that Nest and Google are going downhill. Google no longer stands for quality - they need to learn from Amazon.
title: Pathetic customer support. C grade software system. Do not buy!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Us
content: This is my second purchase of the nest. I had an older version in my last home (before google bought nest), so when I decided to move I bought the nest again hoping for the same positive experience. I bought this copper plated one before we moved and then it sat in a box for a month. We pulled it out and installed it (unfortunately) the day after the return window so I was disappointed when the unit was defective. Thinking that I'd make things right, we contacted Nest ourselves hoping to get it resolved. After waiting on the phone for several hours, the nest customer service representative agreed to send us a replacement if we returned the defective unit. They sent us a shipping label and we boxed it and mailed it back. When Nest received the return, they sent us a box in return except they just sent the main part, the face. No face plate, no instillation tools. Nothing. We were disappointed but went to nest again hoping to make it right. It's been 2 months since the first time we contacted nest and we've contacted Nest 3 times to resolve this issue with nothing but empty promises. We still have less product than we paid for and I can't help but to feel swindled by a major tech corporation.
title: Terrible Company *Buyer Beware*

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Charlie B.
content: This is a very nice thermostat, but not totally high tech enough for my Lennox.  I purchased to install on my Lennox furnace / air conditioner.  Have friends that love their Nest's, and wanted to get started with the Nest universe of products.  Purchased, opened, installed and found it was not compatible.  My Lennox has a continuously variable fan, that I love, and the Nest will not work with it.  I started to questions the Nest after the testing of the fan, turned it on but would not speed up the fan (it barely blew any air).  After much Googling of Nest website, buried deep on the website was a note about continuously variable furnaces, and the fact Nest 3rd did not work.  So, here is what you need to know.  If you have a single stage, dual stage, or three stage (1,2 or 3 speed fan) furnace this will work.  If you have a high tech continuously variable fan your out of luck.  Once you go to a furnace with continuously variable, you will never go back.  You hardly know your furnace is running as it can ramp up and down to the perfect heating and cooling fan speed.  So, hope Nest will update their thermostat some day to work with this style of fan.  Hey Nest, how about a remote thermostat like Ecobee?
title: Good Stat, but did not work with my high tech furnace.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: GrumpyShopper
content: I've spent 3 hours trying to get this to work and I'm done.  Nest support was awesome when it came to getting it wired correctly.  It took a lot of chatting and several photos but they eventually confirmed it was compatible with my system, and sent me an illustrated wiring diagram.  I got it connected and powered up.  The problem was that it wouldn't connect to my Wifi.  I have two 2.4ghz networks and one 5ghz network.  I'd put in the password and it would fail instantly, no indication that is was even trying to connect.  Support told me to try a hotspot from my phone.  That did work, but I'm not going to leave my phone here 24/7.  I rebooted my router and extender, and tried again.  The Nest still won't connect.  Support did send me router recommendations and there was nothing indicating that it shouldn't connect to my 2.4ghz networks.  I'm very disappointed that I'm returning this.  I'm even more disappointed that I wasted so much time on it.
title: Nest support was helpful on one issue, worthless on the other.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Kimi E
content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video. First, check to see if your system is compatible with Nest. You can easily do that from their site. Once you’ve determined that it’s compatible, add this baby to your cart. Skip the expensive pro installation unless you have a really jacked up system. I was able to install it in about 10 minutes. 1) take a picture of your existing unit and where the wires are plugged into 2) cut the power off to the thermostat. I couldn’t figure out which breaker was assigned to our system, so I just shut the main one off to the house. No big deal. 3) dismantle the old unit 4) screw on the vanity plate from Nest (it was more than big enough to cover up the holes from our old unit, so don’t waste money on a large plate if you don’t want to). 5) Connect the wires to where they were on your old unit (kinda like speaker wires, you open the clamp and it pinches down. It’s easy) 6) attach the Nest faceplate (main unit) 7) push on the faceplate to get it hooked up to your WiFi, what settings you’d like, etc. 8) download the app and sync it with your unit Boom, done. Nest also provides a screw driver so that was great! I use Ohm Connect to get monetary kick backs for energy conservation, and if you provide your Nest login they will turn off the Heat or AC during the peak time for an hour then turn it back on to resume normal programming.
title: Absolutely love this thing

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Jacob H.
content: Unfortunately we didn’t have great experience with nest. We got in October when it was hot (down south) and only heat would work, once we had about 5 people look at it and figure out the wiring ac finally got to working. Now we are mid November and it’s finally in the 40s so we needed heat. The heat did not work, only blew cold air. Paid for another ac/heat unit place to come out and look and they determined this does not work with my unit it will not detect heat and cold together only one or the other unless we re did wiring every time we needed another mode. I was passed the point of returning it on amazon but i called them and they handled it immediately and said they’d make an exception and send a full refund and prepaid shipping label, I was very pleased with amazons customer service. The nest system is sleek looking and very user friendly with your phone IF it works for your house. If not it’s an absolute pain! Before purchasing I’d make sure the thermostat is compatible with your system first.
title: Doesn’t work with every unit

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Paul J Paradis
content: Here I sit freezing my butt off. Three times I have dealt with Nest support staff. The Nest thermostat has not worked from day one. Bells whistles, but no consistent, reliable HVAC control. I was at first skeptical when I saw that 13K+ people rated it so high. Ask yourself:  does 13000 people have such unanimity on anything Yet my skepticism based on statistical classes gave way to the romance of big numbers I could read on the display and the bogus too-good reviews. If you do not believe this product is junk, come over and sit a spell but bring a heavy coat and two pair of socks.
title: Bogus reviews--13,000 agree 99%--Never

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Christine Mislang
content: I was a bit worried when I watched several youTube videos on installing my nest.  Once I figured out how to remove my exsisting thermostat, I followed the instructions on the video that nest posts on youTube.  I shut down the power to my house, simply because I was unable to determine which breaker shut down the power to my new heating/cooling unit.  Once I did that, it was super easy to match up the wires to the correct slot, flipped on the power, replaced the front and tada it booted up!  Follow the instructions and download the app on your phone and you are in business. Now I bought the nest because I wanted the ability to control my homes heating/cooling from  a distance.  That can't be done with a simple programmed thermostat.  I like the idea that I can be at work or school, stay uber late and make sure that my heat/cooling doesn't come on and run for a few hours while I'm not home. The box comes with everything you need in order to disconnect your original thermostat and then install your new Nest. The bonus with the nest is my particular gas/power companies offer rebates, that drop the cost of the nest by a significant amount. I would highly recommend the nest to anyone who is looking for an easy install, great control, and nice looking thermostat! Enjoy!
title: Super quick and easy Install!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Jeffrey Baker
content: This has worked so far with an old Day & Night Gas furnace with just two wires. I put the white wire in W1 and the red wire in Rh. However, after reading from others that using a Common wire would be good, I saw that there was an unused blue wire. So I stripped it and plugged it into C. That was not a good idea because the Nest thermostat didn't do anything. It didn't turn on and the little light did not flash or anything. So I unplugged the blue wire from C and then it turned on. It was a little difficult to get the wires pushed into the holes all the way so that the clip button stayed pressed down. Since I read from others that auto-schedule and Eco mode do not work very well I disabled them and just set a schedule. I don't know how Eco mode could effectively know when people are home or not in a house with four people and different schedules. I don't want to make every person install the Nest app on their phones. It was not as easy as I had hoped to get Google Home and Amazon Alexa to recognize the Nest thermostat. It wasn't difficult, but I am a tech and it still should have been easier for non-techs to setup. I wish it worked with Siri without having to buy extra hardware or third party apps, but Google doesn't want to take the time to program it. Apparently it will work with Homebridge and a Raspberry pi. But that is a lot of work and hardware. Also, now it will apparently work with Siri Shortcuts, but you also seem to need to purchase an app called Thermo Watch. But Siri Shortcuts requires iOS 12 or later and I have not updated my iPhone yet.
title: Worked with two wire heater

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: jj_int
content: It’s great until it stops working. I have two Nests:  the cheaper one I got as a work anniversary present; and this more expensive version. All of a sudden, this more expensive version refuses to connect to my WiFi network. The cheaper one chugs along with no problem. I have been through all of Google’s online trouble shooting three times to no avail. What is really bad is now I cannot control my AC unit without removing the Nest from its base and then putting it back, essentially performing a type of “reboot.” I wish I had never spent so much money on this thing. A $20 programmable thermostat from Hone Depot would have been better and more reliable. What a waste of time and money. I finally found the number to tech support (1-855-469-6378) and spoke with a very nice agent who followed Google’s processes...after more than an hour I was finally given two choices for a replacement Nest:  (1) set up Google pay so that Google would send a new Nest to me; or (2) send in the defective Nest back and receive a replacement in about 10 days or so...all the while, I’d have no way to control my AC. Well, I was forced into setting up Google Pay AND I was forced to connect my Nest app account t to my Google account, giving Google yet another siphon to my household data (thermostat data from both Nests now associated with all else of my digital life that touches Google). Extremely disappointed. If you want to waste your money and time, get this thing. If you value tour time and money, go low tech.
title: Time and Money Wasted

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Bob Gibson
content: Cool looking thermostat.  Great display. Nest does a great job advertising the shiny thermostat.  They need to invest some funds into better educating material on what the thermostat actually does.  I shouldnt have to sit on line for a hour to understand the functions of a product. Simple to install (5-10 minutes). Yes, its a learning thermostat.  Yes you can program it yourself. From my observations, it presumes you are away (which changes your thermostat settings) when there isnt motion around the thermostat.  My thermostat is off the kitchen in a dining room that no one sits in.  So if my conclusion is correct---it is not a great tool for my house.  I highlight my use of the words; observation, presume and conclusion---because Nest does not disclose how this function is able to work/function. The app is ok.  Doesn't get the best ratings on the Apple store---but seems to work fine for me. Overall, underwhelmed.  I have an expensive, fancy thermostat on my wall.  Has not added much to my comfort, convenience and I doubt I will see a difference in my heating/cooling bill.
title: Just not drinking the koolaid on this one

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: GM
content: Spent 3 hours on the phone with Support troubleshooting, swapping wires from contact to contact, etc., to no avail, it kept blowing hot air instead of cool. The wait time to talk to Senior Support staff is 45 minutes! A product that is incompatible with most systems, plus a frustrating support service. Don't buy, stay with your current brand of thermostat. After all, this fancy looking gadget doesn't really offer anything special; you just need cool air in the summer and that is all you expect from a thermostat.
title: Too much hype for nothing, bad product with bad support

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Rivershark
content: So I love it, (and it was sooooo easy to install, 10 stars for that!) and the email that the nest sends out about use and stats, BUT... I have some pain points: 1) It doesn't seem to like the fact my husband and I use two different brands of phones. If I'm home the device works great. I'm also the primary. If he's home (and I'm not) and leaves to take the dog out to potty for five minutes, the Nest won't come back from away status even when he's back in the house and walking in front of the thermostat. 2a) I can't find a way to program from the app. Due to issue #1, I want to manually program so this doesn't happen to him again. 2b) Our house is east/west facing and using the eco settings is a major pain. We need to use lower than 75 for our normal non-vacation away temperatures. If I could do my own programming this would be so helpful. 3) The app isn't as intuitive as I would like. I always seem to be searching for what I want to find to do with the nest.
title: I could use more control functions!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Pavel Chernikov
content: After close to 2 years, all of a sudden it stopped connecting to WiFi. It would connect and disconnect immediately. Troubleshooting is next to impossible, it just gives you a cryptic message w/o any details. I've done a hard reset of the thermostat and a hard reset of my WiFi router. No change. I'm out of warranty out of luck. For $250 I expect better quality and way better support. This is unacceptable. I won't be buying any more Google products, their warranty and support are atrocious.
title: I would like to like this product, but when something goes wrong it goes wrong

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: S. R.
content: I hate this thing. I've been on support 3 or more times now to get the home/away assist to work. That's all i really care about. I want it to turn on when I am home and turn off when i leave. Support keeps having me do different thing and nothing works. The home/away assist is supposed to detect when my cell phone is at home. It doesn't and now my activity history does not work. You can find less expensive themostats that work better than this. I'm sitting at home working in my office wondering why it's so hot. It's because it thinks I'm away and sets the thing to eco mode.
title: Nice design, but I hate it

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Cocky4two
content: I wouldn’t recommend buying one of these.  I have had 2 of these already and both have done the exact same thing.  They work well when they work, however if you ever have a power surge or power failure, and then power comes back on, it’s gonna start messing up and tell you that your RH or RC wire, your main power wire, is not working.  It will give you a error code.  And no matter how many times you disconnect it and reconnect, it’ll tell you this!  I had a HVAC tech come out and check everything on my system that cost me $80.00. I found out nothing was wrong.  It was the thermostat.  So I replaced it with another brand new one, another $230 spent and it lasted about 3 months and same thing happened again!  I finally went and bought another smart thermostat by Honeywell and hooked it up.  Not a single problem!  Everything with my system works.  Tried the nest again just to make sure, same issue saying RH wire was not detected.  Hooked the Honeywell back up again, all is good!  So with that being said, don’t wasted your hard earned money of $230-250 for this thing as eventually it will do this to you!  Get you a Honeywell!
title: Big issues after power failure with these thermostats!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Tank
content: For me to meet all my needs, this was the only choice I had between the other brands.  For the past few years I had another brand high end Wi-Fi thermostat.  I liked it and it met all our needs until I upgrade my jetpack to 5Gb.  We live in the out of the cities and we use the jetpack to connect to the internet.  The thermostat would connect if I set the jetpack to 2.5gb which is slow, but would not connect to the 5Gb setting.  In talking to the company, they did not offer a thermostat that would work on a 5Gb setting.  In my reasearch the Nest was the only brand that did connect to a 5Gb.  I was not happy about replacing the thermostat, since the current one worked well. PROS:  Connected my 5Gb jetpack. Large display, and only displayed what I want The advanced features it offeres, if I want. CONS:  It's probably me, but I found some of the instruction a a little confusing.  I did figure it out, and did tell Nest.  I could of called, but didn't. AVERALL, I'm more than pleased and would highly recommend this thermostat.
title: GREAT THERMOSTAT

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: surftim
content: I had purchased a Sensi several years ago and really liked it.  However I did receive a notice that there was possibly an electrical issue with my Sensi.  Last night my furnace stopped working.  Late last night I was deciding between a Nest or Ecobee.  After reading reviews about support, I decided to go with the Nest.  My installation went as smoothly as the instructional video on the Amazon site.  That is a rarity for me with any DIY home projects.  I have the Nest App installed on my phone and can now control my thermostat from my phone like I did with my Sensi. Next task will be setting up Alexa so I can give verbal commands from any room with an Alexa device. Then the most important task, the repairman shows up to repair my furnace.
title: Easy to install without "C" wire

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: B. Link
content: Installation is not straight forward. Got their online assistance and was advised by Nest to do it incorrectly. It worked through the winter but wouldn't control the air conditioning when it finally got hot enough to turn on the system. Not saving us a dime when I have to spend $200 for a service call to fix a simple thing Nest should have made clear if they are giving installation advice. On top of that, record heat and no AC. Would consider an alternative were I to do it again. Makes me concerned about their other products. May revise after seeing how their customer service assists in remediating the problem.
title: Installation is not straight forward. Got their online assistance ...

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: KWM
content: It's a great "smart" thermostat, relatively easy to install and operate,  However, when you integrate it with the Nest camera, there are issues.  The resolution on the camera is so-so. My biggest complaint is the Nest software and their propensity to get owners to subscribe.  They do that by providing an awkward simpleton version that effectively punishes you for not subscribing.  Refer to the attached screen captures.  There is a distinct flavor of "bait & upgrade" here! The first one shows the default display.  Note how large the thermostat display is and how small the video.  Why?  The temp display could be one small corner of the video. The second image displays what you see when you click on the camera.  Hmm... I wonder why they couldn't display the temp in one of those black areas? The third is a zoomed image illustrating the effect of having a low-res camera. My recommendation is to look around and check out the details before you buy.  This is not a first blush review.  I've owned the thermostat and camera for more than two years.
title: It's a great "smart" thermostat

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: A Conserva
content: First Gen 3 wifi failed after about a year.  Thermostat still works but none of the smart feature which is why most of us buy this (phone app or web dont work.  Nest was very good about replacing.  Second Gen 3 wifi failed after about 6 months.  Customer service was puzzled, didn't seem to understand that the new one broke for the same reason as the first.  Basically implying that because they sent me a fix for the first one the second could not get the problem.  Don't know what to say other than the wifi does not work, can't connect my phone, cant reprogram the thermostat outside of the current temp.  They told me that they don't fix the thermostat for the same problem twice and anyways I was just out of warranty (few days) from the original purchase.  They offered me 20% off a new one.  So now I need to spend another $200+ dollars on a product that fails randomly (seriously why would wifi just stop working?) and they don't seem to have a good handle on how to fix or why its caused.  No thanks.  I see there are a lot of other recent complaints about Gen 3's failing.  I would advise skipping this generation.
title: Gen3 has unrepairable hardware issues

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Callum
content: The biggest problem with Nest right now is that Google has taken over complete control of the product and in doing so they took away many features.  This will not work with Alexa in the way that you want, will not work with IFTTT, and therefore making automation work with this impossible.  It's really sad because it was working just fine before, but almost all of the automation functionality of talking to your other smart devices has been removed.
title: Google took over Nest and the broke it.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Picky One
content: I had an issue where the thermostat wouldn’t stop. I was outside but had to drive back home to turn the AC off by shutting off the power. I messaged the seller few days ago but I haven’t received any reply. I had to reset the device so it would work again but I’m doubtful with this device now that it had failed once on the second day of usage... Main reason for the one star is because I expect amazon sellers promptly replying customers and not just ignoring their messages. Any new problem with the device, I’m returning it.
title: Issue on the 2nd day, does not reply to your message

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Karen Guiltinan
content: I own two nest thermostats and now that we are 0 degree temperature they have both gone off line with a low battery setting.  Was on hold for approximately 3 hours yesterday and just gave up after being on hold two hours today since I actually need to work for a living.  Seems like it is a known problem the low battery setting that occurs in cold weather.  My poor husband spent hours yesterday trying to trouble shoot and the problem is the nest.  This morning I contacted Amazon and am not sure if I will be able to get my over $200.00 back since Nest is not a part of Amazon.  Thank goodness I bought my second one elsewhere and they took it right back when we said defective. DON"T DO IT!!!! DO NOT BUY THIS PIECE OF JUNK!  Now I am praying my pipes don't burst as a result of the cold.  Now we need to buy heaters as well as new thermostats.  If you have money to burn this is the thermostat for you but surely not for me. Update - Amazon is giving me back 160 of my purchase.  Cannot give me back full amount but something definitely beats nothing!  Good once again for Amazon customer service helping.
title: NEST IS GARBAGE IN COLD

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Helen
content: Just moved into our new house and Installed the Nest.  We were pretty happy with it until my AC unit stopped working. We were getting ready to call for servicing when my husband decided to put the old thermostat on to see if that was the issue. As soon as we took off the Nest and put the thermostat back on, the AC unit kicked on. Before this happened the Nest kept switching it to the "away" mode and the house was getting hot. I guess we received a defective unit. Pretty sad because we loved the options it provided. Not going to chance it again when it's 94 degrees outside.
title: Worked for less then a week and died

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: LaurenZ32
content: I have actually bought three nest learning 3rd generation thermostats for three houses I own - I wish I did not.  We split our time between two locations (1 location has two houses) and I thought it would be great to have a thermostat that knew I was not home and would lower the temperature in case I forgot.  It does that fine.  I also thought it would be great because it would "learn" when I got there and have the house nice and warm/cool for me when I arrived.  It does not do that and that sucks.  Not only does the thermostat not do this for me M-F arriving home from work everyday at the same time but I also go to the other house every Friday about the same time and the house hasn't started heating/cooling.  I hate coming home to a cold/hot house.  I even go so far as to turn the heat/ac on before I leave for one house but my guess is because I am not home, Nest turns back the heat/ac and that prewarming/cooling I tried to do via the app has stopped. Also, there is no way to "hold" a temperature and I find myself wanting that sometimes. During holidays and vacations (or anytime I am home when I am normally out), I would like to set a temperature for that day and just leave it there until Nest can go back to regularly scheduled programming, but even though there is movement and my phone is around, Nest goes to the schedule it learned and I find myself constantly turning the thing back to the temp I want it. Anyhow, I wanted the Nest brand because it was the "cool" brand and figured it was so popular because it was good...I wish I did more research. I will say this - I installed one myself and needed the help from Nest customer service and they were great! Overall, if I had to do it again, I might have gone with a different one.
title: Really compare brands - I wish I would have

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Geoff Rose
content: NEST has really gotten a great product line out there, and while there are hiccups here and there, their famous thermostat remains a strong contender for 1st gadget people should buy for home automation (a Google or Amazon hub the second). The NEST functions great on its own, running from a smartphone app, but also integrates perfectly with the most popular smart device hubs. I really love being able to remotely prep my A/C and heating depending on the season. Home can be low-power most of the day, then an arrive before I arrive, tell it to switch to preset temp range. Physical install has been made ridiculously easy, and network setup is just plugging in your password (slight security gap in that you have to have a decent router setup keeping your home network secure, but that's a whole other review). I've had my app take a few tries to reach the device, the device disconnect from the network, but 95% of the time, it just works. There are all kinds of profile, scheduling, and other programming features you can do, but it's a great product even if you don't use those.
title: Great product, it's mostly about how much you control

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Slideone
content: After owning this thermostat for 8 months it suddenly decided it would not communicate with my phone. After3 grueling hours on the phone with a "SENIOR TECH" he informs me that my wifi is too fast for the thermostat to communicate with my phone. Humm well it has been communicating just fine for 8 months. What this tech was trying to say after 3 hours he didn't have a clue! He did inform me that it would work fine without the phone, so who cares, if it won't work with the phone it is useless to me. I might add I had to have another one of these replaced at my other house. So, what we have here is a high tech piece of junk. Buy at your own pleasure!
title: Never again!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: M. Blackhurst
content: Simply put... one could spent extensive resources trying to make this product compatible. Details below. Google's (previously Nest.com's) indication that the 3rd generation Nest thermostat is "compatible' with our Bosch Greenstar boiler is either plainly false, ambiguous in its referencing "most boilers," or achieving compatibility is simply cost ineffective. I have spent countless hours and over $560 trying make this thermostat work with our Bosch Greenstar boiler, including $250 for the thermostat; $130 on "service fees" from two different "certified installers" that were unable to install the product, $160 on switching relay with a 110V-24V power transformer; and $20 on a c wire. I have followed all the technical support I can find online, which is pretty poor, and it still does not function. I am now past the return period but have nothing to show for our investment. Update: Got it working. Since Google has taken over Nest, they require users install and use "Google Home" on their devices to interface with the Nest. They also discounted providing software for Apple watch. Purchase another product. Expect additional unwanted changes demanded of Google.
title: If it does not work immediately upon install, I recommend returning to save lots of money

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Thrice-a-dad
content: The units worked fine initially. But THREE have each failed after a month or two. In each case, the unit's output to the heat pump reversing valve went dead, leaving the unit to heat whether heat or cooling is called for. In the days of COVID-19 their phone support is unavailable, but the chat support has been adequate. They sent new units for the first two failures, but now I'm thinking of just returning them for credit and trying an Ecobee. After reviewing search results on Bing (I think Google suppresses reports of NEST problems) I am convinced this is a chronic problem that is not being adequately addressed. Beware if you are buying for a heat pump with an orange or "O" wire as this must be energized to cool on many systems, and the unit fails to energize leaving the house to become VERY HOT when you expect cooling! I have some minor complaints too, but I won't go into them here. Suffice to say that Google is gathering tons of information about your home environment and offering you the merest of summary data in return. As an engineer, this is an additional frustration. Plus, if you have "time of use" electricity plan, there is no mode to respect and make the most of this.
title: BEWARE! Three have failed the same way! Don't buy for heat pump with reversing valve O wire.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Mike G in MN
content: I like the Nest. It is easy to install if you have even the tiniest bit of DIY experience.... but. I do not like the web site by Nest to see if your system is compatible for using the Nest thermostat. I decided to upgrade to the Nest after hearing good things from a few friends. I opened up my old thermostat and check the wiring to see if everything was good. According to the Nest web site I did indeed have everything I needed for a Nest to operate with my system (wiring coming out of the wall from my HVAC system). I was assured by the web site that my four wires (W,G,Y and Rh) were enough to operate the Nest. They were not. If you are going to purchase this Nest... I suggest you look at your current wiring. If you do NOT have a "C" wire (common) either attached to your existing thermostat or shoved back in the wall... you might want to either run this extra wire or look up alternatives on-line. My Nest operated for two days and then died. I troubleshot the fault and found this is a common problem that Nest doesn't really address... at all. Cut to the chase... If you have a HVAC (heating and air conditioning) system like I do... check to see if you have at least five wires coming to your thermostat... if not... you might need to re-wire it BEFORE installing the Nest. Without the "common" wire, your Nest can NOT charge the internal battery... then it cuts the WIFI connection... and then will stop working totally. It was 5 degrees F in Minnesota this morning... I am just glad I found the problem before I went to bed... and that I had not yet thrown out the old thermostat. I intend to run a C wire myself and re-install the Nest... but buyer beware UPDATE- NOTHING BUT PROBLEMS. The Nest website is worthless. I checked out reviews and BAM... Defective thermostats, bad programming that made the thermostat worthless, system malfunctions. I have had nothing but problems since the cooling season started. I ended up removing the Nest.... at the suggestion of my HVAC guy... until I replace my entire HVAC system.
title: Nice, Smart, Well Designed, Easy To Install For A DIYer... but.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: DJ  Clarke
content: First I would like to let people know if you have an older house, mine was built 1978, the correct  wiring was not there. We had an electrician in the house doing other work so we asked him to install it. He has to add wire that was not in the wall .  So this was not an install we could do ourselves. We don’t have Alexia so I can’t comment on that. Temperature control works well. But we’re confused about how one temperature, like 70 degrees could have three settings. I guess 1 is barely 70, 2 is exactly 70, and 3 is almost 71? Anyways . We still like the thermostat. Now that we finally have internet we can get an Alexia set up.
title: May need an electrician for install

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Raymond E. Stephens
content: Great product, technically, but it may be too smart for its own good.  The installation was very quick and straightforward – no surprises there.  The Nest thermostat accurately learned my consistent daily schedule for nearly a week, then I went away on a long trip, setting the system to “away.”  Checking on it with the app two days later, I discovered that someone apparently came home in the early morning of the day after I left, restoring the auto-programmed heat cycle.  Then they seemingly left later that morning, consequently re-triggering the “away” mode, yet no one was supposed to be home at all.  An early morning burglary?  I had someone check on the house but there was no evidence of a forced entry.  What went wrong?  The thermostat evidently detected my unusually early movements on the morning of my departure, and then, in my absence, precisely repeated these actions the following day.  When I reset the “away” mode remotely, the system remained that way for the duration of my trip.  The take-home lesson: don’t walk past the thermostat after you’ve told it that you’ve gone away!
title: Too smart?

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Benny M.
content: I had a 2nd Gen that worked flawlessly for over a year. So good that I decided to give it to my mom and bought a 3rd Gen. What a mistake... The 3rd gen worked for 9 months until the Wifi chip went bad for no apparent reason.  Common problem on these, look it up. Did some troubleshooting to the Nest Tech support team via FB messenger since they don't have a phone number to call anymore (I'm sure a cost cutting measure). They checked the power readings and a few other things and sent me a replacement within a week. The replacement (likely refurb) worked fine for half a day then next morning it suddenly can't detect wifi anymore (and the display wakes up after 30 seconds rather than immediately as it should). Now I ask for another replacement but continually troubleshoot for a week and go as far as including whitelisting the Nest MAC address on my router (which my network hardware config has not changed at all) and they keep telling me that their team is looking into it with no expected time of when they can respond... In this day and age, this is unacceptable service of keeping a customer in the dark. Why not just send me a replacement and their troubleshoot the defective thermostat when you receive it? Also, perhaps they refurb the defective units and use them as replacement stock but clearly, their quality control isn't very high. I'm more tech savvy than your average consumer and I'm pretty sure 9/10 people would have no idea how to whitelist a MAC address. With that in mind, be expected that if yours does go defective, it's pretty much a paper weight and they'll get around to it when they get around to it.  I'd have second thoughts buying another one given my experience.
title: Warning: Tech support and quality declining

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Flaxman
content: I've now used two of these thermostats for 4 years and as I've noticed more annoying particularities, I'm updating my review. These thermostats are obviously very pretty. Build quality is outstanding.  The Nest app, which allows you to control the thermostat remotely, also works great. I have three gripes with these thermostats: 1. The learning feature is worthless to me, unless you want a thermostat that changes the set point every 15 minutes.  Maybe this is good for people who are not capable of setting up a schedule on a programmable thermostat with proper setbacks when they're out and at night. For me it just means the programmed schedule gets messed up if you ever manually adjust the temperature. Thankfully, the learning can be disabled. 2. With heat pumps, alternative heat changeover temperature does not work well. We have a heat pump with a natural gas furnace to provide alternative heat on very cold days. The Nest has a changeover temperature: if the outdoor temperature  drops below that, it will switch to alt heat. The problem is that it gets its outside temperature from Weather.com with zip code granularity. This will work great if the outdoor temperature at your house is always close to the average for your zip code. However, if you live on a mountain side, close to a body of water or any other geographic feature, then that may not be the case and the Nest will not be able to switch over to alternative heat correctly. Temperature at our house is often off from the zip code average by as much as 10 degrees, so that means this function does not work well.  As I am writing this, it's 83 degrees outside and the Nest tells me it's 67. That's a full 16 degrees off. In the winter it's no better and to get around it, we adjust the alt heat temperature frequently as needed. It's unfortunate that there is no way around this. It's just poor software programming at Nest Labs. The device has all the technology to do this right. To get accurate outdoor temperature, it could allow you to enter a weather station code, or even just allow to place a Nest sensor outside your home and designate that as an outdoor sensor. It's all there, but the system doesn't allow you to do this. OK Google, can you fix this? 3. the third issue is that the home/away function stopped working well. I believe this used to be determined by the GPS location of your phones. When Google acquired Nest so that they could monitor us better, they changed the away feature so that "away" means the motion sensor in your thermostat hasn't detected you in 15 minutes. When you walk by the Nest, it knows you're home. This may work great when you live in a studio, but it's useless in a home office, when you're working in a room out of the seeing eye of the thermostat. It made the away feature, which worked pretty well before, completely useless and I had to turn it off. 4. the last issue is that the temperature swing is not adjustable. This is uncommon among programmable thermostats. The differential is always set to 1 degree, which means that you'll have 2 degrees temperature swings; fairly much.
title: A beautiful, extremely expensive programmable thermostat with some issues. Not ideal for heat pumps.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Physics Teacher
content: Amazing thermostat. This NEST Learning Generation 3 thermostat surprises (in a good way) everyday. We are now in week 3 and are still discovering some of its capabilities. We were replacing an 11 year old "dumb" SimpleComfort 2200; dumb but a true workhorse. Installation hiccups: 1) The Widget Wiring diagram was incorrect. If we had followed that diagram's layout we would have been without auxiliary heat strips. A quick call to NEST support caught the Widget error. Basically, the correction was to a move wire from the W1 to W2 Auxiliary. CAVEAT: TAKE A PHOTO of your ORIGINAL thermostat wiring!! You wil be glad that you did. 2) NEST seems very proud of the fact that it does not need/use jumpers. This is true if your jumper is  bridging R to Rh. However, the "no jumper" feature does not include any other jumper settings. In our case we had a jumper bridging W2 to E (Emergency Heat) - see attached photo. Result? We no longer have the Manual Emergency Heat option. While this is disappointing, we could not think of a time when we ever used Manual Emergency Heat. Manual Emergency Heat is not Auxiliary Heat (heat strips). From what we have learned Manual Emergency Heat is a feature most useful in the higher latitudes. We live at the beach in North Carolina so it is not an issue for us. We called NEST support concerning this issue. They researched possible solutions. Unfortunately, the only fix is to run a separate wire from the air handler Manual Emergency Heat connection to the NEST * input. In our case, this is not practical.
title: Amazing thermostat. This NEST Learning Generation 3 thermostat surprises ...

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: MSRR
content: I’m disappointed with the temperature gauge. Something is completely off. The sunblock function does not work. If sunlight hits the Nest directly, it assumes the room is super hot and air conditioning turns on when the temperature is actually satisfactory and 10 degrees cooler. So, the sunblock function is not working. Another example is using the eco setting when it’s windy and we keep the windows open because the temperature feels comfortable. However, the Nest shows a higher temperature than what it feels like and turns on the air conditioning. Basically on some days Nest displays 78 degrees and it feel comfortable whereas on others the same temperature is too hot to handle. We also turned off the google learning feature because we wanted the rooms to heat up by 2-3 degrees early in the morning and then by another few just before getting up. With the learning feature I had to get up 2 hours early to set the temperature and then again 30 minutes before actual wake up time. I wish the learning app could facilitate the set schedule as a basis and then build on by learning deviations. The design is modern and setting up is not an issue, but I cannot claim the Nest is better than the Honeywell we had before.
title: Needs improvement

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Itsa Me
content: After installing the thermostat per nest instructions (4wire, no common) the blower fan started shutting down funny after a call for heat or ac. It would stop, start again a few second later, stop after 30 seconds, and just kind of randomly pulse.  Thought it was part of the money saving logic, so ignored it for a year. Finally googled it and its a sign the nest doesn’t have enough power and needs a c-wire ran. Mine already had the extra wire ran, so not a huge deal to hook it up. More concerned about what this did wear and wise to the blower. For as much logic as they built into this thing, a simple incoming voltage check was just out of the question?
title: Just run the c wire, ignore nests claims

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Sam R.
content: So I ordered 3 of these for my business. Absolute garbage. They do not work with my system. I'm not upset that they don't work - there's plenty of other competitors products I can purchase and use - I'm upset because of WHY they don't work. So far I have returned 2/3 and I installed the third in my home - just to give them a chance. The one in my house is working fine so far and I plan to leave it there for a month or so to see what happens. Installation was simple enough - I've installed plenty of thermostats. I went through the setup like normal - added to wifi - which doesn't have WPS which would make the process SO much easier when you have a 24 character WiFi password! After setup the last step is to do a "system test". Its cold, so it won't let you test AC (which is good you'll find out why soon), but it let me test heat. So I hit heat and the heat turned on. Good! Then I hit done and the display said "the heat is now off". The heat did not turn off. I removed the display from the baseplate. The heat STILL did not turn off. I removed the R wire - the heat then turned off. After talking on the phone with nest support and burning out a second baseplate they tried to tell me that having stranded instead of solid wires was my problem. WHAT A LOAD OF CRAP!! After I told him "lets pretend I have solid wires" he just told me my system was incompatible with NEST. I then decided to measure the current that went through when the heat was running. The systems we have deliver 680mA @28v while running. I'll admit this is high, but its not extreme. Most systems run at less then 300mA. My system at home runs at about 50mA. The systems at work DO have a common wire which the support guy tried to tell me was also the problem. Basically what happened was the 680mA was enough to destroy the circuitry in the baseplate. This is insane to me. The fact that this wasn't engineered well enough to take that little current is just poor design! I began to read online of issues others have had with this. Some people have had the Nest burn their compressor out because the baseplate fried while it was running and the fan turned off but compressor did not. To solve this issue you must add a relay for each wire. Thats crazy. Add relays to switch another set of relays.... So I returned them and ordered 3 EcoBee's. After reading up on them, an engineer stated that they had designed the EcoBee to be able to handle the proper current. Since I have common wires I can use them. Nest's power stealing design I've heard can burn out circuit boards - I hope it doesn't do that to my unit at home. If it does, I'll come change this to a 1* review wish you could give it negative stars! It is unacceptable for a third generation design to not fix a fatal flaw in the hardware of this thermostat. GET SOME BETTER ENGINEERS! I am an EE that works in an office with other EE's. . . We all think its crazy how poor this design is. Last thing to add - support is wonderful because it is 24/7 but when calling at 5pm means you have to wait for a half hour to talk to someone then wait 45 minutes to talk to escalation... useless... Get more employees. So in the end... If you don't have a common wire and need a smart thermostat - this is pretty much your only option unless you run a common wire from the thermostat transformer. Otherwise please don't buy this piece of junk. What a waste of money.
title: Poorly engineered garbage. Software is great except for a few missing features. 24/7 support - be ready to wait for a half hour+

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Shopper
content: This thermostat is a beautiful design and functioning triumph. Not only for what it does, but the way we as humans interact with it. A great technology and human focused design. It makes it easy if you want to save energy/money, by tracking your usage, seeing when your system was on, what temperature it was set to, when it was changed. If you like you can have it use its motion sensing capability to determine if you are home or not, and if not, change the thermostat setting to a more energy efficient one... and when it detects you are back home, change it back. If you also have a Nest smoke detector, you can have the motion detecting capability of that to ALSO tell the thermostat if you are home, or not. I understand you can also set up the thermostat to use the location of the cell phone(s) with the Nest App on it to determine if all of them are out of the house, and then change the thermostat setting ( I have this turned off). The phone App is pretty intuitive, clean design, easy to read and control the thermostat when you are in the house or out of the house. When you log into your Nest account on a PC, you see the same thing as the App on your phone and can control the thermostat from there too. Since the thermostat has connection to the internet, it knows (and displays) the temperature outside. Using that and the indoor temperature it learns how long it will take to heat your house to your desired temperature when you increase the thermostat temperature in the winter... and it will show you the minutes it will take. It also measures and displays indoor humidity, accurately, as I have compared it against another humidity gauge. It directly and correctly controls both stages of my two stage furnace. In the app on your phone, or using your PC, you must set up the thermostat to determine if you are home or not (and change the temperature setting) based on motion it detects as you walk by it, and/or motion that your Nest smoke detector detects, and/or cell phones at home or not. I have them all turned off. I programmed a daily schedule that I want the thermostat to follow whether it thinks I’m home or not. Unlike many other reviews who are complaining that the temperature setting keeps changing, I don’t have that problem as I correctly turned off all those motion detection and cell phone detection features, and mine follows the program I set as my humble servant. And if I’m going to me gone for a few hours, I open the App, touch AWAY, and the more energy efficient settings are used. The only thing more I could ask for from a thermostat is that it makes my lunch. Really, really nicely designed product. Worth it.
title: A beautiful piece of technology made simple and useful. Thank you

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: SH
content: My nest thermostat is amazing in the winter. It anticipates my needs and keeps me comfortable 24/7. In the spring and fall, the nest is a terrible product. I spent time building a great custom schedule in the winter. In the spring, every now and then we have a cold morning and I want just a little help getting the house up to temperature so I will change the thermostat from off to 63. The problem is, the nest has no 'Hold' feature. This means come 8am, the schedule kicks in and my house is now auto heated to 70. A few hours later the sun is out and it has warmed up outside and my house is now roasting. All because I wanted to raise the temperature from 58 to 63 several hours earlier. The official solution is to delete your schedule so it will hold temperature. It took time to get my schedule set exactly how I want it. No way I want to go through that again next winter. It seems like a little thing but this really is a critical missing feature. Would be 5 stars if it had hold functionality. 1 star because I really wish I had purchased a different thermostat.
title: Lacking one very very important feature

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Dave M
content: This thermostat has great reviews but I guess I'm the odd one out.  I installed my first one three years ago.  Had to pay to have a third wire run, about a $100.  I installed it at my vacation home and depended on it to check on the temperature during the winter and to turn up the heat the day before if I was going to travel to the house.  Over the three years my boiler system (baseboard water) malfunctioned every year when it got cold.  Numerous visits from the heating company would get it going only to have it stop in a week or two.  I never thought that it was the thermostat.  Over the three years I likely spent another $500 on heating calls.  When it stopped working this year I replaced it with a brand new Nest.  Same problems.  This time I changed back to a regular thermostat, not wifi, and it's worked ever since.  Too bad I didn't replace it sooner.  As for customer support, it was useless.  They just told me to call a heat repairman. My friend who has used a Nest for years has never had a problem.  Maybe it's the kind of heating system I had.
title: Cost me a lot of repair bills

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: R&R
content: You WILL have problems with these. Setup is easy. Pull off the old thermostat and replace wires in the new one. When it works, it works great, however, when you have issues (and you will have issues) you’re done! Call tech support and you’ve just wasted a couple hours of your life you’ll never get back. I’ve been handed off to several “technicians” and they will jack your settings, wires, etc., then pass you off to another “technician”. This company and product is worthless. Read threads on Reddit. I’ve already replaced one and I have another dreaded call to make because of WiFi issues. I have two. One works one doesn’t. Here goes another few hours of my life...
title: Just burn your money

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Mustafa_Jenkins
content: I wish I had done more thorough research before buying this turd of a thermostat. The thermostat is a huge disappointment all in all. From needing google account integration to blatantly reading the temperature wrong by 6 degrees. I’ve reset the damn thing multiple times, scanned for updates reset again and low and behold the stupid thermostat which it’s only 1 job is measuring temperature just can’t do it correctly. If you’re reading this and are between an ecobee or a nest I can safely say you’d be best off with an ecobee as at the moment I’ve re-installed my ancient Honeywell and am selling this POS Nest on eBay for a fraction of what I paid for it.
title: Does not read temperature correctly.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: B. Harris
content: For the first year or so, this thing was awesome. It had some interesting automatic temperature selection, but we loved the ease of use. Now, even though we've had our wiring checked, it doesn't seem to want to charge and it almost always "offline." I have to remove the faceplate from the wall and charge it via USB, and even then it only goes back online for a day or so. It still controls the thermostat, but we cannot access it from our phones nor do we get the connected reports. Edit: bumping this back to 5 stars. Nest support was awesome and helped me try to diagnose the problem. After trying a few fixes, they sent me a new unit without hesitation. Still great!
title: Battery questions...

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: jajabor
content: Nest says you don’t need a C wire but it won’t run without the C wire. I added the C wire. Now it keeps running the AC even after target temp is reached. I have been waking up in the middle of the night to find the house is freezing. Then when I turn the AC off, it doesn’t cut power to the AC unit. So, it keeps running. The only way to turn AC off is from the breaker. Called Nest but they won’t help. My 20 years old thermostat runs fine but this expensive pice of junk doesn’t work.
title: Don’t buy; doesn’t work 100%; horrible tech support

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Paul
content: Worked great for 6 month then I kept getting an e74 error,  (Red wire not getting power)  I would pull out the wire and put it back in and it worked for about 15 min and would stop again.  NEST technician said he that it was a broken HVAC unit or fuse which is not the case as the unit is new and if it were a fuse it would not kick back on each time I pulled the wire and put it back in.  And of course this happens on a Saturday so unless I want to pay a fortune to get someone out on the weekend we will have to sweat it out through the weekend.  Needless to say not impressed  getting an HVAC person out to put back a normal thermostat.
title: Worked great for 6 month then I kept getting an e74 ...

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: JP
content: had to return this. Installed per instructions and still didnt work. Called NEST customer service and had me switch wires around over 10 times..It got annoying because my circuit breaker is down stairs. I lost about 5 pounds that day..Customer service finally told me that maybe I installed unit incorrectly and that I needed to pay more money to get a NEST PRO out there. I said NAh im good and i told them I will just install my old thermostat.. He said it wouldnt work. I hung up on him and installed my old thermostat. Worked perfect. Wish he would have just listen and sent a new unit.
title: It got annoying because my circuit breaker is down stairs

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: njcrafters
content: I really like this thermostat and can’t help but show it off to friends that stop by to visit. Everyone wants to know if Nest is as cool as it looks (it’s probably even better than you expect).  The super sleek design looks great on the wall without drawing needless attention to itself. Nest’s LED display conveniently lights up the dark hallway it sits in when you walk by at night. However, it’s not so bright that I would hesitate to install it in a bedroom (it wouldn’t wake you up). Having the ability to adjust the settings via the phone app or via a web portal is super slick. The fact that it has the ability to automatically switch between heat/cool modes is also very useful in spring/fall, when the weather requires heat in the mornings and AC by afternoon. It also tells you the inside humidity %, which is pretty awesome. Plus, it knows the local weather so it’s always thinking.  There are a number of energy saving features and reports you can utilize as well. One of my favorite features is the ability to synchronize it to your mobile phones. If you choose to set it up, it will adjust the HVAC setting depending if you’re home or not. Yes, if you give it permission, it can detect if your families’ mobile phones are present and adjust the air so you aren’t wasting $. Seriously, how cool is that??? My big question was if the Nest would accept timer settings - or if you were forced to have it “learn” your preferences over time. My wife wasn’t going to indulge my interest in having a smart thermostat if she was going to have to adjust the thermostat for the first few weeks. Fortunately, I was able to set up a schedule during the week and chose to let it “learn” our weekend routine (since I would be home to teach it on weekends). Truthfully, I haven’t really messed with it more than a few times. My wife has little patience for technology when a less complicated/technological solution can perform the same task. Another nice feature I didn’t know I cared about: Nest quickly “learns” your home and will tell you how long till your selected temperature is achieved. I do worry about what happens in 10 years if they decide they are no longer supporting this “older” technology via new phone/app updates, but I guess I’ll worry about that 10 years from now (it will tell me if I am buying another Nest product when it’s time to replace this one). The thermostat unit the Nest replaced was just a builder grade 6-day timer thermostat that fulfilled its purpose. No frills, but it worked pretty good. The Nest tech is flawless and the online-installation tutorial is pretty much idiot proof. If you register it before you install it, it tells you where to connect the exact wires your wall has sticking out of it. It really couldn’t have been easier. I get a bit nervous when I get into these kinds of home repairs, but it is something a novice can do (if you can change a wall switch/plug, this will be no problem). Highly recommend. If you are on the fence about whether to purchase a Nest, I hope my review was able to address some of your concerns.
title: Sleeker and easier than I anticipated

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: P. Hanlon
content: I was super excited to get the Nest. I figured since I’m a tech guy and I want to save money living in Florida where it’s hot most of the time this would be a no brainer! I was sorely mistaken. So upon pulling off my old thermostat I realized that my connections were :1 2 R C this it turns out is not compatible with the nest system. In fact my system is more advanced and nest can’t use the extra wires. The 1 and 2 are communication wires that nest doesn’t have the ability to actually use. I called google tech support and the “techs” were not helpful at all. In fact I seemed more savvy than they were. They just advised me to return my nest or replace my new HVAC system. Right, like I’m going to spend thousands of dollars so I can use a $250 toy basically. Yeah, google you’re out of your mind. Now I’m stuck with something that’s basically a paper weight and I’ve lost a few hundred dollars and my time. Also, unlike many states where they have “furnaces or boilers” I live in Florida where we have A/C systems or HVAC. Apparently google nest techs aren’t savvy about that. If you are going to buy this go ahead and check your system beforehand and save yourself the trouble if it isn’t compatible. I’ll stick with my current AC set up as it allows me to adjust the humidity level and fan speed whereas nest cannot.
title: DID NOT WORK WITH MY HVAC SYSTEM

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Shortordercook
content: One of the advertised features that persuaded us to purchase this thermostat was geofencing.  It is supposed to recognize when my wife and I are both away from home and put the HVAC into Eco mode until we return.  It does this maybe 25% of the time.  Sometimes it will go into Eco mode if I leave and she stays home.  It's not supposed to do that.  We can always activate the Eco mode manually when we leave but geofencing is supposed to do it automatically.  It IS setup properly, by the way.
