product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Stephen K. Richmond
content: If you have zoned heating and cooling do not purchase unless you want to upgrade the control board on your system to be able to use ANY wifi thermostat. After upgrading my control board so I can use the nest on the master Tstat as well as the other 2 Tstats in my home, I was very disappointed. I was expecting more. If you have more than one nest you should be able to control all of them from one interface and not have to click into one nest at a time, also they should communicate with each other to say if I am away then they all turn to away, I shouldn't have to drain my cell battery by leaving the location services on for the nest to know I am out of the house to turn off all of them. Also my first electric bill was $300 bucks up from the normal $150. Why? I'll tell you, one of the Tstats kept coming on while we were at work, instead of noticing the other two were on AWAY. I say all this to say if you want good tech Tstat then go with a Ecobe, if you only have one Tstat in your house then a nest will do, for what you get for the cost isn't worth it. If you have 3 or more Zones in your house you will need to buy a new Control Board and Transformer ($150) and install it yourself in order to use any WiFi Tstat. The only thing cool about nest is its easy to use...turn it one way or the other...If you already have programmable thermostats then you wont save anything by getting a Nest. Program what you already have. Good Luck
title: Nothing Else but Shatty Tstat

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Anna
content: Bought two Nests for dual zone system with the idea of getting smoke detectors and camera and having all items accessible via smartphone app. After automatic update, one thermostat began turning on fan but no heat and showing temperatures 5 degrees off compared to thermometer standing next to it. Opened service ticket with Nest and it said to call them. So, it can be updated online, it stays constantly connected but no troubleshooting online, not even most basic. First thing they asked was photo of wiring of old thermostat, so save those for future reference. Then they proceeded to try different configurations of wires. No answer why it's off on temperature readout. "No, we cannot roll back the update. Shut the circuit breaker and try this combination of wires...".  This lasted about one hour, throwing Hail Marys one after another. I gave up and closed the conversation. Amazon came through, replaced the thermostat by overnighting new one. It works. I am staying put with what I have, hoping it will continue to work. Suffice to say, no more purchases from this company.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Bruce
content: I've just installed the Nest but I've a few observations.  Installation instructions and support were pretty spectacular (e.g., taking a picture of my wiring and getting a Nest wiring diagram back). I recommend you watch the video before installing just so one can see how things will play out. My quibbles: 1) It doesn't support my HVAC's (Trane) external thermometer, 2) So far Amazon's Alexa could only discover Nest under my account but not my wife's (so we have to change to my account to control the thermometer), 3) Alexa will not tell me the current nest temperature (seems a trending issue, not showing/telling the actual temperature), 4) tapping the Nest to set features seems to require a hefty "thunk" rather than a simple tap such as on a smartphone or other touchscreen.  I thought it was broken during installation when I couldn't get past the language selection screen.  I could select my language but could not get Nest to accept the selection and move on - until I hit is a bit hard :-) in frustration. It will be a few days  I imagine until it has completed learning so we'll see how smart it makes it. I feel better with the little nits as I got it at the $199 price ($50 off) and I'm hoping with software updates it will get better.
title: Have to tap it pretty hard to get it to make a selection, Alexa integration so-so, looks nice and seems to do the basics OK

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Rockonport
content: So I checked the website compatibility checker and determined it was compatible with the wiring that my current thermostats (two of them) have. I found out, after installing both of them, that my furnace has a controller (Honeywell HZ311) that isn't compatible without a "common" wire (a wire I didn't have and would require an electrician to run).  Not wanting to pay for an electrician, I reinstalled the old thermostats and am returning these. I only found out about that because when the heat was on and it was only blowing cold air, I went down to see if somehow the furnace (gas furnace) wasn't lit.  Heard a clicking noise and the zone lights were flashing off and on a piece of equipment labeled HZ311.  I then looked that up and found out that it's only compatible if a "common" wire is used, which is what supplies the power to the thermostat. So if you have a thermostat that requires batteries (like the Chronotherm III does) I suggest you do some more investigating before wasting time and money on this.
title: If your current thermostat uses batteries, I'd do more investigation before wasting your time and money.

author: Product Designer k80
content: I am addicted to my Nest Thermostat! I love seeing when/how I am saving energy through the app on my phone. The nest is so smart and knows when I'm home or when I'm away. I had my dad working from my house one day while I was at work and I could even check in and see how hot he turned it up (those old people like to keep the house like a sauna). I also love how beautiful the product itself is. It is engaging and rewarding to use. I love the interface and noises it makes. I also love how it's motion detecting. Overall great design.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: SeattleDadReviews
content: I bought a Nest thermostat, partly to learn about it from a professional standpoint, and partly because I was excited to try it out. People are raving about them. Bottom line: after several days of trying it out and setting it up, I got so angry at it that I took it off the wall, put back the ancient one that it was replacing, boxed it up, and I'm returning it. I *never* return *anything*, so this is notable. The thing that's wrong with Nest is that it isn't very good at its basic function: being a thermostat. There are two things that it should do: Determine the temperature in the room, and the desired temperature, and try to make the room be the desired temperature. Turn the furnace on and off. On the first point, yes, it kind of does that, but it doesn't show you the current temperature in the room -- only the desired temperature.  It knows the current temperature in the room, right? And every other thermostat on the market shows you both temperatures, right? So why is it that there is literally no way to see the current temperature in the room?  The only answer I can think of is: "design".  We didn't want to mess up the beautiful display by showing you two numbers because that would look bad.  Right.  Good decision. On the second point, turning the furnace on/off, the brand-new 3rd Generation Nest with a fresh software update ... fails miserably. The furnace runs for a while, then I think when the room temperature is just about the desired temperature, it starts to cycle the furnace on/off every 3- 4seconds, for quite a number of minutes. As a programmer, I'm pretty sure this is because the temperature sensor is not quite accurate enough, so when it's on the line between 68 and 69, let's say, it flips back and forth (maybe the temperature is 68.5643 and it rounds off to 68 then to 69 then back to 68 as the temperature fluctuates 0.001 degrees. This is so basic to the functionality of a thermostat that they probably have internal brown-bag lunches on this topic at Honeywell, when you join the thermostat engineering group. Except they don't seem to  have thermostat engineers at Nest, just "user experience designers." Fail. Okay, it sucks at being a thermostat, but isn't it awesome as an Internet of Things poster child? Sort of. The app is nice, and it does show remote status pretty well, and remote control (except for that part about "what temperature is the room, anyway?). But it's focused on saving energy, which is great, but it is not very focused on making me warm on a cold day, which is the other reason for having a thermostat. Auto-Away Nest has a feature they call Auto-Away, which uses the built-in motion sensor to decide whether or not you're home (a pretty good idea) and turns the furnace down when you're not around. This would be great, except for WHEN YOU ARE HOME, and just NOT IN FRONT OF THE THERMOSTAT. Motion detector delays are pretty standard, right? Like your motion detector light fixture on your front porch. There's a switch on there to decide how long a delay you want. Nest's Auto-Away feature has exactly one control: ON or OFF.  That's it.  You can't set the delay for how often you walk by the thermostat. It seems to have a really short one, like 10 minutes, after which it decides you aren't home and TURNS DOWN THE HEAT.  That is so completely not helpful, on a cold day. When you find yourself getting out of your chair many times during a day and walking into the room with the thermostat in it and waving your arms, to try to make the heat go back on, you start to realize that the product is badly designed and implemented. Which brings me to the last feature, the ability to control the furnace from someplace else. This is totally great, and works well.  AND YOU NEED IT, becuase you have to turn Auto-Away off, because it sucks and that's your only choice (ON or OFF). But if Auto-Away is off, then you have to turn it off remotely if you are Away, and forgot to turn the heat down. Fail.  Epic fail, all in all, because it has all the ingredients of being awesome, but absolutely sucks at doing its basic job.
title: DO NOT BUY NEST!! FAIR WARNING NOW!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Cali Weekes
content: I love having this! I never saw all the hype before, but with the black Friday sales, decided to just do it. I am so glad I did! I love that it knows when we are not home, and will adjust acordingly. I can even set up how I want it to react when I leave. How low is too low in the winter, and how hot is too hot in the summer. (we have a pet, so I like that I can let it get a little colder or warmer, but not so cold that our sweet kitten is uncomfortable) It syncs to your phone, so when your phone is more than a couple of miles away for more than an hour or so, it adjusts to the energy saving mode. As soon as your phone pops into that radius - it kicks on to get the house back to where you want it to be. It also has a motion sensor, so if my phone is gone, but the kids are home, it knows to not kick into energy saving mode. I love the fact I can control it from my phone period! One night we got stuck in a snow storm, and it was down in low energy mode. We had to stay the night elsewhere, so I bumped the heat up a notch or two for our kitten to stay warm. (she is spoiled I guess) It can read the weather forecast, so if its colder or warmer than usual, it can adjust accordingly. It gives me a monthly update too on how I did on energy, and how I compared to those around me. It gives us helpful hints on how to run the fan system - without actually running the AC or furnace. This rotates the already warm/cool air without using more energy from those. It can kick the fan on manually or I can set it up to do it automatically. Things I never thought of! I got it in the winter, so I have not had a lot of time to experience the summer months of AC, but I have noticed looking at the readings on my energy bills that the usage has gone down. It helps me be more mindful, and give me tips to save. Just the fact that it knows when we are gone and can turn down, is amazing. No one sets their furnace schedule when they are leaving for a few hours or a quick weekend get away - they leave it alone or turn it off which can cost more in the long run to warm a freezing house back up! This allows us to do that - with no fuss! If you are looking to get - check with your local power and gas company first for rebates. I did this, and got $100 from my power company and $50 from my gas company. I only paid $170 on black Friday - so this thing literally cost me $20. I have easily saved that much in my lowered usage bills. Install was a breeze. My husband had it done in about 10 minutes. He watched a youtube video on it for good measure, but I think he already knew just from the directions what to do. He even said "it cant be this easy - I must be missing something" so that's why he watched the video. And it was right, it was so easy! You match color wire to color slot. Done.
title: Can't say enough good things! LOVE IT! Read the whole post to see how you can get it for almost free like I did!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Glenn Elmore
content: I bought the NEST after returning a Honeywell Lyric that had serious problems connecting to my home network.Others have reported similar experiences with Honeywell .  I'm an electrical engineer and also have more than 20 years of networking and TCP/IP experience. I have a great variety of connected devices on my multiple home networks. NEST was supposed to be not only a great smart thermostat but also easy to configure. Boy was this ever not so! I have a dual-zone single/single stage gas-heat/electric cool Amana system. The controller is an Amana ZCST2A with a master thermostat downstairs and a secondary 'stat upstairs.  When the NEST didn't immediately power up after install, I suspected it was going to need a common power wire but didn't try to figure it all out, instead I went directly to NEST chat suppor.  This 'chat' lasted almost 5 hours! It started with them checking compatibility of my existing hardware and promising me that NEST was 'completely compatible' with it. Then the 'fun' began.  I promise, I did not try to outsmart or second-guess them, I only acted as arms, eyes and photographer all along the way. He kept thanking me for being so helpful and providing information he wanted even before he asked. After a couple of hours, the rep, who was very nice, constantly thanking me and writing "we'll get this" and "I've got your  back" called in his Senior Technical supervisor. The two of them worked for another 2-3 hours with me making changes and reporting/returning results as they asked for it. All along I was led along with "almost there" sorts of responses. Finally, around 5PM my time (PST) they threw their hands up and said that they had come to the end of their troubleshooting ability and that this was beyond the ability of their chat support. They directed me to a web link that gave local for-pay HVAC services and told me that those guys "eat these kinds of problems for lunch" and are "surprisingly" reasonable. I am now continuing that path. I do want a smart thermostat and I suspect that it truly is possible to make all this work. I have sympathy that Amana may not have made it easy for them since a multi-zone, multi-stat heat/cool system is not necessarily trivial  BUT that's the problem that NEST is supposed to solve and the one they repeatedly claimed they would solve! All in all I wasted the better part of a day and would have been better off to simply call and pay for local services to begin with. I would probably not have missed my nap that way either! I will edit this response or often a new opinion if circumstances change and this is merited. For the moment, I have a hard time recommending this product/service to *anyone* with a system that is much larger or more complicated than Heat:on/off.  I like the possibility of a learning stat with geofencing and the hope of saving on heating/cooling bills but at present this product and support organization does not seem to provide it for me. I hope that this changes! [Edit, added after local NEST expert visit] I had a very productive visit from the local expert. After giving him the complete history, he carefully considered it and said "You've done everything I would have"  he then called a peer who has particular NEST experience and received the advice, paraphrased "The Amana ZCST zone board is NOT COMPATIBLE with NEST. Not cost effective to try to install a smart thermostat." I greatly appreciate this result and can only wish that the NEST website plus almost 5 hours of time on the phone with NEST chat hadn't been WASTED due to their ineptitude.  I can take "it won't work with your system", some things are like that. But leading me on and on profits nobody. Incidentally, Ecobee says they can't do it either and recommended a different zone board ($150) in case anybody else has this exact problem. I'm left with Honeywell Lyric being the only possibility but I'm not going there after having tried it, seen the network problems (fixable by workaround at least) and poor quality app. Wasted time for me and no Smart Thermostat. NEST support 0, local help(plural) 10, Ecobee3 support 10. Phooey on NEST!
title: NEST chat support wasted 4.5 hours of my day! Can't recommend

author: Dan C.
content: I never thought I'd be excited about a thermostat. It looks really, really nice, it has a great feel, very solid. If you want to manually create a schedule, no problem, otherwise in the first week of using it it will figure out your habits and change accordingly. Installation was simple, the mounting plate even has a level on it so you get it straight. There were 2 unexpected quirks, both related to low battery on arrival and both cleared up in 1-2 days: (1) when I first mounted it on the wall and it started to power up the first time, it went into an automatic power save mode because the battery was too low, you can either wait and it will come back up eventually, or you can charge it via micro-USB; (2) once there was enough battery for it to be usable, the battery still had to further charge before it would start up wifi and connect to my home network. All of this was resolved after the unit fully charged after 1-2 days.

content: **Updated review: Hooked it up again on a whim and it's working like a charm. I have no idea what happened the first time but now I'm a happy customer. I loved the idea of this. I checked for compatibility, installed it, installed the app, and all seemed fine. Then it wouldn't cool. The house got up to 84 degrees and no matter how much I spun the dang thing, it wouldn't work. Finally for some reason it started cooling. It got so cold, condensation started forming on my vents. I didn't dare stop it. The next day the same thing happened, only this time nothing I did got it to cool down. We spent hours, the house was well over 90 degrees. We ended up taking the nest off and reinstalling the old thermostat. If I find the time to try again and it works, I will gladly update my rating. Here's hoping.
title: Worked sporadically until the house hit 90 degrees - then gave up.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: D Money 24
content: I am very disappointed with this thermostat, first off installation is ridiculous... This was my 3rd thermostat I have installed and the hardest yet, the wires didn't match with what I had in the wall previously so I called the support line and they had me switch a few (this was just to get the unit connected and turned on) so now that I had power I hung up and proceeded to test the unit well.... It blew cold air when it was on heat then blew hot hair when it was on cool, back on the phone with support, this girl was less than useless it seemed like I was bothering her by calling, she would have me change a wire and each time I would have to run to the breaker shut off the power then rewire it, test it to see it failed then run back to the breaker and try again (thermostat on 22nd floor and breaker outside) in the end the girls recommendation was to switch the heating wire and the cooling wire... This ended up not solving the problem because the condensor wouldn't run and push the cold air when it was on cool, at this point I was so annoyed with the girl putting me on mute and taking forever to respond once I had completed a step I hung up and found the answer on Reddit... I basically had to rig the system to think I had a heat pump (which I do not I live in AZ) so now the thermostat is finally running my system properly.... Now comes the annoying dumb smart tech, the system is PREset with a schedule and that would cause it to randomly set to a temperature I did not select and then heat my home up way too much, this I only realized while I was working and started sweating because I went up 3 degrees before I finally realized what it had done... Once I deleted it's preset schedule I thought I was in the clear, that was until the system suddenly decided I was away and kicked into another preset thing that changed the temperature on its on and stopped heating even though I was home (i work from home and rarely leave during the day) this was another setting I had to look for and disable since it was not working properly... All in all I am extremely disappointed with this thermostat and I feel like I paid $200 for the ability to change the temperature from my phone, I do not recommend this product for anyone that works from home, might be better if you are away a lot and want to setup A schedule to have your system run automatically when you are away, just hope you never have to call tech support because you will be disappointed too
title: Very dumb smart tech

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Thomas B. Greenman
content: I'm going to ask you a series of questions and if you answer YES, go ahead and buy a Nest.  Let's begin: 1) Do you hate getting out of bed to adjust the temperature? 2) Are you not really sure what your thermostat is doing? 3) Do you want to save money? 4) Is your thermostat a dumb one? 5) Do you want your house to be at the perfect temp when you get home? All of the above were very relevant needs for me.  I live in Alaska and have a 1500 square foot house with radiant base board heating.  When we bought the house we got a gas powered hot water on demand heating system that ended up cutting our gas bill in half (down to $60 a month from $130) during colder months.  However, our existing thermostat had a week and weekend schedule and that's about it.  I'd heard of the Nest thermostat and wanted to be more energy efficient but also take advantage of new smart technologies. There are two versions, 2nd Gen and 3rd Gen.  I'm not sure on the differences but I can tell you that being a tech guy, get the latest gen.  That way you are upgrading when you see a feature you want but it's not in the last gen.  I got the 3rd gen of course. The Nest was easy to install, just pop the box off your thermostat (no worries, it's easy and it won't break it) and take a picture of your wires - take note of the labels on them.  Go to the Nest site and use their configurator and put in the wires.  The site will email you back exactly where to place these during install.  Unhook the wires and remove your old thermostat (be sure to cut the power off to your furnace/HVAC device before doing so *very important*).  Simply mount the bracket (if you want) and screw in the wiring harness.  Plug up the wires according to your diagram and pop the Nest unit onto it.  That's it.  The hard part is done! Programming is really easy although I recommend doing most of it from the app/website.  Although it can be done easily enough on the device. Once it's all been setup and scheduled, you can tailor it to your needs but don't worry, it learns you and your routines very well.  Once it's all said and done, you can see what you are actually using in energy per day (which amounts to savings you can actually see).  For me, radiant/baseboard heating needs a Nest.  This type of heating tends to overshoot the heat setting.  So it you set a regular thermostat to 72, your heater will shut off at 72 but the hotwater's radiant heat will cause it to overshoot, possibly taking it up to an addition 5 degrees or more over time.  This is a waste of energy and it's a frustration to those who aren't sure why they can't ever seem to "get it right" with the temp.  Those married couples will know what I'm talking about.  With Nest, it will learn how much heat is enough to get it to your desired temp.  It will also tell you how much time it will take to get there (no need to just crank it - just let it do it's thing). Since it's smart, it also knows the outside temp and can predict what kind of  time it will take to warm up your house or if it even needs to.  But one of it's "just paid for itself" features is the text message you'll get if and when it drops below a certain set temp and the furnace/HVAC isn't responding so that way your pipes don't burst or your pets aren't adversely affected. I'm also a big fan of the auto-sense feature that knows when we are home and when we are not.  On the weekends, we have our schedule running most of the day at a higher temperature but if we are gone for a while, the system will go down to a much lower temp to save money.  Now that's smart! I just ordered the Nest Protect smoke/carbon monoxide detector but that's another review.
title: My Nest Adventure

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1

content: Love this product so much I purchased for each thermostat in my home. Easy to install even if you are not handy. I did have problem with one and the customer service was great. A replacement was sent out immediately. Wish all electronic devices offered this kind of customer service.

author: Adam Fernandez
content: This isn't the first Nest product that I've owned (I have Dropcams and a Protect), and once again, I'm beyond impressed by the product! Everyone that's walked into my house has been wowed by the thermostat's design and simplicity. I also love how it ties in with the other pieces of my smart house: for instance, when I lock my door, my cameras turn on, and my thermometer drops the temperature to save money. All in all, great job Nest! I can't wait to see the products you release in the future, IoT really has the potential to change the way we live!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Hugh Mclaughlin
content: The Nest Learning Thermostat is over-rated.  In theory it is great, in practice, not so great.  We lose connection to it from time to time and when things don't work the online support is not so clear.  I am very experienced with tech stuff and and electrical engineer, so it is not that I am an idiot.  It has a sensor to detect activity in the house, but the nest is in a hallway that is not used so much, so if nobody has walked down that hallway in a day it thinks we are away.  Sometimes we are home and wtf, the it is so cold and we check the thermostat and it thinks we are away.  We know people who think the nest is great, but at this point I would rather have an old-fashioned thermostat.  When we leave for the day I would be happy with simply setting the temperature low manually.  A thermostat that is simpler, but with a more intelligent away sensor would be better.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: The Truth May Hurt
content: My initial response and review was excellent. The nest looked great and seemed to perform well. Since then I’ve read many reviews from lots of HVAC professionals, all who believe the nest doesn’t play nice with your HVAC. My issue specifically is the battery and software interface. The 3rd Gen Nest is designed with an internal battery. This was done so to allow it to “work” with an HVAC wiring system that doesn’t have a c-wire/constant 24v power input. This wiring seems common with older HVAC systems. Charging the battery without a C-Wire release on the fan and system to run as it trickle charges the battery. This issue comes apparent when good weather arrives and you run your heat or A/C little to none over several days. The nest without the C-Wire relies on the internal battery to maintain the system settings and WiFi accessibility. Over these few days the battery will discharge completely. Nest recommends you remove the faceplate and charge with a micro-USB. This is annoying. To “restore” the charge the Nest software will power down the thermostat. Now your Nest will not turn on when the critical temperature is reached. This will result in your house being too hot or cold, depending on the season, until you force the unit to power on. After you tell it to heat or cool then it will force power down to charge the low battery. This cycle continues over and over. I have exhausted the internet and there is no video or battery exchange recommended by Nest. My battery (unit purchased in April 2017) is completely drained and can not be resuscitated with a micro-USB charge or with the C-Wire. I have contacted Nest and because I purchase through Amazon they refer me to Amazon for warranty and support. I have not received correspondence from Amazon. Eight months for a $250 thermostat. No thanks. You can just purchase a programmable unit, save $150, and adjust the temperature and save more money, let alone stress. I will not recommend the Nest to anyone.
title: Don’t buy Nest. Battery issues!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Maureen Fink
content: Was delivered earlier than I expected. Installation was very straightforward. We did watch a video on youtube first and it seemed easy and it was easy, My system is two different kinds. One for heat and one for a/c. My heat is oil baseboard and the a/c was put in at a later date so they use different thermostats. I would of preferred to use it on the heat one but it wasn't compatible with my system. At least this model wasn't. The web has any help you might need. Even a version checker to see if the Nest will work with you system. The app installed great on my iphone but on my kindle fire I kept receiving an error msg. Back to installing, it was straight forward and easier than any other thermostat I've installed. I love that it has a built in level and it has a couple different wall plates that you can choose from. The only item not included were screw dowels. Which I personally recommend as the device has some weight to it.  It even comes with its own reversible screw driver. Thirty minutes start to finish. Even if you're not mechanical you could install this. I'm going to check and see if a different model will work with my furnace. I love the display, it can be set to motion activate so as you approach it shows you the temperature. It can be adjusted manually or via the web or app. So far it seems to cover everything from setting schedules to being away. Very impressed and so is my husband who usually doesn't like technology.
title: Very impressed

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: J Howland
content: Nest thermostats are the nuts.  Takes about 10-15 minutes to install.  If you can build a lego set or watch a YouTube video and repeat the steps you can install a Nest thermostat in minutes.  Beyond the mind blowing simplicity, the Nest is simply the best thermostat you can buy.  It's more expensive than your regular thermostat, but like many things you get what you pay for. The wireless connectivity is more than a gimic.  You can turn the temperature down from literally anywhere you have internet access.  Want to come home to a cool house from work.  Boom, set it to cool before you leave.  Come home to a comfy house.  Want to make it cooler without getting out of bed.  No problem. The Nest also learns your behaviors.  So far it's been spot on.  It knows when I'm home and what times of the day to cool more than others.  I also really love the auto-away functionality.  When you're out of the house you can set Nest to keep it relatively warm to conserve energy.  In my first 6 weeks, it's been 100% accurate. Energy efficiency is where the Nest really shines.  Because it regulates cooling based on when you need it and you can set it to be more efficient when you aren't home the amount of energy used goes way down.  I saved roughly 20% on my electric bill in the first month.  And many energy companies will offset some of the initial costs of purchase by registering Nest with them.  For me it was a win-win.  I'd buy Nest again and again if needed.
title: Who knew we had thermostat technology wrong this whole time.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Maria M.
content: I am so impressed with this thermostat and it has only been a day since my husband and I have installed it. I will be updating my review after a month or so of usage since this is a habit learning thermostat and will take some time to truly see the benefits of this new purchase. Our first impression of this thermostat out of the box was a big "wow". It is heavy.... in a good way though. You can definitely tell that this isn't just a cheaply made plastic thermostat. The design is very sleek and very modern. The box included items such as a a little screws, an electrical box mounting cover (optional piece), a trim plate (optional piece), a mini screw driver, and of course the instruction manuals that include label stickers for the wires to keep everything organized during installation. Installation was so easy that it was almost unbelievable. Mounting, connecting the wires, WiFi setup, account creation, mobile app download, and connecting the app with the nest took us less than 20 minutes. there where absolutely no issues or confusion during installation. We have previously owned a Honeywell smart thermostat that works with Vera, and setting up that thing was a nightmare and took us multiple hours and phone calls to their support department. There is just no comparison when it comes to the installation. Another plus, is that screen of the nest when lit up looks awesome. However, you can adjust the brightness for those that are looking for a more discrete look. Furthermore, using the app is very intuitive and straight forward. So far I'm loving it! I also really like the fact that the nest is compatible with a lot of different "smart" products. I am posting a picture of what the nest looks like after installation. Since our house is under major renovations, we used the trim plate to cover up some wholes and also we did not screw the nest firmly against the wall since we will be changing it's location in the near future.
title: First impression: It's a winner!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Mereseydotes
content: I'm very reliant on my AC and I was tired of worrying about the cost of leaving it on all day, but then also coming home to a stifling hot house. So I decided to give this thermostat a try, so I could turn on the AC remotely before I get home. I was terrified to install it. I knew that, if I broke anything, it would be days before I could get someone out to fix it. But I also didn't want to wait days to get someone out to install it. It was actually pretty easy to install. There was a little hiccup during setup, because the ring was being really sensitive and choosing the incorrect network. I called tech support and the man I spoke with (who picked up quickly) was very patient and helpful, though it was already working by then. Then, I went to turn on the AC and it started blowing hot air! I thought I was going to die. I called tech support again, this time panicking, and spoke with another gentleman who was again, patient and helpful. I thought we got the problem resolved, and hung up. It turned out that it was only blowing outside air, not cold air. So, I called tech support again, this time almost having a panic attack. I spoke with the first gentleman again. He was, again, very patient and helpful, even though I was acting pretty crazy by this time. Word to the wise - if you have a heat pump, the white wire that was formerly in the W slot might just want to go in the OB slot, because, of course. Also, this thing is pretty neat.
title: Top notch tech support!

Basically during my initial set up I had set it up to run on 5Ghz wifi band.. Since the router is one room over it didn't get a good signal and caused numerous problems. Once I realized that was the issue and switched over to 2.4 Ghz band I have not had a single problem since.
title: Great product - use 2.4Ghz WiFi band

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Tommaync
content: I purchased the bronze look thermostat which looks very classy on my wall.  It's a very attractive looking device.  I installed it yesterday (1/4/18) and installation went well.  Instructions were good, guiding me step by step.  Once installed hooking it up to the Nest app on my phone was very easy.  It walked me through each step.  Connecting it to Alexa also went very smoothly.  I like the ease in checking settings, energy usage as well temperature, humidity levels.  Adjusting temp is very easy by simply turning the outer ring. Everything can be done on the actual thermostat by simply turning the outer ring and pressing the lens cover on the front.  The thermostat will learn how I like my home temps adjusted over the next few days and eventually will automatically adjust temps.  but I can also adjust it or set my own schedules if desired.  Today when I left for work I turned the temp down.  Before I left work to go home I opened my Alexa app on my phone and reset the temp to a warmer setting.  By the time I got home the temperature had risen to the warmer setting so the house was warm when I walked in.  It also has the ability to automatically adjust temps up/down whenever you leave your home or return by sensing the location of your phone.  It's only been 24 hours since I turned it on but I have been very pleased with its operation.
title: A Nest Energy Saving Connected Thermostat for your Nest

content: Tons of cool features and very easy to install and use.  However, if you're going to be at home for a week, there's no manual override on it.  You have to either readjust the thermostat every single time it changes itself or go in and manually edit the program for the week you're going to be home, then manually edit it back when you go back to your normal schedule.  It's weird that such an advanced thermostat lacks something so basic.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Robert W. Hedge II
content: I'm writing this review early, solely based on the ease of installation. I am no electrician, nor an expert handyman. Out of box to operating in less than 30 min. No bull! Using the online compatibility tool, I was able to determine which wires go where on my old thermostat. You can also determine whether it will even be compatible at all (I guess for some certain units) Nest sends you a wiring diagram based on your current wiring (provided it was done right in the first place). You label your wires where they are currently with provided stickers, turn off power to the furnace/ AC, disconnect current thermostat then attach mounting plate to wall. Easy. Then you place wires into new circuit plate provided, matching labelled wires to the corresponding labelled place in circuit plate. Once this is done, snap control into place, turn breaker back on and easily set up your Nest with given prompts at control. Easily connects to your Wifi, then you have full control and monitoring from your mobile device or computer. Can't wait to see how this learns my habits and works to save me money on heating and cooling. I can already tell an improvement in comfort after first two days. They say it takes a week or so before it really starts learning your habits, so that will be less fooling around with it. Just fun to play with and monitor for now. I can see why Nest is very highly awarded and I really want to integrate more to the system. I have already integrated a Nest Protect to it for smoke/ CO detection.
title: The start of my fully automated home.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: WPDjr
content: The packaging was extraordinary; EVERYTHING one needs to install it is included.  The thermostat itself "feels" like it is made of quality materials.  I appreciated the compatibility tool on the Nest website so I could make sure my system was compatible.  Installation was very straight-forward and simple; the online video is a great help, too.  Programming/Learning and tweaking it took a little getting used to (the first night, I woke up hot because it adjusted the temp because it sensed no one was home).  But, learning new technology to customize to one's preferences does require a learning curve; I've now gotten it set-up exactly as I wanted.  The Home/Away Assist sensor on the thermostat is super sensitive; my ceiling fans were causing it to think someone was home even though I/my phone was physically miles away from home.  So, the Tech Support chat advisor had me disable the occupancy sensor on the thermostat (through the app), and that fixed the issue.  I can already tell my system is working less (while still keeping me very comfortable) and am looking forward to reduced power bills for the foreseeable future.
title: Excellent Product

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Michael the II
content: After 10 months of use Nest started to turn on the AC compressor and force shut off air circulation fan. The result? You get a few hundred dollar bill for 12+ hours of AC compressor runs a day. I got lucky the AC compressor did not get damaged from frost buildup as people write on forums. I installed my old thermostat and all works normal again. I rent 2 houses and one uses Honeywell basic $100 WiFi control thermostat, and my other house uses the stupid "smart" Nest. I have no idea what renters do with Nest or if there are power spikes or anything else weird- all I know is that the houses are 3 miles apart and there are no problems with Honeywell at all.  NEST with its retarded auto-schedules waking me up in winter at 5AM because nest decided to stop heating in the middle of the night (consistently day by day, and the smart thing would not learn.) That was just hard to comprehend and bothersome but not a showstopper. But, opening a Pacific Gas and Electric company's bill for useless AC work in the hundreds that's a mess. I contacted Nest support always there for you via chat. After chatting for 2.5 hours combined and trying disconnecting this wire and that wire, and wiring I was told I need that new plastic ring where I plug the wires into. To my surprise they sent me a stupid all plastic rectangular decorative wall plate that does not come in contact with any wires... Next half hour of chatting they told me to forget about plastic plate and re-set the Nest.  Even if the nest starts to work- how would I know it's not gonna go into its madness spiral cycle of shutting the fan off??? The bottom line is: if you like to take risks and is by that Nest every day- you might gamble on it. If you need a WiFi in a rental house- don't do it to yourself! It will waste both your time and money (so don't buy into Nest promises of saving you dough!).
title: The stupid smart thermostat

author: Mark Murphy
content: Absolutely love it. One of the best purchased (having just bought a house) and was pretty easy for a novice like me to install. product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Eric Whited
content: Just received my Nest 3rd Gen.  I have had the device installed for 2 days, so I have zero data on the efficiency of the device.  I have a Trane Heat pump and previously had a Honeywell 7 day programable thermostat programed so well that my heat/cooling bill only fluctuated about $10-$20/mo in peak winter/summer months (Kansas City, MO), so I am looking forward to compare.  I will say that I took a huge risk trying to get this thing hooked up with my Heat Pump System.  Turns out I was lucky and everything is functioning, I've attached the picture of my wires before, and will do my best to explain my situation (disclaimer: it may not work for you, hire a pro) I had the following wires in my Honeywell: E-White  (Emergeny Heat) S1-Blue (Sensor) S2-Brown (Sensor) R-Red 0/B-Orange (Heat Pump) Y-Yellow G-Green (Fan) Here is where those Wires are in my Nest Gen 3 E-White to Nest * (Emergeny Heat) S1-Blue to Nest C (Sensor) but rewired the Blue Wire from the sensor to the C terminal on my furness S2-Brown not used capped and tucked into wall (Sensor) R-Red to Nest RH 0/B-Orange to Nest 0/B (Heat Pump) Y-Yellow to Nest Y1 G-Green to Nest G (Fan) Pro: -It's attractive on the wall, my wife likes it, but it also scares her enough I don't think she'll touch it (Win!).  I did set up her phone with a Nest Account and the app, so she can adjust if she feels the need to. -It seems future proof. Already looking at adding some "Works with Nest" devices. -Programming was easy (wish there was some presets/examples to work from) If you see the Leaf on the app or nest while programing it means it's still in the Eco range. Cons: -I have a heat-pump and took a chance on the wiring, required me to take one of the sensor wires not being used anymore (nest pulls outside temperature data from the cloud, not the sensor like old system did), and rewire it to create a common wire connection on the furness control panel (C= low voltage wire to power the device). -No way of knowing if it's any better than what I already had.  I'll update once I collect some data. -Price, but mine was free with energy program hosted by my utilities provider.
title: Have Heat-Pump?...Consider Hiring a Pro

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: LOST
content: I absolutely love this thermostat, and plan to purchase another.  The only reason for not  earning a 5 star rating, are the vague instructions for installation and operation.  After 2 hours of frustration, including researching the website,  I called the tech support and they immediately stated that my problem was a common problem and I had to move a wire from the location the instructions outlined.  If it is a common problem, why not include this information as a part of the instructions?  After trial and error and talking with the support tech, I learned pushing the ring or the face performed the same function, also not documented, including the website.  I would definitely recommend NEST, again, we love the convenience and learning technology.  We plan to buy another for second thermostat, installation should be a cinch!
title: I absolutely love this thermostat

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: RJ
content: I been contemplating to get the nest for a while now, and finally took the plunge this black Friday since it was on sale.  It looks great and the functionally to be able to manage it while I'm away is definitely useful.  However its main functionally is to manage the home's heating and cooling and I dont think it does a great job at this. Based on the research I done one way the nest saves money is by delaying when it turns on the heat/AC and you may end up with 1 or 2 degrees fluctuation at times.  For some reason for us the difference was about 6 degrees difference in heat.  Because we have a 3 month old baby and still needs frequent diaper changes, we like to keep the house fairly warm and we set it to 75 and turn off the auto away feature.  At night the temperature was dropping to about 69 and nest was still not triggering the furnace to turn on. I understand one of the purpose of the nest is to help save money but If its at the cost of been uncomfortable in your own home then I rather go back to my old thermostat which actually does what it needs to do and that is maintain the home at a comfortable level.  We needed to resort to keep turning the dial off and back on several times through out the night to trigger the furnace to turn on.  I even set a nightly schedule, but that only helped a little bit.  Their engineers need to fix their algorithm. I ended up having to manage this expensive "smart" thermostat more than I had to manage my $40 programmable thermostat.  So for that reason I ended up returning the nest,  I will try the ecobee3 and see how that goes.
title: it favors efficiency over comfort

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Eric Rosenberry
content: I have installed these now in several homes (mine, my in-laws, etc...) They are a fantastic example of how "Internet of Things" is going to change our lives. Computers are much better at coming up with a heating/cooling schedule than we are, and they never forget to re-program themselves when life patterns change. If the US Government wanted to *actually* make a huge dent in energy usage in this country they should do a deal with Google to give every household in the USA a free Nest thermostat. Now, while I am still giving the Nest five stars because it is overall awesome, I will share three negatives: 1. The upstairs of my house is *much* hotter in the summer than the downstairs where the thermostat is.  The Nest desperately needs remote sensors you can add like competitors have. 2. After I installed my in-laws unit they swear it reads "higher" temps than the room actually is.  After much testing and discussion with Nest, I think the reason is a vent that runs through the wall behind the thermostat.  Previous thermostats in the exact same location did not have the issue.  I think the problem is that the Nest is much more tightly coupled to the wall than the old ones and the thermostat element may actually be in the base ring if I remember correctly.  They are trying to keep it away from the heat producing components in the Nest like the CPU and the display so they bury it farther back.  I wish there was a way to adjust the displayed temp by a degree or two to compensate for this perhaps. 3. They need to come up with ways to better control new more modern multi-stage systems and variable speed fans/compressors.  One advantage the manufacturer thermostats have is that they often communicate using serial and they can very precisely set fan speeds, etc...  This world is evolving and I feel like since their Google Acquisition they have not innovated as fast as before. -Eric
title: I love Nest thermostats!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: J. Bitney
content: The Nest is something that I wish we had purchased sooner. I love being able to set it for a range of temps, rather than having use one temp for the summer and another for the winter. Being able to monitor our home's temp while we are on our three-week vacation in the winter makes it much easier to relax while we're away, as we can see the temp while we are gone and call or message someone if we need to have it checked. The controls are very intuitive, and it is very attractive rather than industrial. We had first seen it in a newly-remodeled bar and grill while on a vacation, and I was impressed enough to ask the owner what it was and how it worked. I then began researching that type of thermostat, spending several months reading articles and reviews and eliminating certain brands. The Nest seemed to stand out from the crowd, and when I found out that our daughter -- who owns rentals and pinches pennies like no other -- had bought one, I know that I was on the right track. It was easy to install, so easy that I wondered if it could be right because I assumed that something which does so much must be harder to install than it was. The one of the best features of the Nest will work only if you have wireless, so if you don't have wireless, you won't be able to monitor it while you are away. We use the WeatherBug app (iOS and Android) for weather, and it works with Nest to help us to monitor both the interior and exterior temps.  It shows us how much money we would be saving or wasting monthly and annually by using various interior temps, allowing us to change the temp in a section called "Thermostat vs Cost" without actually adjusting the Nest. It also has a section called "Energy Meter", and shows what today's cost will likely be based upon the predicted weather that day and with our Nest current temp setting. I would certainly buy this Nest again and tell people about it on a regular basis.
title: The best ever!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: M Star
content: First of all, it's so sexy! Beautiful thermostat, super easy to use, and to install if you avoid some of my pitfalls. They even provide you with a screwdriver, labeling stickers and super easy online installation video as well as install booklet! So here are my pitfalls. I turned off the A/C breaker, but not the furnace breaker. Mine wasn't labeled, so I thought they were one and the same. But Nest self diagnoses, so I was able to figure out that my red wire wasn't getting connected properly. Nest has incredible customer service. Online was very easy to use to trouble shoot and when that failed, on the phone  (and there wasn't really a wait to get a real person!) the rep was super nice, very helpful, walked me through everything and when that didn't work they paid for a technician to come out and diagnose the issue. I was blown away! To make the story short, when I didn't shut off the furnace breaker, I shorted a fuse in the furnace and nothing I was going to do was going to fix it to get my HVAC going again. The Nest  approved technician that came out fixed it in a jiffy and was also pretty awesome. Now I have an awesome working system! Can connect from my phone, net, senses when I am home, learns, and will hopefully save me some $!
title: Beautiful thermostat, super easy to use

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: James Sadler
content: I bought a new place and one of the first things on my to-do list was to replace the old and basic programmable thermostat with something "smart." My friend has a comparable Honeywell model which he loves, but I went with the Nest since it will hook up to more "smart" home components once those mature a little more. Also there was a black friday deal so it was at the same price point as some of the cheaper competitors. I really like the design as it reminds me of those old school thermostats with the rotary setting. The UI and is pretty straight forward and once everything is setup there really isn't much need to dive into it. Installation was easy since I was just replacing an existing system, that already had the wires labeled. The wires just clip into spring loaded clips. I wondered if I had them in far enough, but they just go in until the wire stops, so it is pretty easy. Since I was replacing an older, rectangular model, I used the provided base plate to cover up the area that hadn't been painted behind it. The installation looks clean. Setup/sync with the phone was pretty straight forward. Just follow the instruction and one should be good to go. It is a little weird in that our heater kicks on every so on for about 30 seconds. I am guess that it does this to constantly pump a little bit of heat into the house so that it isn't having to run for longer periods later to try and compensate for a colder ambient temperature or something. The weather has been rather moderate lately though so we haven't seen it have to do any substantial heating or cooling yet, but our house always seems to stay at the desired temperature, or above. I am curious how our bill will look, but I am guessing it will be pretty good, though I wont have anything to compare it to since I replaced the old one the day after we moved in. Yes this thermostat costs more than a traditional programmable thermostat, but it should save us a great deal of money over the next year or two, plus there are some decent rebates from the electric and gas companies where we live, so it puts it into the same ballpark. It just makes too much sense to swap the old "dumb" thermostats for these newer, smart ones.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: B. Roche
content: This is the second wifi thermostat I have had. I had trouble with the last one because the company's website was NOT stable - meaning I sometimes couldn't control my thermostat using wifi.  I have NOT had any trouble so far with the Nest thermostat's website being unstable. I chose the Nest thermostat because I thought it would work with my HVAC system wires.  I had a horrible time setting up my last wifi thermostat and I didn't want to go through that again!  I do NOT have a "C" wire on my system, but the Nest website said my four wires (red, yellow, blue and green) would work with no problem - and THEY WERE RIGHT!  I had NO trouble installing this thermostat - it took me about 15-minutes and everything work flawlessly as soon as I turned the power back on to my system. I also love the app for this thermostat.  The other day I was still in bed with the shades down and I pulled out my iPad to turn up the thermostat.  I noticed that on the main screen there was snow falling in the background and the weather said "20-degrees and Snowing".  I opened up the blinds and sure enough - it was snowing!  Another thing I really love is the instantaneous response after you set the thermostat - that is a breath of fresh air after my last wifi thermostat.  The thermostat looks very nice on the wall also. It is a "learning" thermostat but you have the ability to easily modify and adjust what it has "learned."  This is very important to me because I do not have a "set schedule" like some people have.  I really love this thermostat and I highly recommend it!
title: Excellent Thermostat - No "C" wire and it works GREAT!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Mark Durstewitz
content: I've ordered the Nest 3rd Gen thermostat because I like it's simple yet hi-tech design, and I will update this review once I finish testing it.  I am posting this question here in the meantime, because I see how quickly Nest Staff reply to Amazon customer concerns.  Thank you Nest! I live in Virginia near the coast, and there is a long stretch of many weeks in Spring and Fall where my HVAC system doesn't run at all (like right now).  Since I usually set my thermostat in the summer to 76, and 65 (augmented with a wood stove) in winter, on the Nest thermostat, I would much rather see what the ambient temperature is in the house instead of what the thermostat is set to.  At least give me the option to change the display.  I'd much rather see ambient temperature than a clock face. Just my 2 cents. And now that Alexa talks to the Nest thermostat, I've also sent Feedback to the Amazon Echo folks to please allow me to ask Alexa what the current house temperature is instead of just the outside temp.  Since I can't see the Nest's dial from my living spaces, I'd rather ask Alexa anyway! My Geothermal Florida Heat Pump SE only has 4 wires- G, W, Y and R.  The website compatibility program says the Nest will work, but I've read so many reviews that talk about flaky behavior without a Common wire that I wanted to ask those that already own one without a common wire and have not had any problems. I'm hoping this is the silent majority, since the Nest folks say that 95% of people don't have any problems without a common wire.  I guess all the critical reviews I've read are the other 5%. In my system, there is 28.7VAC between W and R, G and R, and Y and R when the HVAC unit is not running. I can see this potential on the thermostat's terminal board with my multimeter when the Honeywell programmable thermostat is removed. Will this voltage potential charge the Nest when the HVAC is idle, when it is running, or both? Or will I still have to run a Common wire from my HVAC to the baseplate? I ask this, because I've seen conflicting information on both Amazon's consumer reviews and on the Nest community website.  Some say when their system is off for weeks at a time due to mild temperatures, their Nest battery dies.  Others say that in extreme temperatures, their system runs so long that the Nest battery dies and their system never shuts off (in both cases there is no C wire). I know that HVAC's are different--that's why I included the voltages I am seeing when my unit is idle. Does the voltage potential between the three wires and R drop when the unit is running, causing the Nest to then rely on it's battery's charge until the system shuts down again and recharges the battery?  If that's the case, I can imagine the battery will quickly fail because of over-frequent charge and discharge.  Also, in extreme temperatures, if the unit comes on frequently the Nest may never have time to fully recharge between cycles. Thanks in advance!
title: I've ordered the Nest 3rd Gen thermostat because I like it's simple yet hi-tech design

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Athena
content: I really like this product and it works well, but I have one really strong warning:  TAKE A PICTURE OF THE **OLD** WIRING **BEFORE UNHOOKING IT**.  I didn't and I'm still trying to figure out how it was hooked up before to get the wiring right.  I've talked for hours to two different Nest support technicians who both finally gave up and told me to hire an electrician, which I can't afford to do.  So I'm stuck with a system that works well for now because the heat is wired correctly, but the air conditioning still isn't, so it's going to be a big problem when the warm weather returns. A bit more about why I like it: * It's SO easy to change the temp! * I strangely like the little clicks when you turn it  :) * The display is large enough to see what the temp is set to across the room * The system learned our preferences quickly * The motion sensor makes a nice night light when I get up at night (the Nest is in our bedroom) and turns off quickly enough after I go back to bed that it isn't annoying * It's nice to be able to change the temp from my phone -- I haven't done that much so far, but it's nice to know I can -- and that I can also change it when away from home * I like that it changes color for when the system is on (warming up the house) and when it's off (the house is at the set temp) * Except for my wiring issue, set up was relatively easy even for a mom (me) with little DIY or electrical experience What I don't like: * The tech support insists that the circuit breaker has to be turned off from the thermostat before you work on it, but it's only powered by 9 volts, so that really isn't necessary and just adds more work * The menu wasn't quite as intuitive as I'd hoped it would be, and there was a bit of a learning curve to figure it out initially
title: Great product, but TAKE A PICTURE OF YOUR OLD WIRING BEFORE YOU UNHOOK IT!!!!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Jeff H.
content: Standard for all my reviews: When reviewing products, I always remain objective and honest about the product or service. I always review with information that I feel others would like to know about the product as I always assume what I'm writing will influence for or against the purchase. I always try to go above and beyond surface characteristics and input into quality, value and application. Most importantly, I end the review with an answer as to whether I'd purchase the product again which I believe is the most critical question pertaining to the item. To manufacturers: Want me to review your items?  Just let me know! Installation was a breeze and it comes with everything you need for labeling your wires.  A couple of different face-plate options which was nice.  Installation took me no more than about 10-15 mins. and it worked like a charm right out of the box after connecting the proper wires.  Attaching to the home network was fast and intuitive and the onboard functionality is fantastic, from the configuration, learning settings, options, display, etc. I've been bragging to my friends about my new nest T-stat and showing it off every chance I get.  The added auto intelligence is great as it learns your desires and the reporting is great as well.  It just looks 'cool'. I'm not sure what else I can say about it other than it was a zero-pain install, fast setup and flawless performance to date.  Being such a good piece of technology, I expected some learning curve or difficulty and it's been set it and forget it for the most part.  The app for the iPhone is good and very convenient.  Again, setup and configuration is very intuitive and easy.  So much easier for the family to adjust as well if desired. I'm considering purchasing a couple of nest cams as well for the front of the house but am undecided if I really want to.  If I do decide to go the route of cams, I'll give Nest fair consideration as long as I want a wired unit. If you're looking at the Nest T-stat, it's because you are wanting something 'smarter' for your home.  The price isn't trivial but I'm so glad I purchased it and hoping that it pays us back quickly.  Would most certainly buy this again!
title: LOVE IT!

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: New England Mom
content: Overall very happy with our thermostats!  They look great and are incredibly easy to install (check out Nest install video - it saved me hundreds because I ended up doing install myself and didn't need to hire anyony after all).  The thermostats are also user friendly and the phone app is addictive (checking temps, adjusting temps for home and away).  My only criticism.... if your wifi cuts out your Nests go offline and stop working.  This can be a bad thing if the weather is very hot or very cold.  That said - you can choose to set up the Nest offline and it will work fine - like a "dumb" thermostat.  The problem only arises when the Nest is connected to the wifi (which is typically why people want it) and then the wifi cuts out.  So make sure you have good reliable wifi service before investing in a Nest.  I actually had to buy a wifi booster for one part of the home because the signal was weak and the Nest kept falling offline.  Once I installed the booster, though (inexpensive - purchased from Amazon) the Nest worked well - no problems.
title: Modern, energy efficient and very easy to use!

author: KindleKen
content: I just dropped it a star. Seems like a lot of things going on in background to make me wary of the future of this product. Also, ever since installing this Nest thermostat in my house for the main floor a/c, my a/c is, at times, problematic, condenser unit will occasionally make loud noise (requiring me to turn off the unit, wait 15 mins and start it again) and has trouble keeping the set point. Never used to have this problem with old thermostat. I had several a/c companies out to review the situation and check condenser and heating unit it connects to. None of them found any issues with condenser, or TXV valve inside, etc. They seem to suggest that their confidence in Nest products is not that high. Not sure if battery can't stay charged enough to do things from time to time? or worse? Trouble within the workings of the product. The same Nest unit I purchased for lower level a/c is working as expected. I really wanted this to work. The one good thing about it is being able to turn system off/on or change temps as needed from anywhere via my cellphone. Since I'm forever having to turn my a/c off and on to clear issues with setpoint temps, that has been helpful as I don't have to keep going back and forth to either of the two Nest Thermostat units in my house. I'm beginning to consider whether I should try other manufacturers' smart thermostats instead.

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Peter P
content: I have been using the Nest Thermostat for about 2-3 months now. I found the product to be easy to install, about 20 minutes total. The system just runs the AC in the house, but I have another on order for the heating system. At it's basic level, the thermostat does exactly what it is supposed to, turns on and off the AC as needed and keeps the house at the right temperature. Looking at what makes this thermostat more special, it make more sense as to why people spend the money they do on these. The auto-away feature can ensure you are not unnecessarily cooling (or heating) the house, mine is tied to my phone gps, but there is also the device itself that detects if someone is home. If you expand the nest eco system and have the protects installed, these can also be used to determine if anyone is home. The app also adds to the value of this product, with an easy to use and simple interface, but also the ability to control your temperature from anywhere. My simple use case for this was when I went on vacation for a week, the auto-away set the house to 80. At the start of my drive home I could see the house was at 80, and was able to overwrite the auto-away and have the house cooled down to 71 by the time I got home. Very nice to walk into. One feature I would like to see is an integration with Waze, even if done through IFTTT. If I say I am going home, have the system heat or cool the house to a preset temperature in time for me to walk through the door. Google owns both companies, so it would be great to see! I would highly recommend this thermostat. Check the wiring to make sure it will work for you first though: nest.com/works. Also, look at the negative reviews, if the manufacturer is responding, it is a sign they are committed to actually solving issues that arise.
title: I found the product to be easy to install

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: franko
content: My old thermostat required 4 wires (green, red, yellow, white). When you plug in that combination into the www.nest.com web site for compatibility, it says it will work. Yes, it will work BUT without having a common wire (blue) to charge the battery, it will take power from one of the other triggers. (default is fan (green), I believe) When it triggers the green wire, the fan turns on. Not good when it turns on at 3am and you are sleeping. I called customer service and the spent over half an hour trying to trouble shoot and to convince me my HVAC is confused. He even wanted to know if my old thermostat had the same problem. They know this 'trickle charge' is an issue with a four-wire system, yet, they don't mention that as a caveat for their product. I believe they want you to buy it then try to get some pro or someone to correct the issue, claiming their product is smart and smarter than me. Even if most systems out there will comply with a common wire, at the least, they would have happier customer/customer service if they were up-front with technical issues. Mostly, I don't care for their customer service. I was able to YouTube at video explaining a common wire and HVAC setup. Luckily, my wire bundle is a fire wire bundle and I connected the blue wire to the common terminals on both sides. One other comment: THE MAIN READING IS THE TARGET TEMP. THERE IS NO WAY TO CHANGE THAT TO SEE THE CURRENT TEMP. WHEN YOU'RE WALKING BY IT, YOU DON'T WANT TO SEE TARGET TEMP BECAUSE YOU KNOW WHAT YOU SET IT AT OR WHEN IT IS OFF TO SEE A BIG 'OFF'. WHAT IS MORE IMPORTANT IS THE CURRENT TEMP. AT LEAST HAVE THE OPTION OF BEING ABLE TO SEE SET OR CURRENT TEMP AS MAIN READING. After reading multiple reviews, these are common issues. To me, both of these issues seem easy to remedy or maybe I'm not as smart as my thermostat.
title: No common wire / Main reading is set temp / Nest customer service is terrible

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: bcurran3
content: I've been watching these for years thinking, "They're just so expensive, I can't justify paying that much for it." At Christmas time I had a few extra bucks to blow on SOMETHING small for the house. Amazon was offering a $50 card with the purchase. I said, "What the hell." I'm VERY pleased with it. I used to HATE programming my old thermostat. I never really got the old one tweaked the way I wanted it. The Nest Thermostat was easy to install (Instructions are great.) and super easy to adjust and program....while lying in bed! It's exciting for a few days, then it becomes just another appliance. It works really well though, and you'll like the monthly reports. Two features you have to experience to appreciate: 1> set a time and temperature schedule and it will be that temperature AT that time, not start at that time. If you wake up at 8AM, you'll have a warm house AT 8 AM not a cold house with hot air blowing out the vents trying to make it warm. 2> Presence detection and the auto-turn off of HVAC when no one is home - it does make sense and seem to save energy/money. I live in Southern California. I really don't need HVAC that much. It's March now. I haven't had heat on in over a month and I don't foresee AC on for another 3 months. But I now love my Nest Thermostat and smile at it when I walk by it in the hallway. p.s. I went and bought two of Nest's  smoke detectors. Again, I think they are overpriced (I'm frugal.), but I'm very pleasantly surprised by them. I plan on buying more.
title: " I'm VERY pleased with it

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Daniel Rosenblum
content: I bought a 3rd gen and 2 of the 2nd gens within the span of 2 months. Two of them have similar wiring setups and the 3rd is forced air a/c and heat. I have had problems with all 3. The forced air one initially was setup without a c wire and powered off over the coldest weekend this winter while I was away causing my pipes to freeze. I had to add a c wire and the issue now is that it keeps going into away mode even with setting a schedule. The other 2 thermostats had their bases short out. I turned off the power to put the trim plate on one I put the wires back in turned on the power and it shorted out both thermostats on that circuit. Nest kept me on the phone for about an hour running through the wiring and turning my power off and on then getting a volt tester and checking the wiring. What happens when my warranty is up? There is obviously a design flaw in the base. I like the convenience of the wifi thermostats, but would go with another brand if I had to start over. More than $650, rewiring my system and freezing pipes! No thanks!
title: I like the convenience of the wifi thermostats, but would go with another brand if I had to start over

product: Google T3007ES Nest Learning Thermostat 3rd Generation, Stainless Steel, Works with Amazon Alexa, 1
author: Simon Bernick
content: Hello, experienced reviewer here. I've been buying online and off amazon for years and I always research products before buying them. This thermostat is hands down one of the best home improvements I've ever made for number of reasons.  Let me start with some of the basics: 1. It looks great, the sleek design really makes something (thermostats) which was once boring a cool home feature. 2. Solid construction (metal and glass), it looks and feels like its not just some piece of electronic junk from China. 3. Easy installation, if you've set up a new iphone you can install this. Now for some of the other features that really bring this home.  First, you can get rebates on buying a smart thermostat.  I got $100 from my electric company (Comed) and $50 from my gas company (Peoples Gas) so this only actually cost me $100 to buy.  Second, not only does the thermostat turn off when you aren't home (saving you money), but it can also participate in hourly pricing programs (if your provider offers them).  My Nest automatically lets me know when the price of electricity goes above 10 cents a kWh in my area and I can choose to turn it off.  So between the two features I'm actually saving a lot of money on utilities and it paid for itself very quickly.  Add on top of that the learning feature which figures out what temperature you like based on your past settings and the ability to change the temperature without getting off the couch and this is a no brainer. Final Advise: Check to see if your gas and electric utilities offer a rebate for installing a smart thermostat, and if your electric company offers hourly pricing.  If the answer is yes then buy this product ASAP.  If not, I'd still suggest getting it.  You won't save as much money but you still will save some and its really a great product in and of itself.
title: This can save you a ton of money
